questions.text: A 35-year-old patient presents to the dental clinic with complaints of altered sensation in the lower lip and chin on the right side. The patient recently underwent a third molar extraction on the right side. On examination, there is evidence of sensory loss in the affected region. Which of the following nerves is most likely affected during the extraction procedure?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Mandibular nerve (V3):

  • The altered sensation in the lower lip and chin on the right side following a third molar extraction is suggestive of injury to the inferior alveolar nerve, a branch of the mandibular nerve (V3). The mandibular nerve is the third division of the trigeminal nerve (V) and provides sensory innervation to the lower face, oral cavity, and part of the tongue.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Maxillary nerve (V2): The maxillary nerve is responsible for sensory innervation of the upper face, and its branches are not typically involved in lower lip and chin sensation.

Option C - Trigeminal nerve (V): The trigeminal nerve consists of three divisions: ophthalmic (V1), maxillary (V2), and mandibular (V3). The mandibular division is the one primarily associated with the symptoms described.

Option D - Facial nerve (VII): The facial nerve is not involved in sensory innervation of the lip and chin; it is responsible for motor function of the muscles of facial expression.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presents to the emergency department after a fall from a height. On examination, there is tenderness and swelling over the right clavicle. An x-ray was taken. Which of the following structures is at risk for injury in this type of fracture?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Brachial plexus:

  • The given x-ray shows a clear case of Mid shaft fracture of clavicle.
  • A midshaft fracture of the clavicle can pose a risk to the brachial plexus, a network of nerves that supplies the upper limb. The brachial plexus runs in close proximity to the clavicle, and a fracture can result in injury to the nerves, leading to neurological symptoms such as pain, numbness, or weakness in the arm.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Subclavian artery: The subclavian artery is located deeper and is not typically at risk in a midshaft clavicle fracture.

Option C - Cephalic vein: The axillary vein is located more inferiorly and is not directly in the path of a midshaft clavicle fracture.

Option D - Suprascapular nerve: The suprascapular nerve travels over the superior border of the scapula and is not directly at risk in a midshaft clavicle fracture.

questions.text:
A 30-year-old female presents with a complaint of shoulder pain and the noticeable protrusion of her scapula on certain movements. On examination, the following finding is seen.



Which of the following conditions is most likely causing the observed finding?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Long thoracic nerve palsy:

  • The finding in the picture is scapular winging.
  • Scapular winging, the abnormal protrusion of the scapula from the thoracic wall, is often associated with dysfunction of the long thoracic nerve. The long thoracic nerve innervates the serratus anterior muscle, which plays a crucial role in stabilizing the scapula against the thoracic wall during arm movements. Damage to the long thoracic nerve can result in weakness or paralysis of the serratus anterior muscle, leading to scapular winging.

Incorrect Options:

  • Option A - Rotator cuff tear: While a rotator cuff tear can cause shoulder pain and weakness, it is not typically associated with scapular winging.
  • Option C - Suprascapular nerve entrapment: Suprascapular nerve entrapment may result in weakness in the supraspinatus and infraspinatus muscles but is not a common cause of scapular winging.
  • Option D - Subscapularis muscle weakness: Subscapularis muscle weakness alone is unlikely to cause scapular winging.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with weakness in his right leg and difficulty walking. On examination, there is evidence of a steppage gait. When asked to evert the foot, the patient exhibits significant weakness. Which nerve is most likely affected in this case?
questions.solution:
Correct C - Deep fibular (peroneal) nerve:

  • Foot eversion is primarily controlled by the muscles innervated by the deep fibular (peroneal) nerve. These muscles include the tibialis anterior, which dorsiflexes and inverts the foot. Weakness or paralysis of the deep fibular nerve can result in foot drop, characterized by difficulty lifting the foot and a steppage gait.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Tibial nerve: The tibial nerve primarily innervates muscles that plantarflex and invert the foot and is not associated with foot eversion.

Option B - Common fibular (peroneal) nerve: The common fibular nerve bifurcates into the deep and superficial fibular nerves. The deep fibular nerve is responsible for foot inversion.

Option D - Superficial fibular (peroneal) nerve: The superficial fibular nerve innervates muscles involved in foot dorsiflexion but is not the primary nerve responsible for foot eversion.

questions.text: During an arthroscopic examination of the shoulder, a tear is identified in a muscle that plays a crucial role in stabilizing the shoulder joint and is part of the rotator cuff. This muscle is located on the posterior aspect of the scapula and contributes to the external rotation of the shoulder. Which muscle is most likely affected in this case?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A – Infraspinatus:

  • The muscle located on the posterior aspect of the scapula that contributes to the external rotation of the shoulder and is part of the rotator cuff is the infraspinatus. Tears or injuries to the infraspinatus can lead to shoulder instability and weakness in external rotation.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Subscapularis: The subscapularis is located on the anterior aspect of the scapula and is responsible for internal rotation of the shoulder.

Option C - Supraspinatus: The supraspinatus is located on the superior aspect of the scapula and is primarily involved in the initiation of shoulder abduction.

Option D - Teres minor: While the teres minor is also involved in external rotation, it is not the muscle primarily located on the posterior aspect of the scapula and considered part of the rotator cuff.

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient presents with weakness and numbness in the shoulder region following a traumatic injury. On examination, there is weakness in abduction and external rotation of the arm. Sensation over the lateral aspect of the shoulder is also diminished. Which nerve is most likely affected in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Axillary nerve:

  • The clinical presentation of weakness in abduction and external rotation of the arm, along with sensory deficits over the lateral aspect of the shoulder, is indicative of damage to the axillary nerve. The axillary nerve innervates the deltoid and teres minor muscles, which are responsible for these movements.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Radial nerve: The radial nerve primarily innervates the muscles of the posterior compartment of the arm and forearm, and its dysfunction would result in different patterns of weakness.

Option C - Ulnar nerve: The ulnar nerve primarily innervates the intrinsic muscles of the hand, and its involvement would lead to weakness and sensory deficits in the hand and fingers.

Option D - Median nerve: The median nerve innervates muscles in the anterior compartment of the forearm and muscles in the thenar eminence of the hand. It is not typically associated with shoulder abduction or external rotation deficits.

questions.text:
A 25-year-old male presents to the emergency department with a history of falling onto an outstretched hand. Localized tenderness is found in the given region.



On examination, there is swelling and pain during axial compression of the thumb metacarpal. Which bone is most likely affected in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Scaphoid:

  • The anatomical snuffbox is a depression on the radial aspect of the dorsum of the hand, formed by the tendons of the extensor pollicis longus and brevis. Tenderness in this region following a fall onto an outstretched hand is concerning for a scaphoid fracture. The scaphoid is prone to fractures, especially in traumatic incidents, and its location makes it susceptible to injury.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Trapezium: The trapezium is a carpal bone located near the base of the thumb but is not typically associated with the anatomical snuffbox or the characteristic tenderness described.

Option B - Triquetrum: The triquetrum is one of the carpal bones located on the ulnar side of the wrist and is not directly related to the anatomical snuffbox.

Option C - Lunate: The lunate is another carpal bone, and its involvement is not associated with tenderness in the anatomical snuffbox.

questions.text: During a hernia examination, a protrusion is noted through the abdominal wall lateral to the inferior epigastric vessels. The examiner determines that this hernia originates deep to the transversalis fascia. Which structure serves as the opening through which this hernia passes?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Deep inguinal ring:

  • The deep inguinal ring is an opening in the transversalis fascia of the abdominal wall, located lateral to the inferior epigastric vessels. Hernias that originate deep to the transversalis fascia may protrude through this opening, giving rise to indirect inguinal hernias.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Superficial inguinal ring: The superficial inguinal ring is an opening in the external oblique aponeurosis and is not associated with hernias originating deep to the transversalis fascia.

Option B - Femoral canal: The femoral canal is a separate anatomical structure located inferior to the inguinal ligament. Femoral hernias pass through the femoral canal, which is distinct from the deep inguinal ring.

Option D - Inguinal ligament: The inguinal ligament forms the inferior border of the inguinal canal but is not an opening through which hernias pass.

questions.text:
A 28-year-old male presents with weakness in flexion of the forearm and numbness over the lateral aspect of the forearm following a traumatic injury. On examination, there is a weakness in doing the following action:



Also, sensory deficits are noted over the lateral forearm. Which nerve is most likely affected in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option - D Musculocutaneous nerve:

  • The musculocutaneous nerve innervates the muscles of the anterior compartment of the arm, including the coracobrachialis, biceps brachii, and brachialis. Injury to the musculocutaneous nerve can result in weakness in flexion of the forearm and supination. Additionally, the musculocutaneous nerve provides sensory innervation to the lateral aspect of the forearm. Injuries to the musculocutaneous nerve can occur due to trauma, such as direct blows or fractures.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Radial nerve: The radial nerve primarily innervates the muscles of the posterior compartment of the arm and forearm, and its dysfunction would result in different patterns of weakness.

Option B - Median nerve: The median nerve innervates muscles in the anterior compartment of the forearm, but it does not innervate the brachialis, which is primarily supplied by the musculocutaneous nerve.

Option C - Ulnar nerve: The ulnar nerve primarily innervates the intrinsic muscles of the hand, and its involvement would lead to weakness and sensory deficits in the hand and fingers.

questions.text: An athlete experiences a sudden increase in muscle tension during a workout. This increase in tension activates a sensory receptor that plays a crucial role in regulating muscle length. Which of the following physiological mechanisms is primarily associated with this sensory receptor and contributes to the modulation of muscle activity?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Golgi tendon reflex:

  • The Golgi tendon reflex is a mechanism associated with the regulation of muscle tension and length. Golgi tendon organs, located in the tendons at the junction of muscles and tendons, are activated in response to increased tension or contraction of the muscle. This reflex helps prevent excessive muscle contraction and potential damage by causing muscle relaxation.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Hering-Breuer reflex: It is associated with the regulation of respiratory rate and is activated by lung stretch receptors.

Option C - Bainbridge reflex: It involves stretch receptors in the atria and is associated with the regulation of cardiac output in response to increased venous return.

Option D - Bezold-Jarisch reflex: It is triggered by stimulation of receptors in the left ventricle and leads to a reduction in heart rate and blood pressure.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents to the emergency department with complaints of dizziness, weakness, and increased thirst for the past few days. He has a history of polyuria. On examination, he is tachycardic with a blood pressure of 90/60 mmHg. Laboratory investigations reveal hypernatremia and diluted urine. Which of the following best describes the primary physiological role of vasopressin in this patient's condition?

choices.text: Stimulation of water reabsorption in the collecting ducts
Promotion of sodium reabsorption in the proximal tubule

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Stimulation of water reabsorption in the collecting ducts:

  • The patient's symptoms of polyuria, polydipsia, hypernatremia, and concentrated urine are indicative of diabetes insipidus (DI). Diabetes insipidus is characterized by a deficiency of vasopressin (antidiuretic hormone), which plays a crucial role in regulating water balance in the body.
  • Vasopressin acts on the collecting ducts of the nephrons in the kidneys, increasing their permeability to water. This results in increased water reabsorption from the urine, concentrating it and reducing the amount of water excreted. In the absence of sufficient vasopressin, as seen in diabetes insipidus, excessive amounts of dilute urine are produced, leading to dehydration, hypernatremia, and the associated symptoms of dizziness and weakness.
  • Therefore, option B, "Stimulation of water reabsorption in the collecting ducts," best describes the primary physiological role of vasopressin in this patient's condition.

Incorrect Options:

  • Options A, C, and D are not directly related to the primary action of vasopressin on water reabsorption in the collecting ducts and are thus incorrect in this context.

questions.text: A 50-year-old right-handed male is brought to the emergency department after a witnessed sudden onset of speech difficulty. The patient is aware of his surroundings and appears frustrated when trying to communicate. On examination, there is weakness in the right side of the face and right upper and lower extremities. Additionally, there is a notable difficulty in initiating speech, with the patient only able to produce a few words at a time, despite having intact comprehension. Which of the following regions is most likely affected in this patient, leading to his expressive aphasia?

choices.text: Broca's area in the left frontal lobe
Wernicke's area in the left temporal lobe
Angular gyrus in the left parietal lobe
Primary auditory cortex in the left temporal lobe

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Broca's area in the left frontal lobe:

  • This patient's presentation is suggestive of a lesion in Broca's area, which is located in the left frontal lobe. Broca's area is crucial for the production of speech, and damage to this area often results in expressive aphasia. Patients with expressive aphasia have difficulty forming grammatically correct sentences and may struggle to initiate speech.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Wernicke's area in the left temporal lobe: Wernicke's area in the left temporal lobe, is associated with receptive aphasia, where patients have difficulty understanding language and may produce fluent but nonsensical speech.

Option C - Angular gyrus in the left parietal lobe: The angular gyrus in the left parietal lobe, is involved in reading and writing processes but is not primarily associated with expressive aphasia.

Option D - Primary auditory cortex in the left temporal lobe: The primary auditory cortex in the left temporal lobe, is responsible for processing auditory information but is not directly related to the expressive aspect of language production.

questions.text: The administration of tissue plasminogen activator (tPA) in a patient with acute stroke primarily targets which aspect of neuronal physiology?

choices.text: Calcium influx into the presynaptic terminal

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Action potential generation and propagation:

  • Tissue plasminogen activator (tPA) is administered in the context of acute ischemic stroke to restore blood flow by breaking down blood clots. The primary aim is to reestablish perfusion to the affected area of the brain and prevent further damage.
  • During an ischemic stroke, the lack of blood flow can compromise the ability of neurons to generate and propagate action potentials, leading to cellular dysfunction and damage. By restoring blood flow, tPA helps in maintaining the necessary conditions for proper action potential generation and propagation, reducing the impact of the ischemic insult on neuronal function.

Incorrect Options:

  • The administration of tPA does not directly target aspects such as sodium-potassium pump activity, synaptic transmission, or calcium influx into the presynaptic terminal.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male with a history of congestive heart failure presents to the emergency department with worsening shortness of breath and peripheral edema. On examination, the jugular venous pressure (JVP) is elevated, measuring 10 cm above the sternal angle with the patient in a 45-degree upright position. The patient reports compliance with prescribed medications, including diuretics. In this patient, the elevated jugular venous pressure is primarily indicative of:
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Right ventricular failure:

  • Elevated jugular venous pressure (JVP) is often associated with right heart failure. In the context of congestive heart failure, the right ventricle struggles to pump blood effectively into the pulmonary circulation, leading to increased venous pressure. This is reflected in the elevated JVP, especially when the patient is in an upright position.


Incorrect Options:

Option A - Increased cardiac output: It is unlikely in heart failure, as the heart's ability to pump blood efficiently is compromised.

Option C - Aortic stenosis: It primarily affects the left ventricle and is associated with a different set of clinical findings.

Option D - Hypovolemia: It would typically present with decreased JVP due to reduced venous return.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male with a history of hypertension presents to the clinic with complaints of cold hands and feet. Upon examination, the physician notes decreased peripheral blood flow and cool extremities. The patient's blood pressure is elevated. Which of the following physiological mechanisms contributes significantly to the observed vasoconstriction in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Activation of the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system:

  • Vasoconstriction refers to the narrowing of blood vessels, resulting in reduced blood flow to specific tissues or organs. In the context of hypertension, the activation of the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system (RAAS) plays a significant role in vasoconstriction.
  • When blood pressure is elevated, the juxtaglomerular cells in the kidneys release renin, initiating the conversion of angiotensinogen to angiotensin I, which is then converted to angiotensin II. Angiotensin II is a potent vasoconstrictor that acts on blood vessels to increase peripheral resistance and elevate blood pressure. This vasoconstrictive effect is particularly evident in the extremities, contributing to the observed symptoms of cool hands and feet in the patient.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Increased release of nitric oxide: It is not consistent with vasoconstriction. Nitric oxide is a vasodilator, and increased release would lead to vasodilation, not vasoconstriction.

Option C - Inhibition of endothelin-1 production: It is also inconsistent with vasoconstriction. Endothelin-1 is a vasoconstrictor, and its inhibition would lead to vasodilation.

Option D - Stimulation of beta-adrenergic receptors: It generally leads to vasodilation. Beta-adrenergic receptors, when activated, typically result in relaxation of smooth muscle in blood vessels, causing vasodilation.

questions.text: A 55-year-old female with a history of hypertension presents to the clinic with complaints of occasional fatigue and dyspnea. An electrocardiogram (ECG) is performed. Which of the following components of the ECG represents the duration from the onset of atrial depolarization to the onset of ventricular depolarization, and is likely to be affected in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - PR interval:

  • The PR interval on an electrocardiogram (ECG) represents the duration from the onset of atrial depolarization (P wave) to the onset of ventricular depolarization (beginning of QRS complex). This interval reflects the time it takes for the electrical impulse to travel from the atria to the ventricles through the atrioventricular (AV) node.
  • A prolonged PR interval may indicate an abnormal delay in the conduction of the electrical impulse between the atria and ventricles, commonly associated with conditions such as first-degree heart block or atrioventricular block.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - QT interval: It represents the time from the start of ventricular depolarization to the end of ventricular repolarization and is not directly related to the atrioventricular conduction.

Option C - RR interval: It is the duration between consecutive R waves and represents the cardiac cycle length. It includes both the depolarization and repolarization phases and is not specific to atrioventricular conduction.

Option D - QRS complex duration: It represents the duration of ventricular depolarization and is not directly related to the PR interval or atrioventricular conduction.

questions.text:
A 60-year-old male with chronic kidney disease presents to the emergency department with weakness and palpitations. Laboratory tests revealed the following:
 


	
		
			
			 
			
			
			Results 
			
		
		
			
			Plasma Na
			
			
			130 mEq/L
			
		
		
			
			K
			
			
			8.5 mEq/L
			
		
		
			
			Chloride
			
			
			98 mEq/L
			
		
	



Which of the following mechanisms contributes significantly to the electrolyte impairment in this patient?

choices.text: Enhanced cellular uptake of potassium by insulin
Altered potassium release from damaged cells

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Impaired renal excretion of potassium:

  • In the context of chronic kidney disease (CKD), impaired renal function is a common cause of hyperkalemia. The kidneys play a crucial role in maintaining potassium balance by excreting excess potassium. In CKD, the reduced glomerular filtration rate impairs the ability of the kidneys to excrete potassium efficiently, leading to elevated blood potassium levels.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Decreased intake of dietary potassium: It is less likely to contribute significantly to hyperkalemia, as the kidneys can usually adjust potassium excretion based on dietary intake.

Option C - Enhanced cellular uptake of potassium by insulin: It is a mechanism that lowers blood potassium levels and is not a typical contributor to hyperkalemia.

Option D - Altered potassium release from damaged cells: It is a potential cause of hyperkalemia, but in this patient with chronic kidney disease, impaired renal excretion is a more direct and common mechanism.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents to the emergency department with chest pain that worsens upon lying down and improves when leaning forward. On examination, the physician notes a friction rub during auscultation. Which of the following physiological processes contributes significantly to the characteristic chest pain in this patient?

choices.text: Activation of pain receptors in the myocardium
Inflammation and irritation of pericardial layers

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Inflammation and irritation of pericardial layers:

  • The patient is having Pericarditis. Pericarditis is characterized by the inflammation of the pericardial layers, which include the visceral and parietal pericardium. The rubbing of these inflamed layers during cardiac contraction and relaxation leads to the classic chest pain associated with pericarditis. The pain typically worsens when lying down and improves when leaning forward.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Increased coronary blood flow: It is not directly related to the characteristic chest pain of pericarditis. Increased coronary blood flow is more associated with conditions like exercise or myocardial demand.

Option B - Activation of pain receptors in the myocardium: It is not the primary mechanism in pericarditis. The pain in pericarditis is more related to irritation of the pericardial layers rather than the myocardium.

Option D - Vasoconstriction of coronary arteries: It is not a prominent factor in pericarditis. Vasoconstriction is more associated with conditions like angina.

questions.text: An infant was brought by his mother with complaints of poor appetite, poor growth, and irritability. The infant's urine smells like burnt sugar. Which of the following is associated with the condition that this patient is suffering from?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Thiamine pyrophosphate deficiency:

  • Thiamine pyrophosphate is an essential coenzyme for the BCKD complex, facilitating the decarboxylation of alpha-keto acids derived from branched-chain amino acids.
  • The deficiency associated with Maple Syrup Urine Disease (MSUD) is thiamine pyrophosphate deficiency.

Incorrect Optinos:

Option A - Vitamin D deficiency: Vitamin D deficiency is not associated with Maple Syrup Urine Disease (MSUD).

Option B - Cystathionine 𝛃 synthase deficiency: Cystathionine 𝛃 synthase deficiency is associated with homocystinuria.

Option C - α-keto acid carboxylase deficiency: Maple Syrup Urine Disease is an inherited metabolic disorder that affects the breakdown of certain amino acids, specifically leucine, isoleucine, and valine. It is caused by a deficiency in the enzyme α-keto acid decarboxylase (also known as branched-chain α-keto acid dehydrogenase complex), which is responsible for the breakdown of these amino acids not α-keto acid carboxylase.

questions.text: All the following are examples of oxidative phosphorylation step enzymes except:
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Succinyl Thiokinase:

  • Succinyl Thiokinase is an example of a substrate-level Phosphorylation step.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Isocitrate Dehydrogenase: Isocitrate Dehydrogenase is an example of oxidative phosphorylation step enzymes.

Option B - Alpha Ketoglutarate Dehydrogenase: Alpha Ketoglutarate Dehydrogenase is an example of oxidative phosphorylation step enzymes.

Option D - Succinate Dehydrogenase: Succinate Dehydrogenase is an example of oxidative phosphorylation step enzymes.

questions.text: A person working in the paint industry presents with a sudden onset of photosensitivity. What is the most sensitive parameter that can be prescribed by the physician for an early identiﬁcation of lead poisoning?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Elevated zinc protoporphyrin levels:

  • Lead can cause acquired porphyria.
  • Ferrochelatase – Elevated Zinc protoporphyrin levels – most sensitive marker.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Elevated ALA:

  • Lead inhibits Delta ALA dehydratase
  • Delta ALA dehydratase can result in ALA elevation. But this is not the most sensitive marker.

Option B - Elevated coproporphyrin levels: Elevated coproporphyrin levels is also a marker for lead poisoning but not the most sensitive marker.

Option D - High PBG levels: High PBG levels are seen in acute intermittent porphyria not in lead poisoning.

questions.text: All of the following are minor purine bases except?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D – Guanine:

  • Guanine is a major purine base not a minor purine base.

Incorrect Options:

Option A – Hypoxanthine: Hypoxanthine is a minor purine base.

Option B – Xanthine: Xanthine is a minor purine base.

Option C - Uric acid: Uric acid is a minor purine base.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male presents to the clinic with complaints of back pain and stiffness along with pain in hip and knee joints. On examination pigmentation in the eye and thickening of the ear cartilage were observed. Which of the following will be done as a screening test in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Benedict test:

  • The features of joint pain, and discoloration of the sclera and pinna all point toward the diagnosis of alkaptonuria
  • The screening test is Benedict's test. Then if it is positive, prescribe HPLC with tandem mass spectrometry

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Ferric chloride test: Ferric chloride test and Guthrie's test is a screen test for Phenylketonuria.

Option B - Guthrie's test: Ferric chloride test and Guthrie's test is a screen test for Phenylketonuria.

Option D - Cyanide nitroprusside test: Cyanide nitroprusside test is done to detect Homocystinuria.

questions.text: Copper in superoxide dismutase acts as which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Prosthetic group:

  • Copper in superoxide dismutase acts as a prosthetic group.

Incorrect Options:

Option B – Cofactor:

  • A cofactor is a non-protein in a transient dissociated incorporation with the protein part.
  • Examples: Calcium-dependent kinases.

Option C - Apoenzyme:

  • Coenzymes act as recyclable shuttle or group transfer agents.
  • Transfer group from one system to another system such as dolichol

Option D – Coenzymes:

  • All enzymes have a protein part and a non-protein part.
  • Protein part → apoenzyme

questions.text: A 7-month-old child presented with complaints of developmental delay. On examination features of hypotonia and hypothermia are observed. The infant has coarse and frizzy hair. On hair microscopy, Trichorrhexis nodosa is seen. Defect in which of the following is responsible for this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - ATP 7A:

  • ATP7A gene is a gene encoding copper-transporting ATPase enzyme.
  • There is impaired copper metabolism, and less copper levels are found in the liver and brain but high copper levels are found in ﬁbroblasts and enterocytes in Menke disease.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - ATP7B gene defect: ATP7B gene defect is seen in Wilson disease.

Option C - LIPA gene defect: LIPA gene defect is seen in Wolman Disease.LIPA is also known as LAL (Lysosomal acid lipase).

Option D - HGPRT enzyme deficiency: HGPRT enzyme deficiency is seen in Lesch Nyhan syndrome.

questions.text: Classical galactosemia is due to a deficiency of which enzyme?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Galactose-1-phosphate uridyl transferase:

  • Classical Galactosemia is due to the deficiency of the enzyme Galactose-1-phosphate uridyl transferase (GalPUT). It is a rare congenital autosomal recessive disorder. In this condition, galactose levels are increased in circulation and urine.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Aldose reductase: This enzyme is responsible for the conversion of the already accumulated Galactose-1-phosphate in the cells into dulcitol. Its deficiency does not cause classic Galactosemia.

Option B - Galactokinase: This enzyme is responsible for the conversion of galactose to galactose-1-phosphate. The deficiency of galactokinase causes Galactosemia type II.

Option D - UDP galactose-4-epimerase: This enzyme is responsible for the conversion of UDP-Galactose to UDP-Glucose. The deficiency of this enzyme causes a rare condition called epimerase deficiency galactosemia.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy presents with hypoglycemia, which does not respond to CR hormone administration. Blood examination reveals raised levels of ketone bodies, lactic acid, and triglycerides. Which of the following deficiencies is he suffering from?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Glucose-6-phosphatase:

  • The given features are consistent with the diagnosis of VON GIERKE DISEASE. In this disease, there is a deficiency of the enzyme glucose 6 phosphatase. It is the most common glycogen storage disorder.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Glucose-1-phosphate: Glucose-1-phosphate reacts in the presence of phosphorylase with aldoses and ketoses to yield disaccharides and ultimately produce glycogen and phosphoric acid. Also called Cori ester.

Option C - Glucose-1,6-diphosphate: Glucose-1,6-diphosphate is the central regulator in glycogen metabolism, glycolysis, amino sugar formation as well as bacterial cell wall and capsule formation.

Option D – Glycosaminoglycans: Glycosaminoglycans are heteropolysaccharides and consist of various sulfate-free and sulfate-containing compounds.Not related to von Girls disease

questions.text: Which of the following CD markers is commonly associated with B cells and plays a significant role in signal transduction, facilitating B cell receptor activation and subsequent immune responses?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - CD79a, CD79b:

  • CD79a and CD79b are signal transduction molecules associated with B cells. These molecules form the CD79 complex, also known as the Ig-alpha/Ig-beta heterodimer, which is part of the B cell receptor complex. The CD79 complex is involved in transmitting signals from the B cell receptor (BCR) to the interior of the B cell, leading to B cell activation and immune responses.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - CD10 (CALLA):

  • Refers to CD10 (CALLA), which is a marker for common acute lymphoblastic leukemia antigen and is found on B cells.

Option B - CD19:

  • Refers to CD19, which is a pan B cell marker and is important for B cell development and function.

Option C - CD20:

  • Refers to CD20, which is another B cell marker and is the target of monoclonal antibody therapies used in certain B cell malignancies.

questions.text: Which of the following toxins is responsible for ADP ribosylation of GTP?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D – Cholera toxin:

  • Cholera toxin is produced by Vibrio cholerae. It causes ADP ribosylation of the G protein subunit, leading to the persistent activation of adenylate cyclase and increased intracellular levels of cyclic AMP (cAMP). This results in the secretion of electrolytes and water into the intestinal lumen, leading to the watery diarrhea characteristic of cholera.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Shiga toxin:

  • Shiga toxin is produced by certain strains of Escherichia coli bacteria. It inhibits protein synthesis by specifically modifying the 28S subunit of the eukaryotic ribosome but does not involve ADP ribosylation of GTP.

Option B - Diphtheria toxin:

  • Diphtheria toxin is produced by Corynebacterium diphtheriae. It inhibits protein synthesis by ADP ribosylation of elongation factor 2 (EF-2), preventing the transfer of amino acids to the growing polypeptide chain.

Option C - Botulinum toxin:

  • Botulinum toxin, produced by Clostridium botulinum, inhibits the release of acetylcholine at the neuromuscular junction, leading to muscle paralysis. It does not involve ADP ribosylation of GTP.

questions.text: Which of the following organisms shows attachment/effacement lesions as shown in the image?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A – EPEC:

  • The organism which shows effacement and attachment of intestinal cells is EPEC (Enteropathogenic E. coli).
  • Enteropathogenic E.coli (EPEC) causes attaching and effacing lesions.
  • Paediatric age group diarrhoea (infantile) by attaching to enterocytes and causing their effacement.
  • Factors which promote attachment and effacement (loss of microvilli) are:
  • Bundle-forming pilus encoded by a plasmid EPEC adherence factor (EAF).
  • Chromosomal locus of enterocyte effacement (LEE).

Incorrect Options:

Option B – ETEC:

  • ETEC (Enterotoxigenic E.coli) causes attachment through CFA (colonization factor antigen).

Option C – EHEC:

  • EHEC (Enterohemorrhagic E.coli) causes VT (verotoxin) mediated capillary microangiopathy.

Option D - V. Cholerae.:

  • Vibrio cholerae lives in contaminated water.
  • It enters the human body by the consumption of uncooked seafood (e.g., raw shellfish).
  • Cholera toxin (enterotoxin) is a protein that causes “rice-water” diarrhoea.
  • It causes bacterial gastroenteritis.

questions.text: HPV 16 and 18 subtypes of HPV has maximum chances of causing carcinoma cervix. Which of the following structure of HPV is responsible for causing carcinoma?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C – E6 and E7:

  • Rb gene (early gene) controls early viral production during the infection period.
  • Products of E6 and E7 interfere with p53 and Rb genes, as a result of this interference, cause:
  • Immortalization and malignant transformation of keratinocytes.
  • Keratinocytes that are immortalized histomorphological display hallmarks of high-grade squamous intraepithelial lesions and become precursors of cervical carcinoma.

Incorrect Options:

Option A – E4 and E5:

  • E4 and E5 are responsible for making a change in the cell called Koilocytosis.

Option B – E2:

  • E2 is a regulatory protein involved in the control of viral replication and transcription. While it plays a role in the HPV life cycle, it is not directly responsible for the oncogenic transformation leading to carcinoma.

Option D – L1:

  • L1 is the major capsid protein of HPV and is primarily involved in the formation of the viral capsid. It is not associated with the cellular changes that lead to carcinoma.

questions.text: What is the most likely causative agent for the respiratory symptoms in a 25-year-old wool industry worker with shortness of breath, fever. A sputum sample was collected which showed a 'string of pearl' appearance on culture on blood agar with penicillin?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B – Bacillus anthracis:

  • A string of pearl appearance is seen in Bacillus anthracis on Penicillin agar. Blood Agar + 0.5 -0.50 u/ml of Penicillin - spherical cells are seen.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Clostridium:

  • Clostridium is a anaerobic organism and blood agar supports the growth of aerobic organism, even if the anaerobic conditions are created clostridium colonies may appear round, smooth, and convex.

Option C - Pneumococcus:

  • Pneumococcus: Draughtsman /carrom coin colonies on blood agar.

Option D - Staph. aureus:

  • BA [blood agar] - causes β hemolysis - pin head size colonies

questions.text: What is the most likely identification of the parasitic infection in a 28-year-old traveler with abdominal pain, bloody mucus in stools, and fever. A histopathological finding is observed as shown in the image:
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Entamoeba histolytica:

  • The clinical presentation of abdominal pain, bloody diarrhea, fever, and histological finding of flask shaped ulcer are consistent with Entamoeba histolytica.

Flask Shaped Ulcer:

  • Damages the mucosa and submucosa.
  • Can't damage the muscularis as it is difficult to break.
  • Thus, it starts breaking submucosa on left and right.
  • Resulting in flask shaped ulcer.
  • Inside flask shaped ulcers- Trophozoites are seen.
  • Trophozoites have 1 big nucleus and small engulfed RBCs (Erythrophagocytosis).

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Giardia lamblia:

  • Giardia does not exhibit the described features, and it causes watery diarrhea, not bloody diarrhea.

Option C - Cryptosporidium parvum:

  • Cryptosporidium parvum can cause diarrhea, especially in immunocompromised individuals, but it does not exhibit the described trophozoite morphology.

Option D - Trichomonas vaginalis:

  • Trichomonas is a flagellated protozoan that causes genitourinary infections and does not have the features mentioned.

questions.text: What's the likely organism responsible for a 55-year-old HIV-positive man with cavitary lung lesions, fever, and yeast morphology in a lung aspirate sample while on ART treatment, and complaining of neck stiffness and headache?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Cryptococcus neoformans:

  • The organism responsible is Cryptococcus neoformans.
  • This fungal infection commonly affects immunocompromised individuals, such as those with HIV.
  • The patient's symptoms, including cavitary lung lesions, fever, and yeast morphology in the lung aspirate sample, are consistent with Cryptococcus infection.
  • Neck stiffness and headache are indicative of possible fungal meningitis, a common complication of disseminated Cryptococcus infection in HIV-positive individuals.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Candida:

  • Candida is a common opportunistic fungal pathogen in individuals with HIV/AIDS, but it typically causes candidiasis, which may involve mucosal surfaces, the bloodstream, or internal organs. Cavitary lung lesions are not a typical presentation for Candida.

Option C - Penicillium marneffei:

  • Penicillium marneffei is an opportunistic fungus endemic in Southeast Asia, and it is seen in individuals with advanced HIV/AIDS. While it can cause disseminated infection, including lung involvement which often include diffuse infiltrates or nodules., it is not a typical cause of cavitary lung lesions.

Option D - Aspergillus fumigatus:

  • Aspergillosis is an infection caused by a mould called aspergillus fumigatus
  • People with weak immune systems and lung diseases are at greater risk of developing this infection.
  • Aspergillus is also known for causing sinusitis, resulting in stuffiness, runny nose, headache and reduced ability to smell.

questions.text: A 22-year-old patient presents with fever, vomiting, neck rigidity, and rash. The doctor sends the patient lab tests. On microscopy, lens-shaped gram-negative cocci are seen. Biochemical tests of this organism show glucose and maltose fermentation. What can be the most dreadful complication seen in this case?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Waterhouse Friderichsen syndrome:

  • This clinical scenario and sample microscopy indicate Meningococcal meningitis. Maltose and glucose fermentation is specific for this class of bacteria. Fever, vomiting, headache, neck rigidity, and rash are typical symptoms.
  • The Most common severe complication of Meningococcal infection is Water-House Friderichsen syndrome causing bilateral adrenal hemorrhagic necrosis. In this syndrome, adrenal glands fail to function normally.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Water-can perineum:

  • It is a condition that results in the multiple fistulae extending from the urethra to open inside the perineum.
  • They can result as a result of chronic inflammatory strictures. They are primarily seen in gonorrheal infections.

Option B - Fitz Hugh Curtis syndrome:

  • It is a syndrome in which inflammation of the liver capsule occurs associated with adhesion formation, resulting in pain in the right upper quadrant.

Option C – Polyarthritis:

  • It is used when at least five or more joints are involved with pain and discomfort. Swelling, warmth, and redness are typical physical presentations.
  • This condition is mainly caused by an auto-immune disease such as rheumatoid arthritis or systemic lupus erythematosus. But it can also be caused due to alphavirus.

questions.text: What is the likely causative agent for the distinctive sickle-shaped organism and 'falling leaves' motility in a 28-year-old with foul-smelling diarrhea, abdominal cramps, and bloating?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Giardia lamblia:

  • The clinical presentation of foul-smelling, greasy diarrhea, abdominal cramps, and bloating, along with the presence of a distinctive sickle-shaped organism within the lumen and trophozoite motility resembling falling leaves, is characteristic of Giardia lamblia infection. Giardia trophozoites have a characteristic "falling leaf" motility, where their flagella-driven movement resembles the fluttering of leaves.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Entamoeba histolytica:

  • Entamoeba histolytica causes dysentery and amoebic colitis but does not exhibit the described morphology or motility.

Option C - Balantidium coli:

  • Balantidium coli is a ciliated protozoan and does not show the described sickle shape or falling leaf motility.

Option D - Dientamoeba fragilis:

  • Dientamoeba fragilis exhibits sickle-shaped cysts but does not show falling leaf motility.

questions.text: What determines the maintenance rate of amoxicillin-clavulanic acid in the treatment of a 23-year-old male with sore throat, dry cough, headache, and runny nose for four days?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Total body clearance:

  • This is a case of acute pharyngitis in which the patient presents with complaints of sore throat, dry cough, headache and runny nose for four days.
  • On examination of the throat, there is erythema of the tonsils and pharynx without exudates. The doctor prescribed a combination medication of amoxicillin- clavulanic acid twice a day for five days to the patient.
  • Maintenance dose depends on clearance and target plasma concentration.
  • With respect to this case, since targeted plasma concentration is not mentioned, total body clearance is the answer.
  • Amoxicillin and beta-lactams, in general, cause time-dependent killing, and we tend to maintain a dose above the MIC for the maximum time possible.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Volume of distribution:

  • This parameter reflects the apparent space in the body available to contain the drug. While it is important for understanding how the drug distributes in the body, it does not directly determine the maintenance rate of the drug.

Option B - Half-life:

  • The half-life of a drug is the time in which an active drug in the body is reduced to half. It depends upon the metabolism and excretion of a drug.

Option C - Lipid solubility:

  • The solubility of a drug determines its metabolism and the metabolism determines the onset of action of the drug.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man comes to your office with complaints of chronic insomnia. His vital signs are normal. He had never taken any medication for insomnia before. After reviewing his medical history, you decide to prescribe zolpidem. Which of the following is a strong reason to choose zolpidem over a benzodiazepine?

choices.text: Zolpidem does not bind to the GABA receptor
Zolpidem has a slow onset of action
Zolpidem has a lower risk of tolerance and dependence

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Zolpidem has a lower risk of tolerance and dependence:

  • Zolpidem, zaleplon and zopiclone are non-benzodiazepine hypnotics
  • These are hypnotics that lack a muscle relaxant and anticonvulsant effect.
  • These have a negligible effect on REM sleep and do not affect sleep architecture.
  • Zolpidem is a short-acting hypnotic that binds to the GABA receptor and has a lower risk of tolerance and dependence than benzodiazepines.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Zolpidem does not bind to the GABA receptor:

  • Zolpidem binds to the GABA receptor

Option B - Zolpidem has a slow onset of action:

  • Zolpidem has a rapid onset of action.

Option D - Zolpidem is a strong anticonvulsant:

  • The doses of zolpidem required to produce anticonvulsants and muscle relaxation are 10-20 times higher than the doses required for sedation.
  • This makes zolpidem a weak anticonvulsant and muscle relaxant.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man has been experiencing abdominal pain in the gastric region for the past month. The pain is described as burning, not radiating to the back, worsening within 15 minutes of eating, and accompanied by vomiting that provides partial relief. On examination, the patient exhibits the finger pointing sign, deep tenderness at the epigastrium, and signs of anemia. Additionally, the individual has a 20-pack-year history of smoking and consumes alcohol. What might be the likely diagnosis and recommended treatments?

choices.text: Gastric ulcer, proton pump inhibitors (PPIs), bismuth subsalicylate, advise stopping smoking and alcohol
Duodenal ulcer, proton pump inhibitors (PPIs), bismuth subsalicylate, advise stopping smoking and alcohol
Pancreatic ulcer, proton pump inhibitors (PPIs), bismuth subsalicylate, advise stopping smoking and alcohol
Gastro-Esophageal Reflux Disease, proton pump inhibitors (PPIs), bismuth subsalicylate, advise stopping smoking and alcohol

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Gastric ulcer, proton pump inhibitors (PPIs), bismuth subsalicylate, advice to stop smoking and alcohol:

  • The patient of gastric ulcer disease presents with the same given symptoms, such as epigastric pain that is burning in character, not radiating to the back, increases with intake of food within 15 minutes, and is associated with vomiting that relieves pain to some extent.
  • The gastric ulcer can cause the stomach lining to bleed, leading to anaemia showing fatigue and pale skin, e.t.c. The gastric ulcer pain is so sharply localized that the patient can easily define it with two or three fingers showing a finger-pointing sign.
  • Smoking and alcohol are the causative agents in this case. Smoking stimulates basal acid output causing gastric ulcers.
  • Treatment options are :
    • PPIs, Proton pump inhibitors e.g. omeprazole, lansoprazole and pantoprazole. Side effects are nausea, headache, Pseudomembranous enterocolitis and bone fractures.
    • H2 receptor antagonists, e.g. ranitidine, cimetidine and famotidine. Side effects are confusion, Neurotoxicity, cardiotoxicity , gynecomastia and nausea.
    • Bismuth compounds. Side effects are blackening of stool, darkening of tongue and encephalopathy.
    • Prostaglandin analogues. Side effects are abdominal pain and diarrhoea.
    • Antacid contains magnesium and aluminium.
  • Lifestyles must be changed, such as quitting smoking and alcohol are necessary.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Duodenal ulcer, proton pump inhibitors (PPIs), bismuth subsalicylate, advise stopping smoking and alcohol:

  • In duodenal ulcers, pain is relieved by taking food and restarts after 2-3 hours. The patients tend to eat more to relieve their pain.

Option C - Pancreatic ulcer, proton pump inhibitors (PPIs), bismuth subsalicylate, advise stopping smoking and alcohol:

  • In pancreatic ulcers, the patient presents with epigastric pain radiating to the back in the interscapular region.

Option D - Gastro-Esophageal Reflux Disease, proton pump inhibitors (PPIs), bismuth subsalicylate, advise stopping smoking and alcohol:

  • The patient presents with deep pain behind the sternum radiating to the throat.

questions.text: What medication, primarily functioning by opening cardiac potassium channels, can be employed for treating and preventing angina in a 48-year-old male with severe left-sided chest pain, a history of hypertension and ischemic heart disease, and poor control of cardiac symptoms despite being on nitrates, beta blockers, and diuretics?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Nicorandil:

  • Based on the symptoms of severe left-sided chest pain, a significant history of hypertension, ischemic heart disease, and a history of taking nitrates, beta blockers and diuretics for the cardiac symptoms, the patient is likely suffering from angina.
  • Angina pectoris is characterized by recurrent attacks of retrosternal chest pain, pressure or tightness secondary to myocardial ischemia. Triggering factors include stress or exertion, which increases oxygen demand in the myocardium.
  • The objectives of management are to improve ischemia, reduce cardiovascular morbidity and mortality and maintain quality of life.
  • Nicorandil is a novel anti-angina drug that acts by activating potassium channels at myocytes and has arterial vasodilator properties. It activates ATP-sensitive K+ channels, thereby hyperpolarizing vascular smooth muscle.
  • At low doses, it possesses nitrate-like properties and dilates coronary arteries.
  • It acts as a potassium channel agonist at higher doses and reduces coronary arterial resistance by opening potassium channels. It also stimulates guanylate cyclase, which activates cyclic GMP, ultimately increasing nitric oxide concentration.
  • It is also believed to have cardioprotective action by mimicking 'ischemic preconditioning' by activating mitochondrial K-ATP channels.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Ranolazine:

  • It shifts ATP production away from fatty acid oxidation, i.e., partial inhibition of fatty acid oxidation, in favour of more oxygen-efficient glucose oxidation.
  • It inhibits the late phase of the inward moment of sodium current into the myocardial cells, improving the oxygen supply and demand equation.
  • It has anti-anginal as well as antiarrhythmic properties.
  • Higher doses inhibit rapid delayed rectifier potassium current, thereby prolonging ventricular action potential(Add Mild QT prolongation)

Option C - Verapamil:

  • It is a traditional anti-anginal drug.
  • It is a centrally acting calcium channel blocker acting mainly on cardiac myocytes.
  • It slows AV conduction directly and decreases HR, contractility, BP and oxygen demand.

Option D – Lidocaine:

  • It is not an anti-anginal drug. Rather, it is a class IB antiarrhythmic drug.
  • It is a membrane-stabilizing antiarrhythmic agent.
  • Mainly recommended in controlling ventricular arrhythmias by suppression of automaticity in the His-Purkinje system and by suppression of spontaneous ventricular depolarization.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding pilocarpine is correct?

choices.text: Pilocarpine acts by opening cardiac potassium channels, providing relief from angina symptoms.
Pilocarpine is contraindicated in patients with glaucoma due to its potential to increase intraocular pressure.
The primary mechanism of action of pilocarpine is the stimulation of muscarinic acetylcholine receptors.
Pilocarpine is commonly used as a first-line agent for the treatment of hypertension.

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - The primary mechanism of action of pilocarpine is the stimulation of muscarinic acetylcholine receptors:

  • The primary mechanism of action of pilocarpine is the stimulation of muscarinic acetylcholine receptors. Pilocarpine is a muscarinic receptor agonist, and its stimulation leads to the constriction of the pupil (miosis) and increased drainage of aqueous humor, making it a valuable medication in the treatment of glaucoma.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Pilocarpine acts by opening cardiac potassium channels, providing relief from angina symptoms:

  • Pilocarpine primarily affects muscarinic receptors, particularly in the eye, leading to pupillary constriction. It is not used for the treatment of angina or the opening of cardiac potassium channels.

Option B - Pilocarpine is contraindicated in patients with glaucoma due to its potential to increase intraocular pressure:

  • Pilocarpine is actually used in the treatment of glaucoma. It works by decreasing intraocular pressure through its effects on the muscarinic receptors in the eye.

Option D - Pilocarpine is commonly used as a first-line agent for the treatment of hypertension:

  • Pilocarpine is not commonly used for the treatment of hypertension. It is primarily indicated for glaucoma and certain ophthalmic procedures due to its ability to constrict the pupil and reduce intraocular pressure.

questions.text: A researcher is examining the impact of a drug on cardiomyocyte contraction, finding that maximal contractility is attainable with drug A. The investigator has evaluated the safety and toxicity profile of the novel drug. Which of the subsequent statements most accurately characterizes phase IV clinical trials?

choices.text: It is done for pediatric drugs
It is done for rare drugs
It is post-marketing surveillance of drugs
It is also called human pharmacology and safety studies

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - It is post-marketing surveillance of drugs:

Phase IV clinical trials:

  • Post-marketing surveillance compares the real-life efficacy to that described in research studies.
  • Safety studies following approval (esp. evaluation of rare and long-term side effects)
  • The study population is many patients with a specific disease after drug approval.
  • The study design is open-label.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - It is done for pediatric drugs:

  • Phase IV clinical trial includes post-marketing studies. Phase IV trials are meant to identify the long-term risks of drug treatment beyond those discovered during initial trials.
  • They are not just done for pediatric drugs to assess the long-term adverse effects of any drug being sent to the market.

Option B - It is done for rare drugs:

  • Phase IV clinical trials are done for all the approved drugs from phases one to three. Thus include the post-marketing studies of all drugs and assess the long-term adverse effects.

Option D - It is also called human pharmacology and safety studies:

  • Phase I clinical trials are known as human pharmacology and safety studies.
  • Phase I clinical trials assess drug safety and determine tolerable drug dosages.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding the use of Allopurinol and Febuxostat in patients with acute gout?

choices.text: Allopurinol and Febuxostat should be initiated as monotherapy to reduce uric acid levels in acute gout.
Allopurinol and Febuxostat should be combined with NSAIDs and Colchicine for a longer duration in acute gout.
Allopurinol and Febuxostat are not contraindicated in acute gout and can be used safely.
Allopurinol and Febuxostat should be avoided altogether in patients with acute gout.

questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Allopurinol and Febuxostat should be avoided altogether in patients with acute gout:

  • This statement is correct. Allopurinol and Febuxostat are contraindicated in patients with acute gout. Using these drugs during an acute gout attack can increase the risk of exacerbating the condition. This is because Allopurinol and Febuxostat work by reducing uric acid levels in circulation over time, but when used during an acute gout attack, they can cause uric acid crystals to be released from tissues, leading to more severe symptoms. It is recommended to avoid these drugs during acute gout episodes.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Allopurinol and Febuxostat should be initiated as monotherapy to reduce uric acid levels in acute gout:

  • This statement is incorrect. Initiating Allopurinol and Febuxostat as monotherapy during an acute gout attack is not recommended, as it can worsen the condition by releasing uric acid crystals from tissues.

Option B - Allopurinol and Febuxostat should be combined with NSAIDs and Colchicine for a longer duration in acute gout:

  • This statement is incorrect. Combining Allopurinol and Febuxostat with NSAIDs and Colchicine for a longer duration during an acute gout attack is not the recommended approach. Instead, it is suggested to use NSAIDs or Colchicine initially and then continue Allopurinol or Febuxostat for long-term management after the acute attack has subsided.

Option C - Allopurinol and Febuxostat are not contraindicated in acute gout and can be used safely:

  • This statement is incorrect. Allopurinol and Febuxostat are contraindicated in acute gout, as their use during an acute attack can worsen the condition. It is essential to avoid these medications when a patient is experiencing an acute gout episode.

questions.text: Biochemical mechanisms of drug resistance are shown in the given figure below. Which of the following is the most important mode of resistance in MRSA?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A – A:

  • Resistance in MRSA occurs mainly because of altered penicillin-binding proteins.
  • This is marked as "A" in this scenario, wherein the modification of the target site is how MRSA commonly develops resistance.
  • The penicillin-binding proteins like transpeptidase are responsible for linking the peptidoglycan chains in the cell wall of the bacteria

Incorrect Options:

Option B – B:

  • Decreased permeability is the mode of resistance of some gonococci to penicillins

Option C – C:

  • Some organisms produce Beta-lactamases, also known as penicillinase, that degrade the Beta-lactam ring of penicillin if the enzyme encounters it.

Option D - D:

  • Bypass of the metabolism and forming the alternate pathway is a mode of resistance of some organisms to few drugs, not penicillin

questions.text: Which of the following drugs inhibits URAT to block reabsorption of uric acid and may increase the risk of uric acid stone formation?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B – Sulfinpyrazone:

  • This is a uricosuric drug that inhibits URAT (uric acid transporter) to block the reabsorption of uric acid. By doing so, it increases the excretion of uric acid in the urine, making it a useful medication for treating gout and hyperuricemia. However, an important side effect of uricosuric drugs is an increased risk of uric acid stone formation, which is why proper hydration is recommended when using them.

Incorrect Options:

Option A – Allopurinol: Allopurinol is not a uricosuric drug; it is a xanthine oxidase inhibitor. It works by reducing the production of uric acid in the body, making it less likely to form uric acid stones.

Option C – Colchicine: Colchicine is not a uricosuric drug either. It is an anti-inflammatory medication used to relieve gout pain and inflammation during acute gout attacks.

Option D – Prednisone: Prednisone is a corticosteroid medication used for its anti-inflammatory and immunosuppressive effects in various inflammatory conditions. It does not directly affect uric acid levels or uric acid stone formation.

questions.text: What is the pertinent information about the drug administered, Pralidoxime, in the case of a 49-year-old man with altered consciousness, bradycardia, hypotension, sweating, and constricted pupils, who received the medication after being found on the ground by his wife?

choices.text: It should be started after 24 hours of poisoning

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - It is given Intravenously:

  • This is a case of organophosphate poisoning.
  • Pralidoxime is an oxime which is given intravenously.
  • 30 mg/kg i.v. loading dose, followed by 8- 10 mg/kg/hour continuous infusion till recovery
  • Oximes are given for the reactivation of the inhibited acetylcholinesterase in organophosphate poisoning.
  • Two oximes are used :
    • PAM (Pralidoxime): does not cross the blood-brain barrier.
    • DAM (Diacetyl mono-oxime): crosses the blood-brain border, both central and peripheral action.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - It should be started after 24 hours of poisoning:

  • Oximes (pralidoxime and diacetyl mono-oxime ) should be started as soon as possible after atropine is given.
  • If taken a long time, then enzyme ageing may occur (enzyme cannot work)

Option C - It crosses the blood-brain barrier:

  • Pralidoxime cannot cross the blood-brain barrier.
  • There is another oxime called diacetyl mono-oxime; it can cross the blood-brain barrier.

Option D - Inhibits acetylcholinesterase enzyme:

  • Pralidoxime is given for the reactivation of the inhibited acetylcholinesterase in organophosphate poisoning.
  • Organophosphate inhibits the acetylcholinesterase enzyme

questions.text: What population is served by a single Primary Health Center (PHC) in the hilly areas?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C – 20000:

  • In the hilly areas, the population covered by one Primary Health Center (PHC) is generally around 20,000. PHCs are the basic units of healthcare delivery in rural areas.

Incorrect Options:

Option A – 10000: This population size is not associated with the population covered by Primary Health Centers.

Option B – 30000: In the plain areas, the population covered by one Primary Health Center (PHC) is generally around 30,000.

Option D – 40000: This population size is not associated with the population covered by Primary Health Centers.

questions.text: Which among the following is included in the provision of services at the logo given below?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - RTI/ STI services:

  • The logo of Suraksha Clinic is a white color with a red dot for reproductive and sexual health services under the NACP

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Immunization services: Suraksha Clinic primarily focuses on reproductive and sexual health services; immunization services are not typically provided.

Option B - Blood transfusion safety services: Suraksha Clinic does not specifically provide blood transfusion safety services.

Option D - Diarrhea control services: Diarrhea control services are not typically part of the services offered at the Suraksha Clinic.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman was started on a COCP regimen, takes a pill at 10 pm on day 1. She forgot to take the pill on day 2, and by 2 pm on day 3, she realized she missed the previous night's dose. She is currently in the first week of her COCP cycle. What would be the most appropriate next step in managing her situation?

choices.text: Take the missed pill at 2 pm and at night, she can take her regular pill
No need to take the missed pill and continue with her regular pill at 10 pm
Use the barrier method for the next 7 days

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Take the missed pill at 2 pm and at night, she can take her regular pill:

  • She can take the missed pill as soon as she remembers. At night, she can take her regular pill.
  • This means she can take two pills a day.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - No need to take the missed pill and continue with her regular pill at 10 pm:

  • She must take the missed pill along with the regular pill

Option C - Emergency contraception:

  • Emergency contraception is only required In case of unprotected sex in the last 72 hours when she Miss >= 3 pills in ﬁrst or second week or started new pack 3 days late

Option D - Use the barrier method for the next 7 days:

  • If she misses more than equal to three pills, she needs to take a barrier method.

questions.text: Expired medicines are disposed of in which of the following BMW categories?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B – Yellow:

  • Discarder/ Expired medicines, also known as biomedical waste or BMW, are disposed of in the yellow BMW category.
  • BMW refers to any waste generated during healthcare activities that may contain biological material and pose a risk of infection or contamination.
  • This includes anatomical waste such as human tissues, organs, body fluids, and body parts.
  • The yellow BMW category is specifically designated for the collection, storage, transportation, and disposal of these types of waste

Incorrect Option:

Option A - Red: The red BMW category typically refers to Contaminated waste that is recyclable such as Rubber and plastic tubes.

Option C - White: The white BMW category usually represents Sharps.

Option D – Blue: Blue is commonly associated with Glass and metallic implants.

questions.text: Which of the following about the composition of new ORS is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Total osmolarity - 300 mmol/L:

  • Two types of ORS
    • Standard ORS (previous)
    • Reduced osmolarity ORS (new)
  • The total osmolarity in reduced osmolarity ORS (new) is 245 mmol/L

Incorrect Options:

Options A, B, and C are correct regarding the composition of the new ORS:

  • NaCl - 2.6 g/L
  • KCl - 1.5 g/L
  • Glucose - 13.5 g/L

questions.text: A 35-year-old male, Rahul, visits his family doctor for a health check-up. The family doctor is advising Rahul on adequate nutritional requirements. Rahul tells the doctor that his weight is 65kg, is an IT professional and has a sedentary lifestyle. According to the latest NIN RDA guidelines, how many calories should Rahul take?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - 2110 kcal:

  • As Rahul is an IT professional, he has a sedentary life therefore the calorie to be taken by him is 2110 kcal/day according to the new energy guidelines.

Incorrect Options:

questions.text: Which of the following is true about type 1 errors?

choices.text: The null hypothesis is false but accepted
A new drug launched in the market is not better than the existing drug

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - A new drug launched in the market is not better than the existing drug:

Type 1 Error

  • Also known as alpha error
  • Null hypothesis is true but rejected
  • Shows a false positive trial
  • Serious type of error
  • A new drug launched in the market is not better than the existing drug

Incorrect Options:

Options A, B and D:

  • They represent Type2/Beta error in which the null hypothesis is false but accepted and false negative trial is seen.

questions.text: A study is being conducted to understand an association between carpel tunnel syndrome and smartphone use. A group of 60 people with carpel tunnel syndrome and 60 without carpal syndrome was chosen for this study which shows 36 people who had carpel tunnel syndrome were smartphone users. what kind of study is being done here?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - A case-control study:

  • In the case of the case-control study, there is an effect to cause and it starts from disease. This study is hence a case-control study.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Prospective cohort study: The prospective cohort study is a cause-to-effect type of study. hence, this choice is incorrect.

Option B - Retrospective cohort study: The retrospective cohort study is a study where the effect has already occurred and it is a recall study using historical data. This is not a retrospective study.

Option D - Descriptive study: It is the Study of the distribution of health-related events & identification of characteristics. This is not a descriptive study.

questions.text: Under which benefit in the ESI Act, do beneficiaries receive 80% of their wages for two years?

questions.text: A 4-year-old child was playing in the garden when he was scratched by a street dog. The boy is rushed to the hospital immediately. On examination, There was a minor abrasion only without bleeding. What is the best management for this boy?

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Local wound cleaning only: Only individuals that fall under the category I need local wound cleaning.

questions.text: Which of the following bias can be eliminated by using incident cases rather than prevalent cases?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Neyman Bias:

Very ill and/or very healthy are excluded from the study thus true target population is not achieved.

Two scenarios:

  • Eliminating demised patients makes the disease look less severe.
  • Eliminating recovered patients makes the disease look more severe.

Seen with chronic diseases like Hypertension and TB.

Elimination of Bias: Using incident cases rather than prevalent cases

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Berksonian Bias: Select diﬀerent hospitals and patients having a variety of conditions.

Option C - Selection bias: Randomization is a critical technique used in clinical trials to reduce selection bias.

Option D - Recall bias: Recall Bias is Seen in case-control studies committed by a subject who under-reports

questions.text:
Consider the following:

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Teratoma:

Mature teratoma is a benign tumor.
