questions.text: A 15-year-old diagnosed with Burkitt’s Lymphoma undergoing chemotherapy came with nausea, vomiting, and altered mental status. His blood reports showed elevated Uric acid and decreased calcium levels. Which of these is the likely explanation for the patient's condition?

choices.text: Patient has developed Tumor Lysis syndrome

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Patient has developed Tumor Lysis syndrome:

  • Tumor lysis syndrome (TLS) is a potentially life-threatening medical emergency that can occur as a result of cancer treatment. It is often associated with Burkitt’s Lymphoma.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Patient is in Sepsis:

Difference in features:

Feature

Tumor Lysis Syndrome (TLS)

Sepsis

Etiology

Rapid destruction of cancer cells (post-treatment)

Systemic response to infection

Laboratory Findings
  • Hyperuricemia
  • Hyperkalemia
  • Hyperphosphatemia
  • Hypocalcemia
  • Leukocytosis or leukopenia
  • Elevated lactate
  • Coagulation abnormalities

Clinical Manifestations
  • Renal dysfunction - Cardiac arrhythmias - Neurological symptoms
  • Fever or hypothermia
  • Hypotension
  • Organ dysfunction
  • Altered mental status

Renal Dysfunction

Common, due to uric acid precipitation

Common, multifactorial including septic shock

Electrolyte Imbalances

Hyperuricemia, hyperkalemia, hyperphosphatemia, hypocalcemia

Electrolyte imbalances may occur

 

Option C - Patient has developed Vit-D deficiency:

 

Feature

Vitamin D Deficiency

Tumor Lysis Syndrome

Etiology

Inadequate sunlight exposure, dietary deficiency, malabsorption

Rapid destruction of cancer cells, often post-treatment

Pathophysiology

Impaired calcium absorption, bone health

Massive release of intracellular contents, leading to electrolyte imbalances and renal dysfunction

Clinical Manifestations

Musculoskeletal symptoms, fatigue, mood changes

Renal dysfunction, electrolyte imbalances, systemic symptoms

Laboratory Findings

Low serum 25-hydroxyvitamin D levels

Hyperuricemia, hyperkalemia, hyperphosphatemia, hypocalcemia

Treatment

Vitamin D supplementation

Hydration, allopurinol, electrolyte management, supportive care

 

Option D - Patient has Hypomagnesemia: Hypermagnesemia is seen in patients with tumor lysis syndrome where rapid amount of cellular destruction leads to efflux of multiple ion into the blood stream.

questions.text: A 23-year-old male was brought to the ER by his team after he passed out while playing cricket. One of his team members said that he was feeling light-headed and palpitations before passing out. His elder brother had died recently due to cardiac arrest at a very young age. An ECG was done as shown below. What is the most appropriate management strategy?

choices.text: Refer for immediate radiofrequency catheter ablation

questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Refer for immediate radiofrequency catheter ablation:

  • Wolff-Parkinson-White (WPW) syndrome is characterized by an accessory pathway that allows for abnormal conduction between the atria and ventricles, leading to a predisposition for supraventricular tachycardias, including atrioventricular reentrant tachycardia (AVRT). Radiofrequency catheter ablation is the treatment of choice for WPW syndrome, as it targets and eliminates the abnormal accessory pathway.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Administer intravenous adenosine:

  • Adenosine is not typically used in WPW
  • Adenosine is contraindicated in WPW syndrome. While adenosine is commonly used to terminate supraventricular tachycardias, it acts by blocking the atrioventricular (AV) node. In WPW syndrome, the accessory pathway bypasses the AV node, and administration of adenosine can actually increase conduction through the accessory pathway, potentially leading to life-threatening ventricular arrhythmias, including ventricular fibrillation.

Option B - Initiate antiarrhythmic therapy with flecainide:

  • IV flecainide is given for prevention as a long-term management

Option C - Perform electrical cardioversion:

  • Electrical cardioversion is generally not the first-line treatment for WPW syndrome. It can result in very rapid ventricular rates due to conduction through the accessory pathway and may lead to hemodynamic instability.

questions.text:
A 56-year-old male patient presents with chronic abdominal pain, multiple episodes of bloody diarrhea, and weight loss. Which of the following is the earliest feature seen on barium enema for this patient?

LAB parameters are as follows

pANCA +

Hb: 8.3

MCV:76 fl

RDW:14.5%
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Granular appearance:

In ulcerative colitis,

  • Barium enema: Earliest feature is Granular appearance due to pseudo polyps This granular appearance is a result of mucosal inflammation and ulceration in the colon.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Cobblestone appearance:

  • Cobblestone appearance is typically associated with Crohn's disease, not ulcerative colitis. In Crohn's disease, transmural inflammation can lead to a cobblestone-like appearance on imaging studies.

Option C - Pseudomembrane formation:

  • Pseudomembrane formation is more characteristic of pseudomembranous colitis, which is usually caused by Clostridium difficile infection. It is not a typical finding in ulcerative colitis.

Option D - Loss of haustration:

  • The earliest feature of barium enema is the Granular appearance due to pseudo polyps; loss of Haustrations leading to LEAD PIPE COLON appearance is seen later.

questions.text: A physician encounters a patient with symptoms indicative of meningococcal meningitis. The physician, at risk due to the mode of transmission through droplets, becomes infected. His mother and wife who is 4 months pregnant are taking care of him. Which of the following is the most appropriate prophylaxis for his mother?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Ciproﬂoxacin:

  • Neisseria meningitidis causes epidemics of meningitis in winter in an overcrowded population.
  • Family contact can be prevented by using Ciproﬂoxacin.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Ceftriaxone:

  • Health workers and pregnant women are given Ceftriaxone

Option C- - Rifampicin:

  • Rifampicin has 70% eﬃcacy and is not recommended for healthcare workers.
  • Family contact can be prevented by using Ciproﬂoxacin

Option D - Penicillin G:

  • Penicillin G is not mentioned as a preferred prophylactic agent for meningococcal meningitis, and it is not specifically recommended for family contacts in this scenario. Ciprofloxacin is a more appropriate choice for this purpose.

questions.text: 60-year-old patient presents to the hospital with resting tremor, bradykinesia, rigidity, and postural instability. The patient was unable to resist blinking when the doctor tapped repetitively on the area of skin between the eyebrows. Which of the following signs is depicted by the physician?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Myerson sign:

  • Myerson sign, also known as the "glabellar tap sign," is a neurological sign characterized by the inability to suppress the blink reflex when the forehead is tapped repeatedly. This is commonly seen in Parkinson's disease.
  • In the case described, the 60-year-old patient with resting tremor, bradykinesia, rigidity, and postural instability is exhibiting a positive Myerson sign, indicating dysfunction in the basal ganglia.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Babinski Sign: The Babinski sign is a neurological reflex that involves the dorsiflexion of the big toe and fanning of the other toes in response to the stimulation of the sole of the foot. This is not related to the described scenario and is associated with upper motor neuron lesions.

Option B - Chaddock Sign: The Chaddock sign is a variant of the Babinski sign where the response is elicited by stimulation along the lateral aspect of the foot. Like the Babinski sign, it is indicative of upper motor neuron dysfunction and is not relevant to the symptoms presented in the case.

Option C - Gordon Reflex: Gordon reflex, also called the paradoxical flexor reflex, is a clinical sign utilized to detect upper motor neuron lesions. Evaluation of this reflex is simple and rapid and does not require the use of any equipment. A positive Gordon reflex suggests an upper motor neuron lesion, denoted by an extensor plantar response that occurs when the calf is squeezed. A positive Gordon test can appear similar to a Babinski sign in an adult, and both procedures evaluate for upper motor neuron lesions.

questions.text:
Identify the correct statements.

1. MEN 2B is also known as Sipple syndrome

2. MEN 1 is also known as Werner syndrome

3. MEN 2B is characterized by the presence of Marfanoid Habitus.

4. MEN 4 is a/w CDKN1B
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - 2,3,4:

  1. MEN 2B is also known as Sipple syndrome: This statement is false. MEN 2B is not known as Sipple syndrome. Sipple syndrome is associated with multiple endocrine adenomatosis type 2A (MEN 2A).
  2. MEN 1 is also known as Wermer syndrome: This statement is TRUE. MEN 1 is associated with Wermer syndrome.
  3. Marfanoid Habitus is a feature of MEN 2B: This statement is true. Marfanoid habitus, which refers to the skeletal features similar to Marfan syndrome, is commonly seen in individuals with MEN 2B.
  4. MEN 4 is associated with CDKN1B: This statement is true. MEN 4 is a rare form of multiple endocrine neoplasia that is associated with mutations in the CDKN1B gene.

As, statements 2,3,4 are correct so Option D is the correct answer to the question.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - 1,3: As statement 1 is incorrect so option A is incorrect.

Option B - 1,2: As statement 1 is incorrect so option B is incorrect.

Option C - 1,2,3: As statement 1 is incorrect so option C is incorrect.

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman presents with complaints of pain, tenderness, and stiffness in her wrists and fingers after she wakes up in the morning. After further evaluation, the diagnosis of rheumatoid arthritis was made and treatment was started. Which of the following would be the correct statement regarding rheumatoid nodules if present in this patient?

choices.text: Tender, located on the extensor surface
Non-tender, located on the extensor surface
Non-tender, located on the flexor surface
Tender, located on the flexor surface

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Non-tender, located on the extensor surface:

  • Rheumatoid nodules are subcutaneous nodules that are a characteristic feature of rheumatoid arthritis. They are usually painless (non-tender) and are typically found over bony prominences, especially on the extensor surfaces of joints, such as the elbows. Rheumatoid nodules result from the accumulation of inflammatory cells and fibrous tissue and are a specific clinical manifestation of rheumatoid arthritis.

Incorrect options:

Option A - Tender, located on the extensor surface: It is incorrect because rheumatoid nodules are non-tender, not tender.

Option C - Non-tender, located on the flexor surface: It is incorrect because rheumatoid nodules are not typically found on the flexor surfaces.

Option D - Tender, located on the flexor surface: It is incorrect because rheumatoid nodules are non-tender, not tender.

questions.text: A 64-year-old patient was found unconscious and brought to the ER by his son. The patient was soon intubated and put on a mechanical ventilator as his GCS was <6. His blood reports show hypokalemia for which intravenous KCl was advised that requires a central line. On putting an internal jugular vein catheter, a patient has developed sudden onset severe respiratory distress. What would be the most probable reason?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Pneumothorax:

  • The sudden-onset severe respiratory distress following the placement of an internal jugular vein catheter is highly suggestive of pneumothorax, which is the presence of air in the pleural space surrounding the lungs. When air accumulates in the pleural space, it can cause the lung to collapse partially or completely, leading to respiratory distress, chest pain, and other symptoms.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Air embolism: Air embolism is not likely to be the reason for respiratory distress in this patient.

Option C - ARDS - Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome: It is incorrect because although ARDS can cause respiratory distress, it is not specifically associated with the placement of an internal jugular vein catheter.

Option D - Infective endarteritis: It is incorrect because infective endarteritis is an infection of the inner lining of arteries and is not related to the placement of an internal jugular vein catheter.

questions.text:
A 44-year-old male with a history of peptic ulcer disease, diabetes mellitus and HTN presents to the emergency with a complaint of nausea, abdominal pain, and lethargy.

PH=7.2, PO2=56mm Hg, PCO2 = 40 mmHg,spo2: 98% on Room Air.

HCO3 =15 meq (22-26 meq), urine ketones: ++, and RBS = 366 mg/dl

Which of the following types of insulin should be used in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Regular insulin:

  • In the given clinical scenario, the patient presents with symptoms suggestive of diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA), which is characterized by high blood glucose levels, metabolic acidosis, and ketosis. DKA is considered a medical emergency and requires prompt treatment with insulin.
  • Regular insulin, also known as short-acting insulin, is the most appropriate choice for managing DKA.

Incorrect options:

Option B - Rapid-acting insulin: Rapid-acting insulin is commonly used to manage postprandial glucose spikes in individuals with diabetes. However, in the context of DKA, regular insulin is preferred due to its longer duration of action.

Option C - Long-acting insulin: Long-acting insulin provides a steady release of insulin over an extended period (approximately 24 hours). It is used for basal insulin coverage and does not have a rapid onset or peak effect, making it less suitable for managing acute hyperglycemia and acidosis in DKA.

Option D - Pre-mixed insulin: Pre-mixed insulin is less suitable for the management of DKA

questions.text: A 66 year old male patient presents with palpitations and excessive sweating. He also experiences difficulty in breathing when lying down . Framingham Criteria is being used for further diagnosis of this patient. Which of the following will not be included in the minor criteria?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Bilateral Crepts:

  • Bilateral crepts are included in the major criteria not minor criteria

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Tachycardia: Tachycardia is included in the minor criteria for the diagnosis of CHF according to the Framingham Criteria.

Option B - Pitting Pedal Edema: Pitting Pedal Edema is included in the minor criteria for the diagnosis of CHF according to the Framingham Criteria.

Option C - Pleural Effusion: Pleural Effusion is included in the minor criteria for the diagnosis of CHF according to the Framingham Criteria.

questions.text: A 16 year old male presents with complaints of headache of sudden onset and also change in his urine color as given in the image below. He was taking antibiotics for a sore throat 2 weeks ago. Which of the following will be seen in light microscopy of kidney biopsy for this patient?

choices.text: Sub epithelial cell deposits as humps

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Hyper cellular glomerulus:

  • The patient is likely experiencing Poststreptococcal Glomerulonephritis (PSGN), which is supported by the history of sore throat two weeks ago and the current presentation with headache and cola-colored urine.
  • In PSGN, light microscopy typically reveals a hypercellular glomerulus, indicating an increased number of cells within the glomeruli.
  • Polymorphonuclear (PMN) infiltration is a characteristic feature seen in the glomeruli during PSGN.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - C3 deposits:

  • This is associated with immune complex-mediated glomerulonephritis, but PSGN is primarily a result of antigen-antibody complexes involving streptococcal products.
  • The correct characteristic for PSGN is PMN infiltration rather than specific immunoglobulin or complement deposits.

Option C - Subepithelial cell deposits as humps:

  • This is more characteristic of membranous glomerulonephritis or type I membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis, not PSGN.
  • In PSGN, the deposits are typically subendothelial rather than subepithelial.

Option D - Podocyte effacement:

  • Podocyte effacement is a feature seen in nephrotic syndrome, where there is damage to the podocytes in the renal glomeruli. PSGN typically does not present with podocyte effacement.

questions.text:
An intern gets pricked while doing cannulation of a patient in the emergency room. Viral markers were done for the patient which is as follows

HIV -

Anti HCV +

HBs Ag+

IgM anti HBc +

Which of the following is most appropriate regarding the status of this patient?

choices.text: Acute hep C + acute hep B
Acute hep C + highly infectious hep B
Chronic hep C + hep B gap period
Chronic hep C + hep B vaccinated

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Acute hep C + acute hep B:

The most appropriate diagnosis based on the above given serology is that the patient is suffering from acute hep C and acute hep B

  • Anti-HCV + (Positive): Indicates the presence of antibodies against Hepatitis C virus, suggesting a current or past infection.
  • HBsAg + (Positive): Indicates the presence of Hepatitis B surface antigen, suggesting an acute or chronic Hepatitis B infection.
  • IgM anti-HBc + (Positive): Indicates the presence of IgM antibodies against Hepatitis B core antigen, suggesting an acute Hepatitis B infection.
