Incorrect Options:

Option B - Acute hep C + highly infectious hep B:

  • It would have been the answer if HBe Ağ was also positive.

Option C - Chronic hep C + hep B gap period:

  • Only IgM anti HBcAg present in Gap period
  • Also anti HCV is positive making it as acute hep C

Option D - Chronic hep C + hep B vaccinated:

  • This is incorrect as the patient has acute infections of both Hepatitis C and Hepatitis B. The presence of IgM anti-HBc suggests an ongoing acute Hepatitis B infection, not a vaccination response.
  • AntiHbsAg>10 IU/ml:Vaccinated

questions.text: A 6-year-old child presents to the ER with recurrent episodes of vomiting, lethargy, and seizures. He underwent chemotherapy yesterday for ALL. Which of the following electrolyte abnormalities will not be present in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D – Hypernatremia:

  • Hypernatremia is not typically associated with tumor lysis syndrome (TLS). TLS is characterized by the rapid release of intracellular contents into the bloodstream, often occurring after chemotherapy, and commonly presents with hyperkalemia, hyperuricemia, hypocalcemia, and hypophosphatemia. However, an increase in serum sodium levels (hypernatremia) is not a direct consequence of tumor lysis.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Hyperuricemia: Hyperuricemia is a common finding in tumor lysis syndrome. It results from the breakdown of nucleic acids released during the lysis of cancer cells. Increased uric acid levels can lead to complications such as renal impairment and gout.

Option B - Hyperkalemia: Hyperkalemia is a characteristic electrolyte abnormality in tumor lysis syndrome. The release of intracellular potassium from lysed cells can lead to elevated serum potassium levels, posing a risk for cardiac arrhythmias.

Option C - Hypocalcemia: Hypocalcemia is commonly seen in tumor lysis syndrome. The released phosphate can form calcium phosphate precipitates in the renal tubules, leading to decreased serum calcium levels. Hypocalcemia can manifest with symptoms such as tetany, seizures, and cardiac arrhythmias.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male patient presents with odynophagia. He is a truck driver and is AIDS-positive with a history of chronic alcoholism for more than 20 years. His oral examination is given below. Which of the following should be given to this patient as management?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - IV fluconazole:

  • Given the patient's history of odynophagia and being AIDS-positive, there is a high suspicion of an opportunistic fungal infection, particularly esophageal candidiasis. Fluconazole is an antifungal medication effective against Candida species and is often the preferred choice for systemic infections. Intravenous administration is suitable for cases with severe oropharyngeal candidiasis, making IV fluconazole an appropriate choice for this patient.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Oral fluconazole: Oral fluconazole is also effective against Candida infections. However, the choice between oral and intravenous administration depends on the severity of the infection and the patient's overall condition. In less severe cases, oral fluconazole may be considered, but in cases with more significant systemic involvement, as suggested by odynophagia in an AIDS-positive patient, intravenous administration might be preferred for better bioavailability.

Option C - IV clotrimazole: Clotrimazole is an antifungal medication, but it is typically used topically. Intravenous clotrimazole is not a standard or recommended form of administration. The intravenous route is not practical for clotrimazole, and its systemic use is limited.

Option D - Oral clotrimazole: Similar to the intravenous form, oral clotrimazole is generally used for local fungal infections, such as oral thrush. It is not the first-line choice for systemic fungal infections, especially in an immunocompromised patient like the one described. Therefore, oral clotrimazole is not the preferred management for this patient.

questions.text: A 64 year old male patient with a previous history of stroke now is brought by his relatives as he is now unable to talk, eat or drink. He is able to move his eyes in a vertical direction only. He is not able to move his limbs.Which of the following part of the brain is affected in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Pons, midbrain and medulla:

  • This patient is presenting with symptoms consistent with locked-in syndrome. Locked-in syndrome is a condition characterized by paralysis of all voluntary muscles in the body except for the vertical movement of the eyes. It typically results from damage to the lower brainstem, involving the pons, medulla, and sometimes the midbrain. In this case, the patient's inability to move his limbs, speak, or eat/drink is indicative of widespread brainstem involvement.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Pons only: This option is incorrect because the patient's symptoms involve more than just the pons. The inability to move limbs and loss of speech and swallowing function suggest involvement of other brainstem regions.

Option B - Pons and medulla: This option is also incorrect. While the pons and medulla are both part of the brainstem and contribute to the presentation of locked-in syndrome, the midbrain is also involved in this case.

Option C - Pons and midbrain: This option is incorrect. Although both the pons and midbrain are affected in locked-in syndrome, the medulla is also involved, as indicated by the patient's clinical presentation.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female patient presents to you complaining of dryness in the mouth and eyes. Serum testing reveals positive anti-Ro and anti-La antibodies.The test in the image below was positive, with a score of <5 mm in 5 minutes without anesthesia. What is the likely diagnosis
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Primary Sjogren's syndrome:

  • The patient's symptoms of dryness in the mouth and eyes, positive anti-Ro and anti-La antibodies, and the positive Schirmer's test (wet length of less than 5 mm) without anesthesia are consistent with the diagnosis of Primary Sjogren's Syndrome.
  • This autoimmune condition primarily affects the exocrine glands, leading to dryness in the eyes and mouth. The positive anti-Ro and anti-La antibodies further support the diagnosis.
  • Keratoconjunctivitis sicca is the deﬁciency of the aqueous layer.
  • KCS + Xerostomia primary: Primary Sjogren syndrome.
  • Schirmer's test 1 in the image involves placing Whatman paper No. 41 under the lower lid for 5 minutes: A wet length of less than 5 mm indicates dry eye. It measures both basal and reﬂex secretion.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Scleroderma:

  • Scleroderma antibodies are anti-Scl-70 and anti-centromere.
  • Scleroderma is another autoimmune connective tissue disorder, but it is not typically associated with dryness in the eyes and mouth. Instead, it is characterized by skin thickening, vascular abnormalities, and internal organ involvement.

Option C - Secondary Sjogren's Syndrome:

  • Secondary Sjogren's Syndrome can occur in conjunction with other autoimmune diseases, such as rheumatoid arthritis or systemic lupus erythematosus. However, in this case, the patient's presentation and positive anti-Ro and anti-La antibodies suggest primary Sjogren's syndrome rather than secondary.
  • Primary Sjogren syndrome + connective tissue disorder: secondary Sjogren syndrome

Option D - Lacrimal Duct Stones:

  • Lacrimal duct stones are a mechanical obstruction in the tear drainage system and can cause tearing rather than dryness. The positive Schirmer's test and the presence of anti-Ro and anti-La antibodies are not consistent with lacrimal duct stones.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male with a known history of ischemic heart disease and a previous myocardial infarction presents to the emergency department with complaints of chest pain, shortness of breath, and palpitations. On examination, he appears diaphoretic, and his blood pressure is 100/70 mmHg with a heart rate of 180 beats per minute. An electrocardiogram (ECG) reveals was done as given below. What is the most appropriate management for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Options D - IV Amiodarone:

  • In the given clinical scenario, the patient is presenting with chest pain, shortness of breath, and palpitations along with a rapid heart rate (ventricular tachycardia) on ECG. The patient is hemodynamically stable with a blood pressure of 100/70 mmHg. IV Amiodarone is an appropriate choice for the management of stable ventricular tachycardia. Amiodarone is a class III antiarrhythmic medication that can help in stabilizing the cardiac rhythm and preventing further episodes of ventricular tachycardia.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - IV Adenosine:

  • Adenosine is commonly used for the termination of supraventricular tachycardias (SVTs) like atrioventricular nodal reentrant tachycardia (AVNRT) or atrial fibrillation/flutter. However, it is not effective in terminating ventricular tachycardia and may even worsen the condition.

Option B - Synchronized DC Shock:

  • Synchronized DC shock is generally reserved for hemodynamically unstable ventricular tachycardia or ventricular fibrillation. In this scenario, the patient is described as hemodynamically stable, and synchronized shocks are not the first-line intervention in such cases.

Option C - Asynchronized DC Shock:

  • Asynchronized DC shock is typically reserved for life-threatening ventricular arrhythmias, especially in the setting of cardiac arrest. In this scenario, the patient is hemodynamically stable, and asynchronized shocks are not the initial choice for a stable ventricular tachycardia.

questions.text: A 19-year-old male presents with a persistent tremor in his hands, difficulty with coordination, and slurred speech. His family notes a significant change in his personality, with irritability and uncharacteristic aggression. Additionally, he has developed a noticeable yellowing of the eyes and skin. The patient denies any significant alcohol consumption. Laboratory investigations reveal elevated liver enzymes and decreased ceruloplasmin levels. Which of the following will be seen on MRI of this patient?

choices.text: Face of the giant panda sign

questions.solution:
Correct Option A- Face of the giant panda: "Face of the giant panda" sign in the midbrain, with hyperintensity in the tegmentum and hypointensity in the red nucleus and substantia nigra. Seen in MRI of Wilson disease

Incorrect Options:

Option B- Hot cross bun sign: The "Hot cross bun" sign in the pons is associated with multiple system atrophy, not Wilson's disease.

Option C- Dawson's fingers sign: "Dawson's fingers" is a characteristic finding in multiple sclerosis, not Wilson's disease.

Option D- Mickey Mouse sign: The "Cobra head" or "Mickey Mouse" sign in the basal ganglia is not specific to Wilson's disease.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient reports a gradual onset of symptoms over the past 24 hours. On examination, the patient is visibly distressed, with the use of accessory respiratory muscles. Blood pressure measurements reveal a significant drop during inspiration, with a difference of 15 mmHg between the systolic blood pressure during expiration and inspiration. The patient's neck veins appear distended, and lung auscultation reveals diminished breath sounds bilaterally. The condition that the patient has presented is seen in which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B- Severe asthma:

  • Severe Asthma or Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD): During severe asthma attacks or exacerbations of COPD, airway resistance increases significantly during inspiration. This leads to increased negative intrathoracic pressure, affecting venous return to the heart and causing a drop in systolic blood pressure during inspiration.

Incorrect Options:

Option A- Coronary artery disease: Coronary artery disease refers to the narrowing or blockage of the coronary arteries supplying blood to the heart muscle. While it can cause symptoms such as angina (chest pain) or myocardial infarction (heart attack), it is not directly associated with pulsus paradoxus.

Option C- Atrial Fibrillation: Atrial Fibrillation don not have pulsus paradoxus

Option D- Right ventricular myocardial infarction: Right ventricular myocardial infarction refers to a heart attack affecting the right ventricle of the heart. While myocardial infarction can cause various cardiovascular symptoms, pulsus paradoxus is not a characteristic feature of right ventricular myocardial infarction specifically

questions.text: A 62-year-old male with a history of rheumatic heart disease and a prosthetic mitral valve done 3 months ago presents to the clinic with a history of fatigue, unintentional weight loss, and a low-grade fever. The patient reports a new-onset murmur on auscultation and occasional night sweats. Laboratory investigations reveal elevated inflammatory markers, and blood cultures are also sent. An echocardiogram demonstrates vegetation on the prosthetic valve. Which of the following organisms will be seen in blood culture for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B- Coagulase-negative staphylococcus (CONS):

Explanation:

  • Prosthetic valve endocarditis (PVE) is an infection involving a prosthetic heart valve. The risk of PVE is highest in the first year after valve implantation. In this case, the patient has a prosthetic mitral valve placed 3 months ago and presents with symptoms suggestive of endocarditis, such as fatigue, unintentional weight loss, low-grade fever, new-onset murmur, and occasional night sweats. The echocardiogram reveals vegetation on the prosthetic valve.
  • The most common organism causing PVE between 2 and 12 months after valve implantation is Coagulase-negative staphylococcus (CONS). This is often attributed to factors like intraoperative contamination of the operating field or postoperative introduction of the organism. Therefore, CONS is a likely pathogen to be found in blood culture in this scenario.

Incorrect Options:

Option A- Staphylococcus aureus:

  • Staphylococcus aureus is a common cause of acute infective endocarditis, but it is less common in prosthetic valve endocarditis occurring 2-12 months after valve implantation. Coagulase-negative staphylococci are more frequently associated with late PVE.

Option C- Streptococcus viridans:

  • While Streptococcus viridans is a common cause of native valve endocarditis, it is not the most typical organism seen in prosthetic valve endocarditis, especially within the first year post-implantation.

Option D- Mycobacterium chimaera:

  • Mycobacterium chimaera is an atypical and rare cause of prosthetic valve endocarditis. It is not a common pathogen in routine cases and is usually associated with specific circumstances, such as exposure to contaminated heater-cooler units during cardiac surgery. It is not a typical organism to be expected in this patient's scenario.
  • Mycobacterium chimera has been responsible for the outbreak of prosthetic valve endocarditis in certain hospitals. Attributed to patients who are exposed to cardiopulmonary bypass machines with imperfect sterilization techniques followed in hospitals.

questions.text: A 40-year-old female presents with involuntary, rapid, jerky movements of her limbs and face. Her family reports behavioral changes over the past year, including irritability and social withdrawal. On examination, the patient exhibits choreiform movements, hyperreflexia, and cognitive impairment. Her father also had a similar condition. The gene involved is present in which of the following chromosomes?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D- 4:

  • The patient's symptoms such as choreiform movements, hyperreflexia, and cognitive impairment are diagnostic of Huntington Chorea
  • The Gene involved - the Huntington gene present on chromosome number 4.

Incorrect Options:

Option A-1: The gene involved in Huntington Chorea is present on chromosome number 4. Therefore this option is incorrect

Option B-2:  The gene involved in Huntington Chorea is present on chromosome number 4. Therefore this option is incorrect

Option C-3: The gene involved in Huntington Chorea is present on chromosome number 4. Therefore this option is incorrect

questions.text: A 33-year-old female presented to the emergency department following an accidental burns injury. It was identified as a superficial second-degree burn. Which of the following is seen in this category of burn?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Blanch to touch:

  • Second-degree burns are also known as Partial thickness burn
  • Blanch to touch is a feature seen in a superficial second-degree burn

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Involvement of epidermis + Reticular dermis:

  • Involvement of epidermis + Reticular dermis is consistent with deep second-degree burn
  • Involvement of epidermis + Papillary dermis is seen in superficial second-degree burn

Option B - Pinprick sensation is preserved:

  • Pinprick sensation is preserved in a deep second-degree burn

Option D - Healing occurs with scarring:

  • Healing occurs with scarring in a deep second-degree burn

questions.text:
A 34-year-old male patient presents with complaints of abdominal pain and diarrhea along with a history of recurrent ulcers and dyspepsia. He is a known case of MEN1

Which of the following is the best provocative test for this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Secretin Stimulation Test:

  • According to the symptoms of the patient and history of MEN1 syndrome, the patient is likely suffering from Zollinger-Ellison syndrome.
  • The most common site is Duodenum > Pancreas
  • The best Provocative Test is the Secretin Stimulation Test
  • 75% sporadic and 25% associated with MEN 1

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Gastrin >1000 Pg/ml: Gastrin >1000 Pg/ml is diagnostic.

Option B - Basal Acid Output (BAO)>15 mEq/hour: Basal Acid Output (BAO) of more than 15 mEq/hour is also diagnostic.

Option D - Somatostatin receptor scintigraphy (SRS): Investigation of choice for localization is Somatostatin receptor scintigraphy (SRS).

questions.text: A 33-year-old man presents to the ER with an upper GI bleed, vomiting, and dizziness. He is a chronic alcoholic and a smoker for more than 12 years. Upper GI endoscopy shows a partial tear in the esophagus. Which of the following is the most common site for this?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A – Cardia:

  • The above clinical scenario suggests the diagnosis of Mallory-Weiss syndrome
  • Cardia is the most common site of Mallory-Weiss syndrome.

Incorrect Options:

Option B – Antrum: The most Common Site Of Carcinoma Stomach(overall) is Antrum.

Option C - Incisura angularis: Incisura angularis (notch near longer curvature) is the Most Common Site of gastric ulcer.

Option D – Fundus: The fundus is the most common site of carcinoma stomach in pernicious Anemia.

questions.text: A 70-year-old man has unexplained weight loss and frequent urination. On further evaluation, PSA is > 20 ng/dl. There is no history of DM /HTN. He is a painter by profession. All of the following are protective factors for the condition that this old man is suffering from except??
questions.solution:
Correct Option B – Copper:

  • Unexplained weight loss and frequent urination along with PSA is > 20ng/dl is diagnostic of prostate cancer.
  • Copper is not known to be a protective factor for prostate cancer

Incorrect Options:

Option A – Lycopene: Lycopene is one of the protective factors for prostate cancer.

Option C – Selenium: Selenium is one of the protective factors for prostate cancer.

Option D - Vitamin A: Vitamin A is one of the protective factors for prostate cance.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female presents to the clinic with concerns regarding a lump in her neck. On examination, the lump is on the anterior part of the neck towards the midline. A histopathology image has been shown below. Which of the following is true regarding this disease?

choices.text: Most common route of spread: Hematogenous.
Commonly found during the 5 to 6 decades.
Most common site of metastasis: Lungs

questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Most common site of metastasis: Lungs:

  • The above histopathological image shows Optically clear nuclei (Also known as Orphan Annie eye nuclei), Pseudo-inclusion bodies, dystrophic calciﬁcation (Also known as Psammoma Bodies) which are seen in papillary thyroid carcinoma.
  • The most common site of metastasis in papillary thyroid carcinoma is the lungs.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Most common route of spread: Hematogenous: Most common route of spread: Lymphatic (Because level 6 lymph nodes are involved) not hematogenous.

Option B - Commonly found during the 5 to 6 decades: It is not commonly found during the 5 to 6 decades

Option C - 2nd most common thyroid malignancy: It is the Most common thyroid malignancy, not 2nd most common.

questions.text: A 67-year-old man has a painless swelling that's growing slowly in size over the past few years.
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Superﬁcial Parotidectomy:

  • Warthin's Tumor AKA Papillary cystadenoma lymphomatosum – because of Papillary cystic pattern with marked lymphoid component
  • Treatment of choice: Superﬁcial parotidectomy

Incorrect Options:

Options B - Newman & Seabrock's Operation: Newman & Seabrock's Operation is done for parotid fistula.

Option C - Total conservative parotidectomy: Total conservative parotidectomy is not the treatment of choice for Warthin's Tumor.

Option D - Radical excision: Radical excision is done for Acinic Cell Carcinoma.

questions.text: A 20-year-old male presents with swelling as shown in the image. The swelling is soft, ﬂuctuant, and shows transillumination positive. Which of the following is the commonest site for this?

choices.text: Junction of anterior middle and lower 1/3rd of Sternocleidomastoid
Junction of posterior middle and lower 1/3rd of Sternocleidomastoid
Junction of anterior upper and lower 1/3rd of Sternocleidomastoid.
Junction of anterior upper and middle 1/3rd of Sternocleidomastoid.

questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Junction of anterior upper and middle 1/3rd of Sternocleidomastoid:

  • Junction of anterior upper and middle 1/3rd of Sternocleidomastoid.
  • The commonest site of branchial cysts is indeed in this location. Branchial cysts are often found in the Junction of the upper and middle 1/3rd of the sternocleidomastoid muscle, near its attachment to the mastoid process.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Junction of the anterior middle and lower 1/3rd of Sternocleidomastoid: Branchial cysts do not commonly occur in this location.

Option B - Junction of posterior middle and lower 1/3rd of Sternocleidomastoid: Branchial cysts do not commonly occur in this location either.

Option C - Junction of anterior upper and lower 1/3rd of Sternocleidomastoid: Branchial cysts are not typically found in this specific location.

questions.text: A 55-year-old female presents with complaints of non-healing wound on the lateral side of the thigh. She also has a history of accidental splatter of boiling water 9 months ago in the same area. Which of the following is not a characteristic feature of this scar?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D – Painful:

  • A non-healing scar in the previously burned injury area points towards the diagnosis of Marjolin's ulcer.
  • It is a painless scar not painful as there are no nerves in the scar tissues.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - No regional LN metastasis: There is no regional LN metastasis and there would be no lymphatics in scar tissue.

Option B - Slow Growing: Marjolin's ulcer is a slow-growing scar as it is avascular.

Option C - Radio resistant: Marjolin's ulcer is Radio resistant (avascular scar).

questions.text:
Match the following


	
		
			
			A
			
			
			Full thickness skin graft
			
			
			1
			
			
			Involves free absorption of nutrients into graft

			 
			
		
		
			
			B
			
			
			Inosculation
			
			
			2
			
			
			Signiﬁcant graft contractions

			 
			
		
		
			
			C
			
			
			Split thickness skin graft
			
			
			3
			
			
			Better cosmetic appearance
			
		
		
			
			D
			
			
			Plasma imbibition
			
			
			4
			
			
			Completed by 4-5 days
			
		
		
			
			 
			
			
			 
			
			
			5
			
			
			Graft demonstrates both arterial and venous outﬂow.
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - A-3, B-4, C-2, D-1:

  • A-3:Full thickness skin graft results in Better cosmetic appearance due to less graft contractures
  • B-4:Inosculation is one of the phases of graft take. In this Donor and recipient capillaries are aligned together. Inosculation is complete by 4- 5 days.
  • C-2:Split thickness skin graft results in poor cosmetic appearance due to significant graft contractures
  • D-1:Plasma imbibition is also one of the phases of graft take. In this the graft survives up to ﬁrst 48 hours and free absorption of nutrients into the graft takes place by diﬀusion
  • 5: Graft demonstrating both arterial and venous outﬂow is a feature of revascularization which is also one of the phases of graft take.

questions.text: A 24-year-old male presents to the ER with complaints of lower abdomen pain radiating to the scrotum and perineal region. The pain is colicky in nature. Further evaluation reveals the presence of a 3 cm renal stone. An image of the stone is given below. What would be the most appropriate treatment for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B – PCNL:

  • If stone in the Lower 1/3rd of the ureter, pain radiates to (Via ilioinguinal nerve)
    • Scrotum
    • Perineum.
    • Inner aspect of thigh
  • The image is of a brushite stone which is a hard stone
  • The most appropriate treatment would be PCNL(Percutaneous nephrolithotomy) as the stone size is >2cm 

Incorrect options:

Option A – ESWL:

  • For stones of size up to 2 cm - ESWL is used
  • Hard stones like brushite cannot be broken down by ESWL

Option C – LSS:

  • LSS (Laparoscopic stone surgery): Not commonly preferred

Option D - Conservative management:

  • Conservative management is done for Stone size up to 5mm.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman has been experiencing itching and dryness around the skin of her nipple associated with a darkish color change for the past few months. Which of the following can be associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Invasive ductal cancer:

  • Paget's disease is associated with underlying malignancy:
    • Sometimes it is associated with ductal carcinoma in-situ.
    • It is at times also associated with invasive ductal cancer.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Malignant melanoma: Superﬁcial spreading malignant melanoma is similar in appearance; except the color is diﬀerent but it has no association with Paget's disease

Option B - Cystosarcoma phyllodes: Paget's disease is not associated with Cystosarcoma phyllode's.

Option D - Sero-cystic disease of Brodie: Paget's disease is not associated with Sero-cystic disease of Brodie.

questions.text:
A 37-year-old female presents to the clinic for a routine checkup as she underwent cholecystectomy 14 months ago. Blood examination was done which showed deranged LFT parameters:

ALP: 236 IU/L

GGT:98 U/L

5' nucleotidase:27 µ/l

She is otherwise well. Which of the following is the investigation of choice for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B – MRCP:

  • The history of cholecystectomy with asymptomatic elevation of ALP (alkaline phosphatase), GGT (gamma-glutamyl transferase) , 5' nucleotidase leads to the diagnosis of CBD stone.
  • Investigation of choice – MRCP (Magnetic Resonance Cholangiopancreatography)

Incorrect Options:

Option A – ERCP:

  • Gold standard investigation – ERCP (Endoscopic Retrograde Cholangiopancreatography)
  • ERCP (Endoscopic Retrograde Cholangiopancreatography) is also the treatment for stones up to 1.5cm.

Option C – PTC:

  • PTC (Percutaneous Transhepatic Cholangiography) is both diagnostic and therapeutic. It is used to:
    • Remove the stone from the proximal part of the bile duct, the intrahepatic bile duct.
    • Locate stent for proximal biliary strictures

Option D – USG:

  • USG can be done but it is not an investigation of choice for Choledocholithiasis

questions.text: A 43 year old male who was previously treated for traumatic injury now presented with severe wound pain. After further examination, Thin, brown, sweet smelling exudate from wound with crepitus were observed.He is a diabetic patient for past 15 years. Which of the following would have most commonly caused this?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Clostridium perfringens:

  • The image and the clinical features are suggestive of gas gangrene.
  • The most common organism responsible – is Clostridium perfringens (anaerobe).

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Clostridium sordellii: Clostridium sordellii can also cause gas gangrene but is not the most common cause.

Option C - Clostridium difficile: Clostridium difficile causes antibiotic-associated diarrhea.

Option D - Staphylococcus aureus: Staphylococcus aureus does not cause gas gangrene.

questions.text: A 56-year-old male has been unable to pass flatus and stool for the past 3 days. He is on antihypertensive since 12 years. On auscultation, hyperactive bowel sounds can be heard. The physician suspects this is SAIO and asks the intern to put a NG tube. In which position the patient should be kept for the insertion of a Nasogastric tube?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Sitting with the neck flexed:

  • The correct procedure for inserting a Nasogastric (NG) tube is to have the patient sitting with the neck flexed.
  • This position helps straighten the nasal passage and facilitate the passage of the NG tube into the stomach.

Incorrect Options:

Options A - Supine with neck flexed: It is done in comatose patients.

Options B - Supine with neck extended: The supine position with neck extended may also cause difficulty in the passage of the NG tube and increase the risk of complications.

Option D - Sitting with neck extended: The sitting position with neck extended may make the insertion of the NG tube more challenging and increase the risk of complications.

questions.text: A 23-day-old neonate presents with bilious vomiting and failure to thrive. The abdomen appears distended with absent bowel sounds. Which of the following is the most common type of malrotation.?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Incomplete rotation:

  • The clinical presentation of bilious vomiting, gross abdominal distention, and absent bowel sounds suggests malrotation of the gut.
  • Incomplete rotation - MC type of malrotation.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Non-rotation: Non-rotation is the most common rotational abnormality.

Option C - Reverse Rotation: Reverse Rotation is not the most common malrotation.

Option D - Mixed rotation: Mixed rotation is not the most common malrotation.

questions.text:
A newborn fails to pass meconium in the first 24 hours of life associated with generalized abdominal distention and bilious vomiting. An x-ray was done and the following is seen:



Which of the following will be the initial management for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Contrast enema:

  • The initial treatment for a newborn infant presenting with abdominal distension, bilious vomiting, failure to pass meconium, and an X-ray showing dilated small bowel loops with a soap bubble appearance in the right lower quadrant is a contrast enema is suggestive of meconium ileus
  • IOC (Dx + Tx) - Water soluble contrast enema.
  • Water soluble contrast enema - Relieves obstruction in >75% of patients.
  • Precaution -Hydration of the child

Incorrect Options:

Options A - Paul mikulicz ileostomy: Paul mikulicz ileostomy involves creating a surgical opening (stoma) in the ileum to divert the fecal stream. It is not the initial treatment for meconium ileus.

Option B – USG: USG is not the initial management for meconium ileus.

Options D - CECT Abdomen: CECT Abdomen is not the initial management for meconium ileus.

questions.text: A neonate presented with drooling of saliva from mouth within a few hours of birth with a maternal history of Polyhydramnios. At the presentation, the baby had mild respiratory distress. Further evaluation shows Tracheoesophageal fistula (TEF) without Esophageal atresia. The presentation comes under which category of TEF?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Type E:

  • Type E ﬁstula TEF without EA which is also known as H-shaped ﬁstula

Incorrect Options:

Options A - Type A: Type A -Isolated esophageal atresia without Tracheoesophageal fistula.

Options B - Type B: Type B -Esophageal atresia with proximal Tracheoesophageal fistula.

Options C - Type D: Type D: proximal and distal TEF

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of Bisgaard's Regimen?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Intermittent pneumatic compression:

  • Bisgaard's Regimen is done to manage venous ulcers in varicose vein
  • Intermittent pneumatic compression is not a component of Bisgaard's Regimen.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Limb elevation: Limb elevation is a component of Bisgaard's Regime

Option B – Massage: Massage is a component of Bisgaard's Regime

Option C - Compression stockings: Compression stockings are a component of Bisgaard's Regime

questions.text: A 24-year-old male presents with discomfort and swelling in the scrotal region becomes more prominent in a standing position. On palpation, a bag of worms sensation is felt. Which of the following is a predisposing factor?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Nutcracker's phenomenon:

  • The left renal vein compressed between the aorta and superior mesenteric artery is a predisposing factor for varicocele

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Pagetoid phenomenon: Pagetoid phenomenon is not a predisposing factor for varicocele

Option B - Bell clapper phenomenon: Bell clapper phenomenon is not a predisposing factor for varicocele

Option D - Raynaud's phenomenon: Raynaud's phenomenon is not a predisposing factor for varicocele

questions.text: Identify the following instrument
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Lanes Forceps:

  • The image is of Lanes tissue forceps. It is used to hold bulky and slippery tissue

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Babcock's forceps:

Option C - Allis forceps:

Option D - Lahey's forceps:

questions.text:
A 32-year-old woman presents with complaints of a malodorous vaginal discharge and mild irritation. On examination, the following picture is observed.



Microscopic examination of a wet mount reveals the presence of clue cells. What is the most likely cause of the patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Bacterial vaginosis:

  • The clinical presentation of a thin, grayish-white, and adherent vaginal discharge, along with the absence of significant inflammation or erythema, is characteristic of bacterial vaginosis (BV). BV is a common vaginal infection caused by an imbalance in the normal vaginal flora, with an overgrowth of anaerobic bacteria and a decrease in lactobacilli.

  • The presence of clue cells on microscopic examination is a key diagnostic feature of bacterial vaginosis. Clue cells are vaginal epithelial cells coated with bacteria, making them appear stippled or "clue-like" when observed under the microscope.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Candidiasis:

  • It is associated with a thick, cottage cheese-like discharge and is caused by an overgrowth of Candida species. This presentation is not consistent with the clinical findings in this patient

Option B - Trichomoniasis:

  • It is characterized by a frothy, greenish-yellow discharge and is caused by the protozoan parasite Trichomonas vaginalis. The clinical presentation described does not match the typical features of trichomoniasis.

Option D - Gonorrhea:

  • This typically presents with purulent discharge and is not the most likely cause of the symptoms described in this case

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents with oligomenorrhea and hirsutism. On hormonal evaluation, the patient is found to have an increased luteinizing hormone (LH): follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) ratio. Which of the following conditions is most likely responsible for this hormonal profile?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS):

  • Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS) is a common endocrine disorder in women of reproductive age and is a leading cause of oligomenorrhea and hirsutism. One of the characteristic hormonal features of PCOS is an increased luteinizing hormone (LH): follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) ratio. In PCOS, there is an overproduction of luteinizing hormone (LH) relative to follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH), leading to disrupted ovarian function.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Primary Ovarian Failure:

  • It is characterized by a decreased ovarian function, leading to elevated levels of both LH and FSH. PCOS, on the other hand, is associated with elevated LH levels.

Option C - Hypothalamic Amenorrhea:

  • It typically presents with low levels of both LH and FSH due to a disruption in the hypothalamic-pituitary-ovarian axis. The LH:FSH ratio is not typically increased in hypothalamic amenorrhea

Option D - Hyperprolactinemia:

  • It can result in menstrual irregularities, but it is not associated with an increased LH:FSH ratio. Elevated prolactin levels suppress both LH and FSH.

questions.text:
A 25-year-old sexually active female presents with complaints of vulvar itching. On examination, the following appearance is noted:



Microscopic examination of a wet mount confirms the presence of motile organisms. What is the preferred treatment for the most likely causative agent in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Metronidazole:

  • The patient's presentation of frothy, greenish-yellow vaginal discharge, vulvar itching, and the presence of motile organisms on wet mount is indicative of trichomoniasis, which is caused by the protozoan parasite Trichomonas vaginalis.

  • Metronidazole is the preferred treatment for trichomoniasis. Metronidazole is an antibiotic with activity against anaerobic organisms, including Trichomonas vaginalis. A single oral dose or a seven-day course of metronidazole is commonly prescribed: Single 2g stat oral or 500 mg BD oral for 7 days.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Fluconazole:

  • Fluconazole is an antifungal agent and is effective against yeast infections (candidiasis) but not against Trichomonas vaginalis. It is not the preferred treatment for trichomoniasis.

Option C - Azithromycin:

  • Azithromycin is an antibiotic primarily used to treat bacterial infections, and it is not the preferred treatment for trichomoniasis.

Option D - Doxycycline:

  • Doxycycline is a tetracycline antibiotic used for the treatment of various bacterial infections, including certain sexually transmitted infections like chlamydia and gonorrhea. It is not the preferred treatment for trichomoniasis.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents for her routine gynecological examination. Her medical history reveals early initiation of sexual activity, multiple sexual partners, and a history of smoking. She has not received the human papillomavirus (HPV) vaccine. What is the most significant predisposing factor for cervical cancer in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Lack of HPV vaccination:

  • The most significant predisposing factor for cervical cancer is infection with high-risk strains of human papillomavirus (HPV). HPV is a sexually transmitted virus, and certain high-risk types, such as HPV 16 and 18, are strongly associated with the development of cervical cancer.

  • While all the factors mentioned (early initiation of sexual activity, multiple sexual partners, and smoking) contribute to the overall risk of cervical cancer, the most significant and directly modifiable factor in this patient is the lack of HPV vaccination.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Early initiation of sexual activity:

  • Early sexual activity is a risk factor for HPV exposure, but the primary concern is the acquisition of high-risk HPV strains.

Option B - Multiple sexual partners:

  • Having multiple sexual partners increases the risk of HPV exposure and infection with high-risk strains, contributing to the development of cervical cancer.

Option C - History of smoking:

  • Smoking is considered a cofactor in the development of cervical cancer. It may enhance the carcinogenic effects of HPV, but the lack of HPV vaccination is a more direct risk factor.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with acute lower abdominal pain and vaginal bleeding. She reports a positive home pregnancy test and a history of irregular menstrual cycles. On examination, she appears distressed, and pelvic examination reveals cervical motion tenderness. Transvaginal ultrasound shows an adnexal mass with no intrauterine gestational sac. The patient's vital signs are stable. What is the most likely site of ectopic pregnancy in this case?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Fallopian tube:

  • The clinical presentation of acute lower abdominal pain, vaginal bleeding, cervical motion tenderness, and an adnexal mass on ultrasound, especially without an intrauterine gestational sac, strongly suggests an ectopic pregnancy. The fallopian tube, particularly the ampulla, is the most common site for ectopic pregnancies, accounting for approximately 95% of cases.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Ovary:

  • Ectopic pregnancies rarely occur in the ovary. The ovary is not a favorable site for implantation.

Option B : Uterine fundus:

  • Implantation in the uterine fundus is characteristic of a normal intrauterine pregnancy. Ectopic pregnancies involve implantation outside the uterine cavity.

Option D - Cervix:

  • Ectopic pregnancies rarely occur in the cervix. Cervical pregnancies are uncommon and associated with a higher risk of severe bleeding.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents to the gynecology clinic with complaints of pelvic pain and dysmenorrhea for several years. She describes the pain as deep, aching, and often worsening during menstruation. She also reports pain during sexual intercourse. The patient has a regular menstrual cycle and no significant gynecological history. On pelvic examination, there is tenderness upon palpation of the posterior vaginal fornix, and a fixed retroverted uterus is noted. Transvaginal ultrasound is given. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct C - Endometriosis:

  • The patient's symptoms of chronic pelvic pain, dysmenorrhea, and pain during sexual intercourse, along with the findings of tenderness upon palpation of the posterior vaginal fornix and a chocolate cyst on transvaginal ultrasound, are suggestive of endometriosis.

  • Endometriosis is characterized by the presence of endometrial-like tissue outside the uterus, leading to inflammation, scarring, and the formation of chocolate cysts (endometriomas). The symptoms often include pelvic pain, dysmenorrhea, and pain during sexual intercourse.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Pelvic inflammatory disease (PID):

  • While PID can cause pelvic pain, it is often associated with other symptoms such as fever, vaginal discharge, and cervical motion tenderness. The fixed retroverted uterus is not a typical finding in PID.

Option B - Ovarian cyst rupture:

  • While ovarian cyst rupture can cause acute pelvic pain, the chronic nature of the patient's symptoms and the presence of a chocolate cyst (endometrioma) on ultrasound make endometriosis a more likely diagnosis.

Option D - Uterine fibroids:

  • Uterine fibroids can cause pelvic pain and abnormal uterine bleeding, but they are not typically associated with a fixed retroverted uterus or chocolate cysts on ultrasound.

questions.text: A 28-year-old sexually active woman presents to the emergency department with lower abdominal pain, fever, and purulent cervical discharge. She reports recent unprotected sexual intercourse with a new partner. On examination, there is cervical motion tenderness, bilateral lower abdominal tenderness, and adnexal tenderness on bimanual examination. What is the most appropriate initial diagnostic procedure for confirming the diagnosis in this patient?

choices.text: Nucleic acid amplification test (NAAT) for Chlamydia trachomatis and Neisseria gonorrhoeae

questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Nucleic acid amplification test (NAAT) for Chlamydia trachomatis and Neisseria gonorrhoeae:

  • Given the clinical presentation of lower abdominal pain, fever, and purulent cervical discharge along with the risk factors of recent unprotected sexual intercourse with a new partner, the patient is at a high risk for pelvic inflammatory disease (PID). The most appropriate initial diagnostic procedure for confirming the diagnosis in this patient is the Nucleic acid amplification test (NAAT) for Chlamydia trachomatis and Neisseria gonorrhoeae. This test is highly sensitive and specific for detecting the presence of Chlamydia trachomatis and Neisseria gonorrhoeae. These are common pathogens associated with sexually transmitted infections (STIs) that can lead to PID. NAAT is a sensitive and specific method for detecting the presence of Chlamydia trachomatis and Neisseria gonorrhoeae DNA.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Transabdominal ultrasound:

  • While ultrasound may be useful in evaluating the pelvic organs, it is not the initial diagnostic test for PID. Ultrasound findings may be nonspecific, and the diagnosis is primarily clinical.

Option B - Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI):

  • MRI may be used in cases where the diagnosis is uncertain or to evaluate complications of PID, but it is not the initial diagnostic procedure. It is more useful in assessing the extent of disease or detecting abscesses.

Option C - Endometrial biopsy:

  • Endometrial biopsy is not the first-line diagnostic test for PID. It may be considered if the diagnosis remains unclear after initial testing, but it is not routinely performed.

questions.text: A 28-year-old primigravida at 34 weeks of gestation presents to the antenatal clinic with complaints of new-onset high blood pressure. She denies any history of hypertension or renal disease. On examination, her blood pressure is 150/95 mmHg. There is no proteinuria on dipstick testing. Fetal monitoring reveals no signs of distress. What is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?

choices.text: Perform a 24-hour urine collection for protein estimation
Immediate hospitalization for induction of labor
Repeat blood pressure measurement after 6 hours

questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Repeat blood pressure measurement after 6 hours:

  • This patient with new-onset high blood pressure at 34 weeks of gestation falls under the category of gestational hypertension. Gestational hypertension is defined as elevated blood pressure (systolic ≥ 140 mmHg or diastolic ≥ 90 mmHg) that develops after 20 weeks of gestation without proteinuria.
  • Management of gestational hypertension involves close monitoring to assess for the progression to preeclampsia, which is characterized by hypertension and proteinuria. In this case, the most appropriate next step is to repeat the blood pressure measurement after a short interval to confirm the diagnosis and assess for any signs of worsening hypertension or development of proteinuria.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Prescribe antihypertensive medication:

  • In the absence of severe hypertension or signs of end-organ damage, immediate initiation of antihypertensive medication is not the first-line approach. Close monitoring is initially recommended.

Option B - Perform a 24-hour urine collection for protein estimation:

  • This is not the immediate next step. Proteinuria is a key feature of preeclampsia, and if gestational hypertension progresses to preeclampsia, proteinuria may develop.

Option C - Immediate hospitalization for induction of labor:

  • Hospitalization and induction of labor are typically reserved for cases of severe gestational hypertension or preeclampsia with complications. In this case, with no signs of severe disease or fetal distress, immediate induction is not warranted.

questions.text: A 32-year-old couple presents to the fertility clinic with a history of infertility for the past 18 months. The husband reports a normal sexual history with no known medical conditions. The wife's menstrual cycles are regular, and her hormone levels are within normal limits. As part of the initial infertility workup, a semen analysis is ordered for the husband. The results reveal a low sperm count (oligospermia), decreased sperm motility, and a high percentage of morphologically abnormal sperm. What is the most likely diagnosis based on these findings?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Oligoasthenoteratozoospermia (OAT syndrome):

  • Oligoasthenoteratozoospermia (OAT syndrome) is a condition characterized by low sperm count (oligospermia), decreased sperm motility (asthenospermia), and a high percentage of morphologically abnormal sperm (teratospermia). This combination of abnormalities in sperm quantity, motility, and morphology can contribute to male infertility.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Varicocele:

  • While a varicocele (enlarged veins in the scrotum) can impact sperm production and quality, it typically presents with a specific set of findings, such as a bag of worms sensation on palpation and is more commonly associated with increased spermatic vein reflux.

Option B - Obstructive azoospermia:

  • Obstructive azoospermia is characterized by the absence of sperm in the ejaculate due to a blockage in the reproductive tract. This condition is not typically associated with decreased sperm motility or abnormal morphology.

Option D - Retrograde ejaculation:

  • In retrograde ejaculation, semen is redirected into the bladder instead of being expelled from the penis. This condition is characterized by a lack of ejaculate and is not associated with abnormalities in sperm count, motility, or morphology.

questions.text: A 26-year-old primigravida at 36 weeks of gestation presents to the emergency department with a generalized tonic-clonic seizure. The seizure lasts for approximately 3 minutes. On regaining consciousness, the patient is noted to have elevated blood pressure (170/110 mmHg) and mild epigastric pain. Initial investigations reveal proteinuria on urine dipstick. Fetal monitoring shows signs of distress. What is the most appropriate immediate management for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Administer magnesium sulfate:

  • This patient's presentation is consistent with eclampsia, a serious complication of preeclampsia characterized by the onset of seizures. The immediate management of eclampsia involves controlling seizures and preventing their recurrence, along with addressing the hypertensive crisis.
  • Magnesium sulfate is the first-line agent for seizure control in eclampsia. It acts as a central nervous system depressant and is effective in preventing and treating eclamptic seizures. It also has neuroprotective effects on the fetus.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Initiate antihypertensive therapy with labetalol:

  • While managing hypertension is important, antihypertensive therapy is not the immediate priority in the presence of ongoing seizures. Magnesium sulfate takes precedence for seizure control.

Option C - Perform an emergency cesarean section:

  • While delivery is the definitive treatment for preeclampsia and eclampsia, the immediate focus should be on stabilizing the patient and controlling seizures. Cesarean section is indicated if there is persistent maternal or fetal distress after initial stabilization.

Option D - Administer diazepam for seizure control:

  • Magnesium sulfate is the preferred agent for seizure control in eclampsia. Diazepam is an alternative, but magnesium sulfate is more commonly used due to its safety profile and additional benefits.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman, G2P2, presents to the postpartum unit after a vaginal delivery. Her pregnancy and labor were uneventful. The delivery was completed without complications, and the placenta was delivered intact. Approximately 30 minutes after delivery, the patient complains of increased vaginal bleeding. On examination, the fundus is firm, but the bleeding persists. Initial attempts to control bleeding with uterine massage and administration of oxytocin have been ineffective. What is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Perform a bimanual uterine examination:

  • This patient's presentation is concerning for postpartum hemorrhage (PPH), defined as blood loss exceeding 500 ml after a vaginal delivery. In this case, the persistent bleeding despite a firm fundus suggests a possible source within the uterus, such as retained placental tissue.
  • A bimanual examination involves the insertion of one hand into the vagina to assess the uterus while the other hand is placed on the abdomen to palpate the fundus. This can help identify retained placental fragments or clots that may be causing the ongoing bleeding.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Administer methylergonovine:

  • Methylergonovine is a uterotonic medication that can be used to help control postpartum hemorrhage. However, the first step should be to identify the cause of the bleeding through a bimanual examination.

Option C - Insert a Bakri balloon:

  • A Bakri balloon is a device used for uterine tamponade in the management of postpartum hemorrhage. While it can be a valuable intervention, it is typically employed after the cause of bleeding has been identified.

Option D - Order a complete blood count (CBC):

  • While assessing the patient's blood count is important in the management of postpartum hemorrhage, the immediate priority is to identify and address the cause of the ongoing bleeding.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman, G3P2, at 34 weeks of gestation presents to the emergency department with sudden-onset abdominal pain and vaginal bleeding. She reports no antenatal complications until now. On examination, the uterus is tense, and there is tenderness on palpation. Fetal monitoring shows signs of distress. What is the most likely diagnosis, and what is the immediate management for this patient?

choices.text: Uterine atony; uterine massage and oxytocin

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Abruptio placenta; immediate delivery:

  • This patient's presentation is suggestive of abruptio placenta, where the placenta detaches from the uterine wall before delivery. The sudden-onset abdominal pain, vaginal bleeding, and signs of fetal distress are characteristic features. Immediate delivery is the management of choice in cases of abruptio placenta to mitigate the risk to both the mother and the fetus.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Placenta previa, initiate tocolysis:

  • Placenta previa presents with painless vaginal bleeding. In contrast, abruptio placenta is associated with painful bleeding and a tense uterus.

Option B - Uterine rupture, emergency cesarean section:

  • Uterine rupture may present with severe abdominal pain and signs of fetal distress, but it is not associated with the characteristic uterine tenderness seen in abruptio placenta.

Option D - Uterine atony, uterine massage and oxytocin:

  • Uterine atony, or failure of the uterus to contract, can cause postpartum hemorrhage but is not typically associated with sudden-onset abdominal pain and uterine tenderness seen in abruptio placenta.

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl presents to the pediatric endocrinology clinic with concerns about delayed puberty. She reports a lack of breast development and menstrual cycles compared to her peers. On examination, she is short for her age, with a broad chest, widely spaced nipples, and a high-arched palate. The physical examination also reveals a webbed neck and cubitus valgus. What is the most likely diagnosis, and what additional cardiovascular assessment is crucial for this patient?

choices.text: Klinefelter syndrome; echocardiogram for aortic coarctation
Turner's syndrome; echocardiogram for aortic coarctation
Androgen Insensitivity Syndrome; electrocardiogram for arrhythmias
Congenital Adrenal Hyperplasia; magnetic resonance angiography for renal anomalies

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Turner's syndrome; echocardiogram for aortic coarctation:

  • This patient's clinical features, including short stature, webbed neck, cubitus valgus, and the 45,X karyotype, are consistent with Turner's syndrome (45,XO). Turner's syndrome is characterized by the partial or complete absence of one of the X chromosomes in females. Patients with Turner's syndrome are at an increased risk of cardiovascular anomalies, with coarctation of the aorta being one of the common findings. Therefore, an echocardiogram is crucial to assess the aortic arch and rule out aortic coarctation in individuals with Turner's syndrome.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Klinefelter syndrome:

  • This condition involves the presence of an extra X chromosome in males (47,XXY) and typically presents with tall stature, gynecomastia, and infertility. It is not associated with the characteristic features of Turner's syndrome that are mentioned in the question.

Option C - Androgen Insensitivity Syndrome:

  • This syndrome involves a genetic mutation resulting in the inability of cells to respond to androgens, leading to incomplete masculinization in genetically male individuals. It does not present with the features described in this case.

Option D - Congenital Adrenal Hyperplasia:

  • This condition involves enzymatic defects in cortisol synthesis, leading to an excess of androgens. It is not associated with the characteristic physical features of Turner's syndrome.

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman presents to the gynecology clinic with complaints of pelvic pain and discomfort during intercourse. On pelvic examination, the physician notes tenderness in the rectouterine pouch and suspects the presence of a pelvic pathology. Which of the following conditions is most likely to cause tenderness in the rectouterine pouch?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Endometriosis:

  • Endometriosis is a condition in which tissue similar to the lining of the uterus (endometrium) grows outside the uterus. It commonly involves the rectouterine pouch, also known as Douglas pouch or cul-de-sac. In endometriosis, the ectopic endometrial tissue can cause inflammation and scarring in the pelvic cavity, leading to tenderness and pain, particularly in the rectouterine pouch.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Ovarian cyst:

  • While ovarian cysts can cause pelvic pain, they are less likely to specifically cause tenderness in the rectouterine pouch.

Option C - Uterine fibroids:

  • Uterine fibroids are noncancerous growths of the uterus and are less likely to cause tenderness in the rectouterine pouch.

Option D - Pelvic inflammatory disease:

  • Pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) involves infection and inflammation of the female reproductive organs. While it can cause pelvic pain and tenderness, it may not specifically target the rectouterine pouch as seen in endometriosis.

questions.text: A 35-year-old obese woman presents to the gynecology clinic with complaints of abnormal vaginal bleeding between menstrual cycles. She reports occasional pelvic discomfort but denies any pain during intercourse. On pelvic examination, a soft, less than 1 cm, reddish-purple, finger-like projection is noted on the cervix. The patient has no significant medical history, and Pap smear results from the previous year were normal. What is the appropriate management for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Simple polypectomy:

  • The patient's presentation with abnormal vaginal bleeding, occasional pelvic discomfort, and the visual finding of a soft, less than 1cm, reddish-purple, finger-like projection on the cervix is consistent with a cervical polyp. Cervical polyps are benign growths that originate from the cervical canal or the surface of the cervix. They can cause irregular bleeding and may occasionally be associated with pelvic discomfort. The appropriate management for a cervical polyp is simple polypectomy. This procedure can often be performed in the office setting during a gynecological examination. The polyp is grasped and excised, and the specimen may be sent for histological examination to confirm its benign nature.

Incorrect Options: 

Option A - Referral for colposcopy : Colposcopy is not the primary management for a cervical polyp. Colposcopy is typically indicated for the evaluation of abnormal cervical cytology (Pap smear) or suspicion of cervical dysplasia or cancer.

Option C - Antibiotic therapy: Antibiotic therapy is not indicated for the management of cervical polyps. Cervical polyps are non-infectious, benign growths, and antibiotic therapy is not effective for their treatment.

Option D - Hysteroscopic resection : Hysteroscopic resection is a more invasive procedure and is typically reserved for the removal of larger intrauterine lesions, such as submucosal fibroids. It is not the first-line treatment for cervical polyps.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman presents to the gynecology clinic with a complaint of amenorrhea. reports history of frequent domestic fights with her partner and in laws regarding heavy workload. She reports having regular menstrual cycles in the past but has not had a menstrual period for the past six months. The patient denies significant weight changes, excessive exercise, or stress. She is not sexually active and has not used any form of contraception. On examination, there is no evidence of hirsutism, acne, or galactorrhea. Serum beta-human chorionic gonadotropin (β-hCG) is negative. What initial investigation should be considered?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Serum follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH):

  • The most appropriate initial investigation for the evaluation of amenorrhea in this patient is a serum follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) level. The patient's history of regular menstrual cycles in the past, the presence of significant weight changes, excessive exercise, or stress, along with a negative serum beta-human chorionic gonadotropin (β-hCG) test, makes hypothalamic amenorrhea a likely cause.

  • Hypothalamic amenorrhea often presents with low FSH levels due to the central suppression of the hypothalamic-pituitary-ovarian axis. This hormonal profile helps differentiate hypothalamic causes from other conditions.

Incorrect Options: 

Option A - Pelvic ultrasound : While pelvic ultrasound may be useful in assessing the ovaries and the uterine cavity, it is not the first-line investigation for evaluating amenorrhea in the absence of other concerning symptoms or signs.

Option B - Repeat β-hCG after one week : The initial β-hCG test was negative, and the patient denies sexual activity. Repeat testing after one week is unnecessary in the absence of new symptoms or signs.

Option D - Serum prolactin level : While hyperprolactinemia can cause amenorrhea, the absence of galactorrhea makes it less likely. Measuring serum prolactin levels is an appropriate investigation if there are signs or symptoms suggestive of hyperprolactinemia.

questions.text:
A 32-year-old woman at 34 weeks of gestation presents to the emergency department with complaints of upper abdominal pain, headache, and visual disturbances. She reports nausea and malaise over the past 24 hours. On examination, her blood pressure is elevated (160/100 mmHg), and she has epigastric tenderness. Laboratory tests are given. What is the appropriate management in this case?

			38
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Prompt delivery:

  • The diagnosis for this patient is HELLP syndrome. HELLP syndrome is a severe variant of preeclampsia characterized by Hemolysis (H), Elevated Liver enzymes (EL), and a Low Platelet count (LP). The patient's presentation with upper abdominal pain, headache, visual disturbances, nausea, malaise, elevated blood pressure (160/100 mmHg), epigastric tenderness, thrombocytopenia, elevated liver enzymes, and hemolysis is indicative of HELLP syndrome.

  • Prompt delivery is the mainstay of management for HELLP syndrome. Delivery is often recommended, even if the fetus is premature, as it is crucial to prevent maternal and fetal complications. The decision for delivery is based on the severity of the syndrome, gestational age, and the condition of both the mother and the fetus.

Incorrect Options: 

Option A - Antihypertensive therapy : While elevated blood pressure is a component of HELLP syndrome, the primary management is prompt delivery. Antihypertensive therapy may be used to manage hypertension but is not the main focus.

Option B - Magnesium sulfate for seizure prophylaxis : Magnesium sulfate is typically used for seizure prophylaxis in cases of severe preeclampsia, but in the context of HELLP syndrome, the mainstay is prompt delivery.

Option D - Supportive care : Supportive care is important in the overall management, but the definitive treatment for HELLP syndrome is delivery.

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman presents to the gynecology clinic with complaints of heavy menstrual bleeding and pelvic pressure. She reports a gradual increase in the size of her abdomen over the past year. On examination, a palpable, irregular, and firm mass is noted in the lower abdomen. Ultrasound reveals multiple well-defined, hypoechoic lesions within the uterine wall. What additional investigation may be useful for further evaluation?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Pelvic magnetic resonance imaging (MRI):

  • The patient's presentation with heavy menstrual bleeding, pelvic pressure, and a palpable, irregular, and firm mass in the lower abdomen is suggestive of uterine leiomyoma, commonly known as fibroids. The characteristic ultrasound findings of multiple well-defined, hypoechoic lesions within the uterine wall support this diagnosis.

  • Pelvic magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) is the most appropriate additional investigation for further evaluation of uterine leiomyomas. MRI provides detailed information about the size, location, and characteristics of the fibroids, aiding in treatment planning.

Incorrect Options: 

Option A - Serum CA-125 level : CA-125 is a tumor marker that is often used in the evaluation of ovarian masses, particularly in the context of suspected ovarian cancer. However, it is not the primary investigation for uterine leiomyomas.

Option C - Endometrial biopsy:  Endometrial biopsy is a valuable tool for evaluating endometrial pathology, such as endometrial hyperplasia or cancer, but it is not the primary investigation for uterine leiomyomas.

Option D - Transvaginal ultrasound : While transvaginal ultrasound can identify uterine leiomyomas, the scenario describes that ultrasound has already been performed, revealing well-defined, hypoechoic lesions within the uterine wall. Pelvic MRI is often employed when additional details are needed.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents to the gynecology clinic for a routine Pap smear. The Pap smear reveals low-grade squamous intraepithelial lesions (LSIL). She has no history of abnormal Pap smears and reports no significant gynecological symptoms. The clinician decides to perform colposcopy for further evaluation. During colposcopy, multiple acetowhite lesions are observed on the cervix. What is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Biopsy of acetowhite lesions:

  • The patient with a Pap smear revealing low-grade squamous intraepithelial lesions (LSIL) and multiple acetowhite lesions on colposcopy requires further evaluation with a biopsy of the acetowhite lesions.

  • Biopsy is essential to determine the extent and severity of cervical abnormalities, including whether there is progression to high-grade squamous intraepithelial lesions (HSIL) or cervical cancer. The management of cervical abnormalities, especially when LSIL is identified, depends on the results of the biopsy.

Incorrect Options: 

Option A - Immediate cryotherapy: Cryotherapy may be considered as a treatment option for certain cervical abnormalities, but a biopsy is needed for accurate diagnosis before initiating any treatment.

Option C - Repeat Pap smear in 6 months : While follow-up Pap smears are a part of the management of cervical abnormalities, in the presence of LSIL and acetowhite lesions, a biopsy is indicated for a more comprehensive evaluation.

Option D - HPV testing : HPV testing is valuable in the assessment of cervical abnormalities. However, in this scenario, a biopsy is the next step for a definitive diagnosis.

questions.text: A 15-year-old girl presents to the pediatric clinic with complaints of cyclic lower abdominal pain that worsens during her menstrual periods. She started menstruating at the age of 12, but since then, she has experienced increasing difficulty with tampon insertion and reports the inability to use menstrual cups. On examination, there is a bulging, bluish membrane at the introitus, and a pelvic ultrasound confirms the presence of a hematocolpos. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B -  Imperforate hymen:

  • The most likely diagnosis for this patient is imperforate hymen. The clinical presentation of cyclic lower abdominal pain that worsens during menstrual periods, difficulty with tampon insertion, inability to use menstrual cups, and the presence of a bulging, bluish membrane at the introitus are consistent with imperforate hymen.

Incorrect Options: 

Option A - Vaginal septum : A vaginal septum is a congenital condition where a wall or partition divides the vagina. While it can cause similar symptoms, the characteristic finding of a bulging, bluish membrane at the introitus is more indicative of imperforate hymen.

Option C - Vaginal agenesis : Vaginal agenesis refers to the absence or underdevelopment of the vagina. This condition is not likely in this case, as there is a bulging membrane at the introitus.

Option D - Müllerian agenesis : Müllerian agenesis, or Mayer-Rokitansky-Küster-Hauser (MRKH) syndrome, involves the underdevelopment or absence of the uterus and upper part of the vagina. It does not typically present with a bulging membrane at the introitus.

questions.text: A 22-year-old male presents to the clinic with a tall stature and elongated limbs. On examination, he demonstrates hypermobility of the joints and has a family history of similar features. The ophthalmologist is consulted to evaluate for ocular manifestations. What is the most common ocular feature associated with this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Superio-temporal ectopia lentis:

  • The clinical picture of tall stature, elongated limbs, hypermobility of the joints, and family history of similar features gives the diagnosis of Marfan’s Syndrome.

  • The most common ocular feature associated with Marfan syndrome is ectopia lentis, the lens typically dislocates in a superio-temporal direction.

Incorrect Options:

Option A – Megalocornea: Megalocornea refers to an abnormally large cornea. This is the most prominent ocular feature seen in patients suffering from Marfan's Syndrome.

Option B - Inferio-nasal ectopia lentis: Inferio-nasal ectopia lentis is seen in patients with homocystinuria.

Option D – Retinal detachment: Rhegmatogenous retinal detachment is seen in patients suffering from Marfan's Syndrome but the most common feature of Marfan's Syndrome is Superio-temporal ectopia lentis. Patient with Stickler syndrome presents with retinal detachment as the most common ocular feature.

questions.text:
Match the following images with their accurate description


	
		
			
			1. 

			
			
			
			a. Dendritic ulcer
			
		
		
			
			2. 
			
			
			b. Superficial punctate keratitis
			
		
		
			
			3. 

			 
			
			
			c. Pseudo dendritis
			
		
		
			
			4. 
			
			
			d. Nummular keratitis
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - 1-b, 2-c, 3-d, 4-a:

  • This option correctly matches all the images with their correct description.

Image 1 - Superficial punctate keratitis: Superficial punctate keratitis (SPK) is a condition characterized by multiple, fine, pinpoint epithelial erosions on the surface of the cornea often seen as punctate or dot-like lesions on the corneal surface caused from viral infections like Herpes simplex virus.

Image 2 – Pseudo dendritis: Pseudo dendritis is seen in viral keratitis caused by Herpes Zoster Ophthalmicus. It has no knob ends as seen in dendritic ulcer caused due to herpes simplex virus.

Image 3 – Nummular keratitis: It is seen in case of stromal involvement by Herpes Zoster Ophthalmicus. Seen as a coin shape just under the epithelium.

Image 4 - Dendritic ulcer: There are knob ends filled with viruses as seen in the image, they are usually linear. It is caused by herpes simplex virus.

 

All Other options A, B, and D incorrectly match the image with their description.

questions.text:
An 18-year-old female presents with complaints of blurry vision and frequent changes in her glasses prescription. Upon examination, you notice the following finding in her left eye.



What is not true about the condition associated with the patient?

choices.text: V-shaped deformity of the lower lid on down gaze is seen
Fleischer’s ring is seen through slit lamp
Red reflex is seen on retinoscopy
It can lead to uniocular diplopia

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Red reflex is seen on retinoscopy:

  • The given scenario and image given in the question confirm the diagnosis of keratoconus.

  • On retinoscopy - by objective refraction method, reflex looks like a cross, also called scissor's reflex and not red reflex.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - V-shaped deformity of the lower lid on down gaze is seen: V-shaped deformity of lower lid on down gaze typically observed using a penlight or torchlight in patients suffering from keratoconus.

Option B - Fleischer’s ring is seen through Slit lamp: Fleischer’s ring is iron deposition at the base of the cone at the epithelial layer seen in patients suffering from keratoconus.

Option D - It can lead to uniocular diplopia: Keratoconus can cause irregular astigmatism, which may lead to distorted or double vision.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male patient with a known history of multisystem inflammatory disorder characterized by the formation of granulomas most commonly involving lungs presents with floaters and vision loss in his right eye. On examination, you observe segmented venous sheathing on the fundus examination. What is this finding known as?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D – Candle wax dripping:

  • The systemic disease in question is referred to as Sarcoidosis and the segmented venous sheathing seen in patients suffering from sarcoidosis is called Candle wax dripping.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Lander’s sign: It is a pre-retinal nodule (exact location - Posterior hyaloid membrane of vitreous and retina) seen in patients suffering from Sarcoidosis.

Option B – Iris pearls: Iris pearls are pathognomonic feature of leprosy associated with Uveitis, mainly containing bacteria.

Option C – Suguira’s sign: Perilimbal depigmentation is called Suiguira’s sign seen in the Convalescent phase of Vogt Koyanagi Harada Syndrome.

questions.text: A 28-year-old male presents with a complaint of sudden painless marked diminished vision, but he describes a sensation of "looking through a tunnel." On examination, thread like arteries and segmented flow of blood in veins are observed. Which of the following statements is not true regarding the condition responsible for his symptoms?

choices.text: Seen in patient with dual blood supply to macula
Cilioretinal artery is a branch of short posterior ciliary artery
It is seen in the patient with central retinal vein occlusion
Quinine toxicity and drugs like Vigabatrin can cause tunnel vision

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - It is seen in the patient with central retinal vein occlusion:

  • Tunnel vision is not a typical presentation of central retinal vein occlusion (CRVO), it is more commonly seen in Central Retinal Artery Occlusion in which patients who got dual blood supply to the macular area (central retinal artery and cilioretinal artery) might still not be blind instead they get tunnel vision because when the cilioretinal artery is supplying, its supplies a very small amount of field at the center, in result a very small area is retained leading to tunnel or tubular vision.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Seen in patient with dual blood supply to the macula:

  • 14% of the population has dual blood supply to the macular area, One is the central retinal artery, and the other artery is cilioretinal artery.

  • The cilioretinal artery is a branch of the short posterior ciliary artery and can contribute to the blood supply of the macula, hence the patient suffering from the CRAO might still not be blind due to the blood supplied by the cilioretinal artery.

Option B - The cilioretinal artery is a branch of the short posterior ciliary artery.

  • The cilioretinal artery is indeed a branch of the short posterior ciliary artery, providing blood supply to the macula.

Option D - Quinine toxicity and drugs like Vigabatrin can cause tunnel vision.

  • Drugs like Quinine and Vigabatrin are associated with visual field defects, including tunnel vision. Quinine toxicity can cause a condition known as cinchonism, which includes visual disturbances, while Vigabatrin, an antiepileptic medication, is known to cause concentric visual field constriction.

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient with diabetes presents with a painful, red eye and decreased vision. On examination, a perforating corneal ulcer with stromal edema is observed. The patient has developed these symptoms in the past 48 hours. Which organism is commonly associated with this clinical presentation?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B – Pseudomonas aeruginosa:

  • Pseudomonas aeruginosa is known for causing rapidly progressing and potentially severe corneal infections. The quick onset of symptoms (usually presents with corneal perforation within 48 hours), along with the presence of stromal edema, is consistent with bacterial keratitis, and Pseudomonas aeruginosa is a common culprit in such cases. Pseudomonas release exotoxins which have collagenolytic effect causing perforation.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Streptococcus pneumoniae:

  • Streptococcus pneumoniae is not a common cause of rapidly progressing corneal ulcers. While it can be associated with ocular infections, it is not typically implicated in cases with the acute onset and severity described in the question.

Option C - Herpes simplex virus:

  • Herpes simplex virus (HSV) can cause viral keratitis, but the symptoms and signs associated with HSV keratitis often involve a dendritic corneal ulcer rather than a rapidly progressing bacterial corneal ulcer. The timeline and characteristics of the ulcer described are not typical of HSV keratitis.

Option D - Staphylococcus aureus:
