  • Staphylococcus aureus can cause bacterial keratitis, but the rapid onset of symptoms and stromal edema may be more indicative of Pseudomonas aeruginosa, which is known for its aggressive and fast-progressing corneal infections.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department with swelling and redness around his left eye. He complains of pain upon eye movement and has a low-grade fever. On examination, there is proptosis, restriction of extraocular movements, and tenderness to palpation. Imaging reveals opacification of the left ethmoid sinus. Which of the following organisms is most commonly associated with this condition in children?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B – Haemophilus influenzae:

  • The clinical picture of U/L involvement of the eye with low-grade fever, proptosis, and restriction of ocular movements suggests the diagnosis of Orbital cellulitis and ethmoid sinus infection confirms the diagnosis. The most common organism associated with the development of orbital cellulitis in children is Haemophilus influenzae. This bacterium is a gram-negative coccobacillus and is a common pathogen in sinusitis.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Streptococcus pyogenes: Streptococcus pyogenes is not the most common pathogen associated with orbital cellulitis in children.

Option C – Staphylococcus aureus: Staphylococcus aureus is most commonly associated with orbital cellulitis in the general population whereas Haemophilus influenzae is most commonly associated with orbital cellulitis in the pediatric population.

Option D – Escherichia coli: Escherichia coli is not a common pathogen associated with orbital cellulitis. It is more commonly associated with urinary tract infections and gastrointestinal infections.

questions.text: Which of the following images correctly depicts proliferative diabetic retinopathy?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - 

 

  • This image correctly depicts Proliferative diabetic retinopathy according to ETDRS classification, showing large flame shaped hemorrhages, hard exudates, cotton wool spots, and there is a tuft of new blood vessels at the disc, marking it as a Neovascularization at disc.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - 

  • In this image we can only see hard exudates, small flame shaped hemorrhage features of Mild nonproliferative diabetic retinopathy.

Option B - 

  • In this image we can see multiple cotton wool spots, large flame shaped hemorrhages, and large dot and blot hemorrhage making it as Moderate non-preproliferative diabetic retinopathy according to ETDRS classification

Option D -  

  • In this image we can see there is looping of vessels, blot hemorrhages, large dot hemorrhage and cotton wool spots features of moderate nonproliferative diabetic retinopathy according to ETDRS classification.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child living in a rural community brought by her parents presents with a history of recurrent eye infections, characterized by mucopurulent discharge, redness, and intense pain. On examination, you note follicular conjunctivitis with pronounced conjunctival scarring and corneal opacification. What us the most likely complication in this patient's condition is?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D – Corneal ulcer:

  • The clinical picture of mucopurulent discharge from the eye and intense pain gives the diagnosis of trachoma in a 5-year-old child. In trachoma, a bacterial infection caused by Chlamydia trachomatis, repeated episodes of inflammation can lead to conjunctival scarring and corneal opacification. These ulcers can contribute to visual impairment and are a significant complication of advanced trachoma.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A – Trichiasis: Trichiasis is a condition where eyelashes are misdirected and rub against the eye's surface, potentially causing irritation and corneal abrasions. While trichiasis can be associated with trachoma, it is more of a consequence of the disease rather than a complication.

Option B – Scarring: Conjunctival scarring is a common consequence of recurrent trachoma infections. The scarring can lead to various complications, including impaired vision and increased susceptibility to further infections.

Option C – Entropion: Entropion is a condition where the eyelid turns inward, causing the eyelashes to rub against the eye. While entropion can be associated with trachoma due to conjunctival scarring, it is more of a consequence of the disease rather than a complication.

questions.text: A 7-year-old male is brought to the clinic by his parents due to concerns about his vision. On examination, you notice dry, foamy patches on the conjunctiva as shown in the image. The clinician says the dry foamy patch on the conjunctiva is a keratinized epithelium. Which side is more commonly affected?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B – Temporal side:

  • The clinical picture in the question and image confirms the condition is Bitot's spot. Bitot's spots are a clinical manifestation of vitamin A deficiency and are characterized by dry, foamy, triangular patches on the conjunctiva. The keratinized epithelium in Bitot's spots is more commonly found on the temporal side of the conjunctiva.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Nasal side: In Bitot's spots, the keratinized epithelium is not commonly found on the nasal side. Bitot's spots usually appear most commonly on the temporal side of the conjunctiva.

Option C – Inferiorly: Bitot's spots are not specifically associated with the inferior aspect of the conjunctiva. The characteristic dry, foamy patches are more commonly found on the lateral or temporal side.

Option D – Superiorly: Bitot's spots are not typically observed on the superior side of the conjunctiva. The temporal side is the more common location for the keratinized epithelium associated with Bitot's spots.

questions.text:
A 42-year-old female with a history of glaucoma presents for a follow-up visit. She has been using an anti-glaucoma eye drop for several months. During the examination, the ophthalmologist notices the following findings in the iris of the patient.



Which anti-glaucoma drug is most likely taken by the patient here?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B – Latanoprost:

  • Latanoprost is a prostaglandin analogue commonly used as an anti-glaucoma eye drop. It works by increasing the outflow of aqueous humor through the uveoscleral pathway.

  • Heterochromia iridis, which is a difference in iris color between the two eyes, can occur as a side effect of Latanoprost use. This change in iris pigmentation is more commonly seen in patients with mixed-colored irises, where the darker color becomes more prominent.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Timolol: Timolol is a beta-blocker commonly used in the treatment of glaucoma. Some of the potential side effects of timolol eye drops include NLD obstruction, corneal anaesthesia, and blepharoconjunctivitis.

Option C - Apraclonidine: Apraclonidine is an alpha-2 adrenergic agonist used in glaucoma treatment. Some of the potential side effects of apraclonidine eye drops include: Lid retraction.

Option D - Netarsudil: Netarsudil is a Rho kinase inhibitor used in the management of glaucoma. Some of the potential side effects of netarsudil eye drops include: Vortex keratopathy also known as cornea verticillata.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female presents with complaints of dry eyes and occasional blurred vision. She has a history of rheumatoid arthritis for which she takes nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs). On examination, the ophthalmologist suspects dry eye syndrome and decides to perform the Schirmer test. Which paper is used in the Schirmer test to assess the wet length?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Whatman paper:

  • In the Schirmer test, Whatman filter paper No. 41 is commonly used to measure tear production and assess dry eye syndrome. This standardized filter paper is designed to absorb tears, allowing for the measurement of the wet length as an indicator of tear production.

Incorrect Options:
Option A – Litmus paper: Litmus paper is typically used to test the acidity or alkalinity of a solution based on a color change. It is not used in the Schirmer test.

Option C – Wax paper: Wax paper is not used in the Schirmer test. It is a type of paper that has been coated with a thin layer of wax to make it moisture-resistant.

Option D – Parchment paper: Parchment paper is not used in the Schirmer test. It is a type of paper that is treated with sulfuric acid or zinc chloride to give it a smooth and non-stick surface.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male presents to the ophthalmology camp in a rural area with complaints of gradual visual loss in both eyes. The ophthalmologist asks his intern what is the most common cause of preventable blindness in India?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B – Cataract:

  • Cataract is the clouding of the eye's lens, leading to visual impairment. Cataracts are a major cause of preventable blindness worldwide and in India, and they are the leading cause of preventable blindness.

Incorrect Options:

Option A – Trachoma: Trachoma is a bacterial infection caused by Chlamydia trachomatis. Trachoma is the chronic conjunctivitis in children which is caused by Chlamydia trachomatis. Trachoma is the world's leading cause of preventable and irreversible blindness and is the second most common cause in India.

Option C – Glaucoma: Glaucoma is a group of conditions that are characterized by chronic progressive optic neuropathy that results in characteristic morphological changes at the optic nerve head and in the retinal nerve fibre layer. It is the most common cause of blindness in developed countries but not in India.

Option D – Refractive error: Refractive errors, such as myopia (near-sightedness), hypermetropia (far-sightedness), and astigmatism, can cause visual impairment. It is the second most common cause of blindness in India.

questions.text: The parents of a 13-month-old child took her to the clinic for a general examination. The infant couldn't speak "papa," but other developmental milestones were normal, according to the doctor. In which month does the relevant milestone development take place?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - 9 months:

  • A 9-month-old infant starts babbling bi-syllables without meaning (mama, papa).

  • Other milestones at 9 months:

    • Child waves bye-bye

    • Assisted pincer grasp

    • Standing with support

Incorrect Options:

Option A - 6 months:

  • Milestones achieved at 6 months:

    • Mono-syllables babbling (ma, ba, da)

    • Mirror play appears

    • Immature Palmar grasp

Option C - 12 months:

  • Milestones achieved at 12 months:

    • Speaks 2-3 words with meaning

    • Kisses on request

    • Plays a simple ball game

 

Option D - 18 months:

  • At 18 months, the baby starts to speak a vocabulary of 8–10 words with meaning.

questions.text: The mother of a 3-year-old child complains to the pediatrician that her son looks "swollen." When examined, the patient weighs 9 kg and has pitting edema, moon face, reddish hair, hepatomegaly, dry skin, and a low appetite. Which of the following conditions will lead to complications?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Hypoglycemia:

  • The patient suffers from severe acute malnutrition (SAM).

  • Based on the findings of hepatomegaly, moon face, edema, and poor appetite suggestive of Kwashiorkor.

  • In SAM, hepatic gluconeogenesis is reduced, and energy production from substrates like galactose and fructose is impaired. This increases the risk of hypoglycemia.

  • Intestinal absorption of nutrients and glucose is also markedly reduced in children with or without edematous malnutrition.

  • Blood glucose clearance is reduced along with insulin levels, but these changes do not increase blood glucose levels.

  • Hypoglycemia increases both morbidity and mortality in these patients.

Incorrect Options: 

Option A - Neurogenic shock:

  • In severe acute malnutrition patients, there is an alteration in gut barrier function and mucosal immune function, and reduced production of pro-inflammatory cytokines.

  • Lymph nodes, tonsils, and thymus are atrophic and they are at increased risk of developing septic shock.

  • There is no role of neurogenic shock in SAM.

Option B - Hypernatremia:

  • Sodium pump activity is reduced at the cellular level, which leads to increased cellular membrane permeability that results in an increase in intracellular sodium.

Option C - Hyperthermia:

  • The basal metabolic rate in severe acute malnutrition is reduced to 30%.

  • Both generation and heat loss are impaired; thus, the child has hypothermia, not hyperthermia.

questions.text: A 2-year-old child was brought to the emergency department with complaints of blue coloration of the body within a few minutes of playing. His SpO2 is 78%, Temp: 37.7℃. After squatting, cyanosis disappears. Examination shows a single S2 and RVH pattern on ECG. What are the X-ray findings consistent with this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A:

  • The given clinical scenario is consistent with the X-ray findings of a ‘Boot Shaped Heart (or) 'Cor En Sabot' appearance’ that is suggestive of Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF).

  • TOF:

    • MC congenital cyanotic heart disease in children

    • 4 Components:

      • Large, non restricted VSD

      • Right ventricular outflow tract obstruction (RVOT) or pulmonary stenosis (infundibular or subpulmonic>valvular)

      • Overriding of aorta

      • Right ventricular hypertrophy

Incorrect Options:

Option B:

  • The given X-ray finding is Egg on the String Sign appearance which is seen in Transposition of Great Arteries

  • TGA: Pulmonary artery instead of arising from Right Ventricle, arises from left ventricle and aorta instead of arising from left ventricle, arises from right ventricle

Option C:

  • The given X-ray finding is a box-shaped heart seen in the Ebstein anomaly.

Option D:

  • The given X-ray finding is 'Figure 8' or 'snow man' appearance seen in supracardiac TAPVC (Total Anomalous Pulmonary Venous Connection)

questions.text: A 10-year-old child comes into the clinic complaining of skin changes that have occurred during the last six days, including a symmetrical, pigmented rash over the neck, upper body, and limbs. Lesions became larger over time, and after being in the sun, they started to burn and itch. She has a history of diarrhea. There is no history of any change in her behavior. Due to a decline in maize planting in her area, which provides the household's staple meal, her dietary history showed a lower food intake. In this patient, what is highly susceptible?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Pellagra:

  • In the above case, the symmetrical pigmented rash around the neck and the upper trunk region limbs with a sore mouth and itching burning, diarrhea history, and maize-based diets, are all suggestive of Pellagra.

    • Pellagra is a disease of 4D's

      • Diarrhea

      • Dermatitis: Photosensitivity, rashes on sun-exposed area like Casal's necklace (hyperpigmented rash in the neck area)

      • Dementia (early onset)

      • Death

Incorrect Options: 

Option A - Scurvy:

  • Scurvy is caused by a lack of vitamin C (ascorbic acid).

  • It is characterized by gingival swelling, bleeding gums, generalized tenderness of the limbs, painful joint swellings, pseudoparalysis, and scorbutic rosary.

Option C - Kwashiorkor:

  • Kwashiorkor is a severe form of malnutrition.

  • It is most common in some developing regions where babies and children do not get enough protein or other essential nutrients in their diet.

  • It is characterized by pitting edema, fat sugar baby appearance, flaky paint dermatosis, and a flag sign of hair.

Option D - Beri-Beri:

  • Thiamine deficiency causes Beri-Beri

    • Wet Beri-Beri: There can be features of congestive cardiac failure like edema, respiratory distress

    • Dry Beri-Beri: Neurological features like irritability, weakness of lower limbs, and DTRs (Deep tendon reflexes) may be

questions.text: A newborn delivered at 31 weeks gestation and undergoing respiratory distress as a result of prolonged labor has to be admitted to the Neonatal Intensive Care Unit (NICU) shortly after birth; bag and mask ventilation was initiated. The mother's prenatal assessment had been discussed with the doctor; under what circumstances would the bag and mask ventilation need to be stopped promptly?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Congenital diaphragmatic hernia:

  • Bag and mask ventilation - Absolute contraindication in congenital diaphragmatic hernia.

  • Congenital Diaphragmatic hernia:

    • There is a pleuroperitoneal membrane defect through which the bowel loops herniate into the thorax

    • In bag and mask ventilation,can cause insufflation of the stomach and subsequent extra pulmonary compression of the lungs .This may compromise adequate oxygenation and ventilation

  • Ventilation in patients with a congenital diaphragmatic hernia can be done by placing a nasogastric tube into the stomach for the removal of the air and secretions.

Incorrect Options: 

Option A - Cleft palate:

  • A cleft palate is a split or opening in the palate.

  • The Cleft palate causes a hole between the mouth and nose.

  • Bag and mask ventilation is not contraindicated in cleft palate patients

Option B - Umbilical hernia:

  • An umbilical hernia is very common in preterm babies.

  • Bag and mask ventilation is not contraindicated in the umbilical hernia

Option C - Cleft lip:

  • A cleft lip occurs when the developing facial structure doesn't close completely in an unborn baby.

  • The bag and mask ventilation is not contraindicated in cleft lip patients

questions.text: A 7-year-old girl was admitted to the outpatient department (OPD) after complaining of a fever, cough, and redness in both eyes for two days. The immunization was not finished by the patient according to the National immunization schedule. There are reddish patches on the child's buccal mucosa with a white core. Regarding this condition, which of the following states is true?

choices.text: Most common cause of death is Pneumonia
The fever stops before the onset of the rash

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Most common cause of death is Pneumonia:

  • The described clinical scenario suggests the diagnosis of measles.

  • After measles, cell-mediated immunity of the child decreases and child is prone to infections like respiratory infections, pneumonia, diarrhea. So, the most common cause of death in measles patient is Pneumonia

  • Vitamin A is often used in the treatment of measles, it helps in mucosal immunity.

Incorrect Options: 

Option B - It follows the iceberg phenomenon:

  • Measles does not follow the iceberg phenomenon.

Option C - The fever stops before the onset of rash:

  • Low-grade fever develops in the prodromal phase of measles.

  • The fever keeps increasing in intensity till the onset of the rash.

  • The fever and other prodromal symptoms of the infection begin to subside after the onset of the rash.

Option D - The incubation period is 10-21 days:

  • The incubation period of measles is 8-12 days

questions.text: A 5-year-old child was brought to the outpatient clinic complaining of a rash on her legs and buttocks, as well as pain in her ankle and abdomen joints. Examining her reveals tenderness in her abdomen, and both ankle joints, and a rash that does not blanch over when pressed. Her blood tests showed no abnormalities. Hematuria and proteinuria are shown in the urine report. Which diagnosis suits the patient most accurately?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Henoch-Schonlein purpura:

  • In this case, the findings constitute the classic triad for diagnosing Henoch-Schonlein purpura.

  • The classic triad comprises arthralgias, abdominal pain, and palpable purpura without thrombocytopenia on the buttocks/legs.

  • HSP is also known as anaphylactoid purpura.

  • It is a systemic, IgA-mediated vasculitis.

  • Henoch-Schonlein purpura - Small vessel vasculitis.

Incorrect Options: 

Option A - Kawasaki disease:

  • The patient usually presents with conjunctival infection, rash, and strawberry tongue.

  • It is most common in Asian children < 4 years of age.

  • Kawasaki disease - Medium vessel vasculitis

Option B - Juvenile Dermatomyositis:

  • MC Inflammatory myositis in children

  • The patient presents with proximal muscle weakness and a characteristic rash (Heliotrope rash and Gottron papules)

Option C - Systemic lupus erythematosus:

  • It is a type 3 hypersensitivity reaction.

  • It usually presents with a characteristic butterfly rash on the face, joint pain, and fever in a female of reproductive age.

questions.text: A 7-year-old child is admitted to the emergency room after complaining of five days of extreme, all-over body edema. In addition, the patient reports having difficulty breathing when lying down. He continues on to say that sitting upright helps with his dyspnea. The patient has pedal edema, facial puffiness, and periorbital edema, according to a physical examination. The patient has hypoalbuminemia and severe proteinuria, based on a blood and urine examination. Given the patient's present pathology, which medication is recommended?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Prednisolone:

  • This is a case of nephrotic syndrome in which the child is brought to the emergency department with complaints of severe generalized swelling of the body for 5 days.

  • The physical examination of the patient reveals periorbital edema, facial puffiness, and pedal edema, which suggest nephrotic syndrome.

  • The drug of choice for a child with first-episode nephrotic syndrome is oral prednisolone.

  • The generalized edema of the patient can be relieved by the administration of diuretics.

Incorrect Options: 

Option A - Mycophenolate mofetil:

  • Mycophenolate mofetil is an immunosuppressant drug.

  • It is used in autoimmune diseases.

  • It is used in relapsing nephrotic syndrome.

Option B - Cyclophosphamide:

  • The drug of choice for steroid-dependent nephrotic syndrome is Levamisole > cyclophosphamide.

  • SDNS (steroid-dependent nephrotic syndrome): 2 consecutive relapses during alternate-day steroid treatment or relapse within 14 days of stopping steroid therapy.

Option D - Cyclosporine:

  • Drugs of choice for steroid-resistant nephrotic syndrome are calcineurin inhibitors like cyclosporine and tacrolimus.

  • SRNS (Steroid resistant nephrotic syndrome): Inability to induce remission within 4 weeks of daily steroid therapy.

questions.text: The parents of a 7-month-old boy brought him in, complaining of persistent diarrhea after he began receiving a supplemental wheat diet. The infant shows pallor and delayed developmental milestones. The result of a duodenal biopsy is given below. Which of the following antibodies does not correspond with this illness?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Anti Topoisomerase-1:

  • The given duodenal biopsy depicts Villous atrophy.

  • The clinical scenario and biopsy suggestive of Celiac sprue/Celiac disease

  • Immunological factors of celiac disease:

    • Anti TTG (Tissue Trans Glutaminase)

    • Anti Endomysial Antibody (EMA)

    • Anti DGP (Deamidated gliadin peptide)

  • Anti Topoisomerase-1 antibody is associated with Scleroderma

Incorrect Options: 

Option A - Anti-TTG antibody:

  • Anti-TTG antibody is associated with Celiac disease

Option B - Anti-endomysial antibody:

  • Anti-endomysial antibody is associated with Celiac disease

Option D - Anti-gliadin antibody:

  • Anti-gliadin antibody is associated with Celiac disease

questions.text: The parents of a 6-year-old girl reported that their daughter swallowed a coin while playing and is currently being examined in the emergency room. The coin is found to be dislocated in the esophagus, as shown by a chest X-ray. The patient doesn't have difficulty breathing or drooling. Which of the following describes this condition's preferred method of treatment?

choices.text: Dislodge the coin to the stomach by inserting Ryle's tube

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Endoscopic removal after 24 hours:

  • This child has presented with the ingestion of a coin, and the radiography reveals the presence of the coin in the esophagus.

  • The child does not have a respiratory dress or any signs of esophageal obstruction.

  • The next best step in management is to wait for 24 hours for the spontaneous passage of the coin into the stomach.

Incorrect Options: 

Option A - Immediate endoscopic removal:

  • If the patient has respiratory distress or signs of esophageal obstruction, such as drooling or difficulty swallowing secretions, the coin should be immediately removed endoscopically.

Option C - Wait for 48 hours:

  • A wait of 24 hours is enough for the spontaneous passage of the coin into the stomach. If the coin does not pass into the stomach after 24 hours, it should be removed via flexible endoscopy.

Option D - Dislodge the coin to the stomach by inserting Ryle's tube:

  • If the patient is asymptomatic and the coin is located in the esophagus, it is better to wait for the spontaneous passage of the coin into the stomach.

questions.text: An eleven-year-old kid was brought to the outpatient department (OPD) complaining of three days of cola-colored urine, oliguria, facial puffiness, edema, and hypertension. No abnormalities were found during the general physical examination. The ASO titre level is elevated, C3 levels are decreasing, and urine albumin is positive. Red blood cells without red blood cell casts are visible in urinalysis. Two weeks ago, he suffered a skin infection, but it resolved after treatment. Which of the following characteristics most frequently corresponds to the pathology the patient currently has?

choices.text: C3 levels return to normal in 6-8 weeks
Cyclosporine is the treatment of choice
The most common age group involved is 1-4 years
Epithelial Crescents is the hallmark finding

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - C3 levels return to normal in 6-8 weeks:

  • This is a case of post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis, which is followed by infection of the throat or skin by certain “nephrogenic” strains of group A β-hemolytic streptococci (Throat serotypes - M1, M4, M25, and some strains of M12 and skin serotype - M49).

  • The serum C3 level is significantly reduced and returns to normal 6-8 weeks after onset.

Incorrect Options: 

Option B - Cyclosporine is the treatment of choice:

  • Management of PSGN involves

    • Diuretics

    • Early antibiotics do not eliminate the risk of glomerulonephritis

    • Salt and water restriction

  • Cyclosporine is not indicated in acute PSGN.

Option C - The most common age group involved is 1-4 years:

  • Poststreptococcal GN usually affects school-age children (5-12 years of age) and is uncommon below 3 years of age.

  • Symptoms usually appear 1-2 weeks after URI and 3-6 weeks after skin infections

Option D - Epithelial Crescents is the hallmark finding:

  • Epithelial Crescents is the hallmark finding of Rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis

  • In post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis- On electron microscopy, there are electron-dense deposits, or “humps,” are observed on the epithelial side of the glomerular basement membrane.

questions.text: All of the following given below are X-linked recessive disorders, except?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Rett syndrome:

  • Rett syndrome is an X-linked dominant inheritance

  • It is a condition more common in girls

  • Most common gene mutation: MECP 2 gene mutation

Incorrect Options: 

Option A - Duchenne muscular dystrophy:

  • Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD) is an X-linked recessive disorder

  • Dystrophin gene is affected in DMD

Option B - Fabry disease:

  • Mode of inheritance: X-linked recessive inheritance

  • It is a Lysosomal storage disorder

Option C - Hunter disease:

  • Mode of inheritance: X-linked recessive inheritance

  • It is a Type II Mucopolysaccharidosis

questions.text: What is the diagnosis for a 7-week-old baby who was brought to the emergency department with symptoms of inability to feed, irritability, fever with chills, and difficulty breathing for 2 days and on examination, temperature: 101°F, respiratory rate: 65/min, and presence of subcostal and intercostal recessions.?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Pneumonia:

  • The signs and symptoms of this child are suggestive of pneumonia.

    • The presence of any general danger signs or stridor in a calm child is classified as very severe pneumonia.

    • The danger signs include; persistent vomiting, confusion, convulsions, inability to drink or breastfeed, and lethargy.

    • Urgent admission to the hospital, management of the airway, treatment of fever, and antibiotic doses of ampicillin and gentamicin right away are recommended for very severe pneumonia.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Acute epiglottitis:

  • Symptoms include acute onset of high-grade fever, throat pain, drooling of saliva, muffled voice, respiratory distress, and stridor.

  • Treatment is supportive care and 3rd generation of cephalosporins for 10 days.

Option B - Croup:

  • Croup, also called acute laryngotracheobronchitis, is caused by para influenza.

  • X-ray shows a Steeple sign' due to subglottic narrowing.

  • Treatment includes oxygen support, a single dose of dexamethasone for mild cases

Option D - Acute tonsillitis:

  • It is usually caused by group A beta-hemolytic streptococci.

  • Treatment includes antibiotics and tonsillectomy.

questions.text:
A 51-year-old woman presents to the clinic with complaints of recurrent attacks of vertigo for 7 months associated with hearing loss and a feeling of fullness in the left ear. An audiogram is done as shown below. Which of the following will be seen as an examination finding in this patient?



                                       x : AC, ]:BC
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Low-frequency SNHL:

  • The other test performed in patients with Meniere's disease is an audiogram where it is typically observed that the hearing loss is more at lower frequencies.
  • Thus, at 250 hertz, the hearing threshold is at 70.
  • X is for air conduction of your left ear and close bracket - ']' is for bone conduction of your left ear.
  • Both air conduction and bone conduction are aﬀected because it's a sensorineural pathology.
  • At lower frequencies, the hearing loss is higher whereas at higher frequencies, the hearing is better. The graph is of an upsloping type of audiogram for left ear.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Webers towards the affected ear:

  • Rinne will be positive towards the normal ear, whereas Weber will be towards the affected ear.
  • Therefore this option is incorrect

Option C - SP/AP < 30%:

  • Testing the electrical activity produced by the eighth nerve and cochlea is known as electrocochleography and it is investigation of choice to diagnose meniere disease. SP/AP < 30% is suggestive of meniere disease. It can be used for intraoperative cochlear and eighth nerve monitoring.
  • The summating potential to action potential ratio i.e., SP/AP < 30% or 0.3 in normal individuals.

questions.text: An elderly diabetic female who was previously treated with steroids and Remdesivir for COVID has now presented with a black, foul-smelling discharge from the nose associated with headache and fever. An MRI was done. Which of the following signs will be seen?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Black turbinate sign:

  • Mucormycosis is a fungal infection of the nose and sinuses which may prove rapidly fatal. From the nose and sinuses, it rapidly spreads to involve the orbit, cribriform plate, meninges, and brain.
  • The typical finding is the presence of black necrotic material filling the nasal cavity and eroding the nasal septum, hard palate, and turbinates
  • The non enhancement of nasal turbinates is Seen on the MRI (hallmark sign)

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Empty delta sign:

  • Empty delta sign sign is seen in Dural sinovenous thrombosis
  • This is not associated with mucormycosis.

Option C - Bare orbit sign:

  • Bare orbit sign is seen in neurofibromatosis type 1 as a result of sphenoid wing dysplasia

Option D - Hot nose sign:

  • Hot nose sign is associated with brain death and serves as a secondary sign of brain death when intracerebral perfusion is absent

questions.text:
A 4-year-old child presents to the ER. The child is drooling and is agitated. The respiratory rate is 40 breaths per minute and the temperature is 102 F. An x-ray was done



Which of the following is responsible for the condition that the child is suffering from?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Streptococcus pneumonia:

  • Acute epiglottitis is the Inﬂammation of epiglottis.
  • Only supraglottic structures, Epiglottis, epiglottic fold, and arytenoids are involved.
  • The inﬂammation is secondary to bacteria such as streptococcus pneumonia.
  • In a Lateral View X-ray of the neck. A thumb sign is seen.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - H influenza:

  • Initially, it was caused by H inﬂuenza, but since vaccines are given. The inﬂammation is secondary to bacteria such as streptococcus pneumonia.

Option B - Parainfluenza:

  • Bronchitis is caused by the parainfluenza virus 1 and 2.
  • It leads to Inﬂammation of the larynx, trachea, and bronchus.

Option D - Group A beta-hemolytic streptococcus:

  • Group A beta-hemolytic streptococcus causes diseases such as scarlet fever, a bacterial infection characterized by sore throat and rash.

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman presents to the clinic with complaints of a change in voice for the past few days. She is a teacher by profession. She has no history of smoking. On examination, she has a low and raspy voice. Which of the following structures is affected in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Superﬁcial lamina propria:

  • Patients suffering from Reinke's edema have complained about diplophonia or a change in voice.
  • The vocal cord has four layers: Thyroarytenoid muscle, deep lamina propria, intermediate lamina propria, superﬁcial lamina propria, and the squamous epithelium.
  • The space between the epithelium and the superﬁcial lamina propria is called Reinke's space.
  • Whenever there is an accumulation of the edematous tissue or the myxomatous tissue in Reinke's space it is called Reinke's edema.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Thyroarytenoid muscle: Thyroarytenoid muscle is not affected in Reinke's edema

Option B - Deep lamina propria: Deep lamina propria is not affected in Reinke's edema

Option C - Intermediate lamina propria: Intermediate lamina propria is not affected in Reinke's edema

questions.text: A 65-year-old male presents with complaints of an increase in the size of his nose over the past few years. He is a diabetic with a history of chronic smoking for the past 20 years. Which of the following is the treatment of choice for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Co2 laser debridement:

  • Rhinophyma is hypertrophy of the sebaceous glands of patients with acne rosacea or diabetes mellitus or in elderly patients.
  • TOC is the removal of the tissue by carbon dioxide laser debridement of the hypertrophic tissue with a skin graft.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Augmentation rhinoplasty: Augmentation rhinoplasty is usually done in case of saddle nose deformity. It does not have any role in treating Rhinophyma

Option B - Surgical excision: Surgical excision with radiation is not a treatment choice for rhinophyma. It is used as a choice of treatment in squamous cell carcinoma

Option D - Reduction Rhinoplasty: Reduction Rhinoplasty is made to remove the excess bone edge in case of hump nose deformity

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect regarding the rodent ulcer?

choices.text: Mohs micrography is used for the detection
Caused by exposure to UV radiation
The most common tumor of the skin

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Ulcer with rolled-out edges:

  • Basal cell carcinoma is the most common malignant tumor of the skin of the external nose
  • It usually presents with a Cyst / Papulo pearly nodule or ulcer with rolled-in edges

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Mohs micrography is used for the detection:

  • This statement is correct regarding basal cell carcinoma
  • Mohs micrographic technique is used to detect it. If it continues to occur, then radiation therapy is done.

Option C - Caused by exposure to UV radiation:

  • Basal cell carcinoma is also called rodent ulcer
  • Caused by exposure to UV radiation

Option D - The most common tumor of the skin:

  • The most common tumor of the skin is basal carcinoma followed by the second most common tumor that is squamous cell carcinoma.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most appropriate regarding the landmark of the facial nerve in the labyrinthine segment?

choices.text: Anterior : vestibule, middle : cochlea, posterior : semicircular canals
Anterior : cochlea, middle : vestibule, posterior : semicircular canals
Anterior : semicircular canals middle : vestibule , posterior : cochlea
Anterior : cochlea, middle : semicircular canals, posterior : vestibule

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Anterior : cochlea, middle : vestibule, posterior : semicircular canals:

  • Labyrinthine Segment (3-4mm Length and 0.7mm Diameter, Shortest and Narrowest segment).
  • This port is the segment of the facial nerve in the inner ear Since it's the narrowest portion it is prone to ischemia and edema (bell's palsy).
  • Anterior: cochlea, middle : vestibule, posterior : semicircular canals.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Anterior : vestibule, middle : cochlea, posterior : semicircular canals: The facial nerve runs above the vestibule, so anteriorly there is a cochlea and posteriorly there is semi-circular canals.

Option C - Anterior : semicircular canals middle : vestibule , posterior : cochlea : Anterior : cochlea, middle : vestibule, posterior : semicircular canals

Option D - Anterior : cochlea, middle : semicircular canals, posterior : vestibule: Anterior : cochlea, middle : vestibule, posterior : semicircular canals

questions.text: A 11 year old boy presents to the ER with complaints of nasal discharge following trauma. On examination the discharge appears clear and watery in consistency. Which of the following tests is a hallmark to confirm whether the discharge is CSF ?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Beta 2 transferrin test:

  • The beta-2 transferrin test is the hallmark test for CSF since beta-2 transferrin is a protein present only in the CSF.
  • If beta-2 transferrin is positive, then it's 100% CSF.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Reservoirs sign:

  • CSF rhinorrhea shows a positive reservoir sign.
  • But this is not a hallmark test for identifying whether it is CSF or nasal secretion

Option B - Handkerchief sign:

  • In cases of the common cold, upon blowing into the handkerchief, there's stiffening of the handkerchief.
  • However, in patients with CSF rhinorrhea, there's no stiffening of the handkerchief.

Option C - Glucose estimation test:

  • Content of the fluid should be 2/3rd of the blood glucose of the patient.
  • Still, this test is not the confirmatory test of the presence of CSF.

questions.text: Merciful anosmia is seen in which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Atrophic rhinitis:

  • Merciful anosmia: Patient himself is unware of the smell due to marked anosmia.
  • The patient may complain of nasal obstruction inspite of unduly wide nasal chambers
  • It is a feature of Atrophic rhinitis

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Drug-induced rhinitis:

  • If the drug as a side effect is causing rhinitis, then it is called drug-induced rhinitis.
  • Merciful anosmia is not a feature

Option C - Vasomotor rhinitis:

  • When the symptoms are similar to allergy but serum IgE is normal, eosinophil count is normal called Vasomotor rhinitis.
  • Merciful anosmia is not a feature

Option D - Non allergic rhinitis:

  • It is defined as allergic rhinitis but clinically stimulates nasal allergy with symptoms of nasal obstruction, rhinorrhea, and sneezing but the serum IgE level is normal.
  • Merciful anosmia is not a feature of Non-allergic rhinitis

questions.text: A 17-year-old boy presented with complaints of recurrent epistaxis. Holmann miller sign is seen on CT scan. Which of the following is the most common site of origin for the condition that the patient is suffering from?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Sphenopalatine foramen:

  • Angiofibroma is a tumor filled with lots of blood vessels andfibrous tissue.
  • Most common site of origin is from sphenopalatine foramen (near posterior wall of maxillary sinus).

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Fossa of rosenmuller:

  • JNA does not originate form fossa of rosenmuller
  • It is a site of origin for Nasopharyngeal carcinoma

Option C - Maxillary sinus:

  • JNA does not originate from maxillary sinus

Option D - Pituitary:

  • JNA does not originate from pituitary
  • Pituitary adenoma is a benign tumour that arises in pituitary

questions.text: A 45 year old female presented to the clinic with complaints of sudden onset of a sense of spinning motion in the surroundings associated with nausea and vomiting for the past few days. She was suffering from a viral infection a few days ago. On further evaluation, the hearing tests came out to be normal. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis for this patient ?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Vestibular neuronitis:

  • It is characterized by sudden onset of vertigo, nausea, and vomiting without deafness and tinnitus.There is no hearing loss.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Vestibular labrynthitis:

  • Labyrinthitis leads to inflammation of the entire labyrinth.
  • The problem is observed to exist for several days to a few months.· In this, a person has hearing loss.

Option C - Peri lymph fistula:

  • In this , Perilymph leaks through the oval window and round window and often presents with intermittent vertigo caused by surgery , trauma or CSOM

Option D - BPPV:

  • This also cause vertigo without hearing loss but as the question mentions a history of viral infection, vestibular neuronitis is the diagnosis

questions.text: A 6-year-old child is brought by his mother to the clinic with complaints of inattention and poor school performance. He had a history of fever and otalgia 12 weeks ago. A tympanometry was done. Which of the following will be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - 

  • SOM is a common sequel to Acute otitis media in children and may persist for weeks to months when the air reaching the Eustachian tube or the ventilation to the middle ear gets reduced.
  • This results in negative pressure in the middle ear.
  • If this negative pressure is present for some time, it acts on the mucosal cells of the middle ear.
  • Slowly there's exudate formation in the middle ear.
  • Presence of air bubbles and air-fluid level (hallmark for SOM).
  • Type B represents a flat curve seen if there is fluid in the middle ear

Incorrect Options:

Option A - 

  • Type A represents a normal tympanogram

 

Option C - 

  • Type C is seen in eustachian tube obstruction
  • Represents maximum compliance in negative pressure

 

Option D - 

  • Type Ad is seen in diseases such as otosclerosis.
  • It represents lower compliance at or near ambient pressure

questions.text: A 28-year-old male underwent endoscopic sinus surgery. later on, the patient developed periorbital ecchymosis and blurring of vision. Which of the following has caused this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Anterior ethmoidal artery bleed:

  • Blurring of vision is mostly caused by the traumatized ethmoidal artery. As they are traveling from the medial wall of the orbit to the ethmoidal sinuses.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Sphenopalatine bleeding:

  • The sphenopalatine artery is also known as the artery of epistaxis but in this case, the periorbital ecchymosis and blurring of vision is caused by the trauma to the ethmoidal artery

Option C - IMA bleed:

  • Internal maxillary artery can be traumatized intraoperatively during Posterior osteotomy
  • Not in the case of endoscopic sinus surgery

Option D - Facial artery bleed:

  • The facial artery gives rise to a superior labial artery. The superior labial artery supplies the septum inferiorly via the septal branch. however, periorbital ecchymosis and blurring of vision are caused by trauma to the ethmoidal artery

questions.text:
A 28-year-old male presents to the emergency department with sudden-onset sharp chest pain on the left side. He reports no recent trauma or heavy lifting. On examination, decreased breath sounds and hyperresonance on percussion are noted on the left side of the chest. Chest X-ray is given below.



What is the ideal management of this case?

choices.text: Observation with serial chest X-rays and supplemental oxygen therapy.
Administration of nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) for pain control and reassessment in 24 hours.

questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Needle decompression:

  • The patient's presentation, including sudden-onset sharp chest pain, decreased breath sounds, and hyperresonance on percussion, suggests a tension pneumothorax, a life-threatening emergency. Needle decompression is the immediate intervention of choice to release trapped air in the pleural space, alleviate pressure on the affected lung, and stabilize the patient.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Inhalational Corticosteroids:

  • Inhalational corticosteroids are not indicated in the management of pneumothorax. They are typically used in conditions such as asthma or chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD).

Option B - Observation with Serial Chest X-rays and Supplemental Oxygen Therapy:

  • Observation and serial chest X-rays are not ideal for managing a symptomatic pneumothorax. Immediate intervention is required rather than observation.

Option C - Administration of Nonsteroidal Anti-Inflammatory Drugs (NSAIDs) for Pain Control and Reassessment in 24 Hours:

  • NSAIDs do not address the underlying issue of trapped air in the pleural space. The patient requires a more definitive intervention with chest tube placement.

questions.text:
A 60-year-old immunocompromised patient presents with a persistent cough and fever. Chest CT reveals the following:



What is the most likely organism responsible for the patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Mycobacterium tuberculosis:

  • The "tree-in-bud" appearance on chest CT is a characteristic finding associated with Mycobacterium tuberculosis infections. This appearance represents centrilobular nodules and branching linear opacities, indicating the spread of infection along the airways and bronchioles. In immunocompromised individuals, such as the presented patient, tuberculosis can manifest with atypical radiological patterns.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - COVID-19 (SARS-CoV-2):

  • COVID-19 typically presents with bilateral, peripheral ground-glass opacities on chest CT. The "tree-in-bud" appearance is not a typical radiological finding in COVID-19 pneumonia.

Option C - Aspergillus:

  • Aspergillus infections can lead to various radiological patterns, including nodules and cavities, but the "tree-in-bud" appearance is more characteristic of mycobacterial infections like tuberculosis.

Option D - Klebsiella:

  • Klebsiella pneumoniae can cause pneumonia with a tendency for cavitary lesions. However, the "tree-in-bud" appearance is not typically associated with Klebsiella pneumonia.

questions.text: A middle-aged female with sudden onset of headache and neck rigidity. There is no history of trauma. NCCT head scan is shown below. What could be the probable diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Subarachnoid Hemorrhage (SAH):

  • The sudden onset of headache and neck rigidity, especially without a history of trauma, is highly suggestive of a subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH). The NCCT scan image showing star of death appearance further supports this diagnosis. SAH refers to bleeding into the space between the arachnoid membrane and the pia mater, usually caused by the rupture of an intracranial aneurysm. The most common symptom is a severe headache, often described as "the worst headache of my life."

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Meningitis:

  • While meningitis can present with headache and neck rigidity, the acute onset and the presence of star of death appearance on NCCT scan make SAH a more likely diagnosis in this case.

Option C - Epidural Hematoma:

  • Epidural hematomas typically result from trauma, and they are characterized by bleeding between the skull and the dura mater. The absence of trauma makes this an unlikely diagnosis.

Option D - Intraventricular Hemorrhage (IVH):

  • Intraventricular hemorrhage involves bleeding into the brain's ventricular system. While it can occur, especially in premature infants, the symptoms described are more indicative of SAH.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female presents with progressive dysphagia to both solids and liquids. A barium swallow study is performed, revealing dilatation of the esophagus with a narrowed distal esophageal segment, and is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Achalasia cardia:

  • Achalasia is a motility disorder characterized by impaired relaxation of the lower oesophageal sphincter and absent peristalsis in the oesophagus. The classic radiographic finding in achalasia is the "bird's beak" appearance, which represents the narrowed and tapered distal oesophagus on a barium swallow study.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD):

  • GERD refers to the backward flow of gastric contents into the oesophagus, leading to symptoms such as heartburn and regurgitation. It does not typically present with the "bird's beak" appearance seen in achalasia.

Option C - Oesophageal carcinoma:

  • Oesophageal carcinoma refers to malignant tumours arising from the oesophageal epithelium. While it can cause oesophageal narrowing, apple core appearance is seen.

Option D - Oesophageal web:

  • Oesophageal webs are seen in Plummer Vinson syndrome. A smooth, thin strip may be seen on X-ray in case of esophageal web.

questions.text: A 27-year-old female tourist who had been missing for a week was found near a waterfall, the forensic team has noted the presence of Masque Ecchymotique. What could this finding suggest as a possible cause of death?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Traumatic asphyxia:

  • The presence of Masque Ecchymotique, indicates traumatic asphyxia.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Ligature strangulation:

  • The ligature mark is transverse, complete below the thyroid cartilage (mostly).
  • Masque Ecchymotique is not seen in this case.

Option B - Manual strangulation:

  • Constriction of the neck by hands/ fingers manually is known as manual strangulation.
  • Masque Ecchymotique is not seen in this case.

Option D - Drowning:

  • Drowning involves submersion in a liquid, usually water, leading to respiratory failure. While drowning can cause external signs of trauma, it doesn't typically result in Masque Ecchymotique.

questions.text: A 35-year-old individual presents to the psychiatric clinic with a history of recurrent aggressive fantasies, a fascination with causing physical or psychological suffering to others, and a notable lack of empathy. The patient describes deriving pleasure from inflicting pain and humiliation. What psychiatric term is most appropriate to describe this pattern of behavior?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Sadism:

  • Sexual preference disorder focuses on the infliction of suffering, pain, or humiliation to achieve sexual gratification.
  • To obtain sexual gratification the sadist may hurt or ill-treat or torture his sexual partner in many other cruel ways.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Voyeurism:

  • Voyeurism is the act of observing or spying on individuals who are naked or engaged in sexual activity without their knowledge or consent, for the purpose of sexual gratification. This behavior does not involve inflicting pain or harm on others, as in the scenario described.

Option B - Fetishism:

  • Fetishism is a type of sexual disorder in which an individual is sexually aroused by inanimate objects (bra and underpants) of the opposite sex.

Option D - Masochism:

  • Masochism is a sexual disorder in which an individual derives sexual pleasure from receiving pain or humiliation. In the scenario described, the individual is inflicting pain and harm on their partner rather than receiving it themselves.

questions.text: Which IPC section is applicable in cases involving criminal abortion without the woman's consent?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - IPC 313:

  • Section 313 of the IPC states the punishment for conducting criminal abortion without the consent of a female

Incorrect Options:

Option A - IPC 312:

  • Punishment for conducting criminal abortion with the consent of the pregnant female

Option C - IPC 314:

  • Punishment for any kind of criminal abortion resulting in the death of the female.

Option D - IPC 315:

  • Gives punishment for any person who does an act, with the intent to prevent the child from being born alive to cause it to die after birth.

questions.text: Who conducts the inquest when a male, who kidnapped a 14-year-old girl, is arrested by the police but dies while in police custody?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Judicial magistrate:

  • The inquest in the given scenario would typically be conducted by a Judicial magistrate.
  • Judicial magistrate conducts the inquest for police beating deaths as well as police custodial deaths.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Police:

  • The police are responsible for inquest in cases of unnatural deaths like in :
    • Accidental case
    • Suicide case
    • Homicide case

Option B - Executive magistrate:

  • The executive magistrate can con conduct an inquest in the following cases:
    • Dowry death
    • Exhumation
    • Encounter death

Option C - Medical examiner:

  • A Medical Examiner may provide valuable information and evidence during an inquest, but they are not typically responsible for conducting the inquest itself.

questions.text:
A 55-year-old woman complains of pain and stiffness in her hands, particularly in the morning. She notices swelling and warmth in multiple joints, and there is a mild deformity in the proximal interphalangeal (PIP) joints. On examination, the following finding is noted:



Which of the following joints is most likely affected in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Distal interphalangeal (DIP) joints:

  • The clinical presentation of pain, stiffness in the morning, swelling, and warmth in multiple joints, along with the presence of Heberden's nodes and Bouchard’s nodes, are indicative of osteoarthritis (OA), particularly in the hands.
  • Heberden's nodes are bony enlargements that occur at the distal interphalangeal (DIP) joints, which are the joints closest to the fingertips. These nodes are a characteristic feature of osteoarthritis affecting the hand joints.
  • In osteoarthritis of the hands, the DIP joints are commonly involved, leading to the development of Heberden's nodes. Osteoarthritis primarily affects the articular cartilage, leading to joint space narrowing, osteophyte formation, and bony changes such as the development of Heberden's nodes.

Incorrect Options:

  • Options A, B, and C are less likely to be affected in the described clinical scenario. Osteoarthritis typically involves weight-bearing joints such as the knees and hips, but the presence of Heberden's nodes points toward the involvement of the DIP joints in this case.

questions.text:
A 35-year-old man presents with severe pain and deformity in his left upper arm following a fall from a height. On examination, there is significant swelling, and the patient is unable to actively move his left arm. An X-ray is given:



What is the most appropriate management for this patient?

choices.text: Closed reduction and immobilization in a cast
Physical therapy for a range of motion exercises

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Closed reduction and immobilization in a cast:

  • In the case of a mid-shaft fracture of the humerus, the initial management often involves closed reduction and immobilization in a cast. Closed reduction is the manipulation of the fractured bone fragments to restore alignment without a surgical incision. Following reduction, the arm is typically immobilized in a cast to allow for healing.
  • Radial nerve injury is a potential complication associated with mid-shaft fractures of the humerus. Patients may experience weakness or paralysis of the muscles controlled by the radial nerve, leading to difficulty in extending the wrist, fingers, and thumb. Sensory deficits in the back of the hand and forearm may also be present.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Open reduction and internal fixation (ORIF):

  • Open reduction and internal fixation (ORIF) may be considered if there are specific indications, such as significant displacement of fracture fragments, open fractures, or vascular or nerve injuries. However, the initial approach for many mid-shaft humeral fractures involves attempting closed reduction and immobilization.

Option B & C - Application of a functional brace and physical therapy for range of motion exercises:

  • These are not typically the initial steps in the management of acute fractures but may be considered in the later stages of rehabilitation once initial healing has occurred.

questions.text:
A 50-year-old man presents with sudden-onset severe pain, swelling, and redness in his left big toe. He reports a history of recurrent episodes of similar symptoms in multiple joints, including the knees and ankles. On examination, the affected joint is warm, and tender, and has a limited range of motion. Laboratory analysis is given:


	
		
			Test Name
			Result
		
		
			Uric acid
			9.5
		
	


What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Gout:

  • Gout is a form of inflammatory arthritis characterized by the sudden onset of severe pain, swelling, redness, and tenderness, typically affecting the joint at the base of the big toe. It is caused by the deposition of urate crystals in the joints and surrounding tissues. Individuals with gout often have elevated levels of serum uric acid, a byproduct of purine metabolism.
  • The classic presentation of acute gout involves the first metatarsophalangeal joint (podagra), but it can also affect other joints such as the knees and ankles. Recurrent episodes of gout may lead to the development of tophi, which are urate crystal deposits that can be palpated as nodules under the skin.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Osteoarthritis:

  • It is a degenerative joint disease characterized by the breakdown of joint cartilage, leading to pain and stiffness.

Option B - Rheumatoid arthritis:

  • It is an autoimmune disease that primarily affects the synovium of joints, causing inflammation and joint damage.

Option C - Psoriatic arthritis:

  • It is a type of inflammatory arthritis associated with psoriasis.

questions.text:
A 20-year-old patient presents with localized pain and swelling in the distal femur. X-ray revealed the following findings:



Biopsy confirms the presence of malignant osteoid-producing cells. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Osteosarcoma:

  • Osteosarcoma is a primary malignant bone tumor that arises from primitive bone-forming mesenchymal cells. It commonly occurs in the metaphysis of long bones, particularly around the knee joint. The presentation includes localized pain, swelling, and sometimes a palpable mass.
  • The characteristic radiographic findings of osteosarcoma include a lytic lesion with an aggressive periosteal reaction, forming Codman's triangle. Codman's triangle is a triangular area of new subperiosteal bone formation, often seen in aggressive bone lesions where the periosteum is lifted off the bone.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Osteochondroma:

  • Osteochondromas are benign bone tumors characterized by the overgrowth of cartilage and bone near the end of long bones. They usually occur in adolescents and young adults. Radiographically, they appear as a bony projection with a cartilage cap, and they do not typically exhibit aggressive features like Codman's triangle.

Option B - Ewing sarcoma:

  • Ewing sarcoma is a malignant bone tumor that often arises in the diaphysis of long bones, pelvis, or chest wall. It is more common in children and young adults. Radiographically, it may present as a permeative, destructive lesion, but it is not typically associated with Codman's triangle. Ewing sarcoma is characterized by small, round, blue cells in histology.

Option D - Chondrosarcoma:

  • Chondrosarcoma is a malignant cartilage-forming tumor that most commonly occurs in adults. Radiographically, it may appear as a lytic or mixed lytic/sclerotic lesion with areas of calcification. It is not typically associated with Codman's triangle.

questions.text: Sarah, a 9-year-old girl, is brought to a developmental clinic by her parents. Her parents say she doesn't like to interact with others in school as well as in society. Sarah has good language skills and has never experienced any language delay. She struggles with non-verbal communicative gestures and often engages in repetitive behaviours. Her parents are concerned about her condition and seek a diagnosis. Based on the presented scenario, what is the most likely diagnosis for Sarah?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Asperger syndrome:

  • This is the most likely diagnosis for Sarah based on the presented scenario. Asperger syndrome is characterized by good language skills without any language delay, impairment in non-verbal communicative gestures, and a repetitive pattern of behaviour. Sarah's struggle with non-verbal gestures and engaging in repetitive behaviours aligns with the symptoms of Asperger syndrome.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Intellectual Disability Disorder:

  • Intellectual disability, formerly known as mental retardation, is a condition characterized by limitations in cognitive functioning and adaptive behaviour. It typically manifests during childhood and results in difficulties with learning, problem-solving, and independent daily living.

Option C - Specific Language Impairment (SLI):

  • SLI is characterized by difficulties specifically in language acquisition and use, but Sarah's good language skills indicate that language impairment is not the primary concern.

Option D - Attention-Deficit/Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD):

  • ADHD involves symptoms of inattention, hyperactivity, and impulsivity, which are not specifically mentioned in the scenario. Sarah's difficulties primarily revolve around social interactions and repetitive behaviours, suggesting a different diagnosis.

questions.text: During a routine psychiatric evaluation, a 30-year-old male patient is observed to display unusual motor symptoms. The examiner attempts to move his arms, but there is a noticeable resistance initially and then the examiner can move the arms freely and makes the patient come in a position as shown in the image below and slowly the arms of the patient come down. Which of the following terms best describes the patient’s behaviour?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Waxy flexibility:

  • Waxy flexibility is a motor symptom commonly observed in patients with catatonic features of schizophrenia. It is characterized by the feeling of resistance encountered when attempting to move the patient's limbs or body into different positions. The patient's body seems to exhibit a pliable and moldable quality, similar to the bending of a wax candle. Waxy flexibility is a passive phenomenon, meaning the resistance is felt when the examiner tries to move the patient's body.

Incorrect Options:

Option A – Catalepsy:

  • Catalepsy refers to maintaining an odd posture for an extended period. It is a passive phenomenon where the patient maintains the posture in response to external instructions, such as the examiner asking the patient to hold a particular position. Catalepsy does not involve the feeling of resistance encountered during movement, as seen in the described scenario.

Option B – Posturing:

  • Posturing is similar to catalepsy in that it involves maintaining an odd posture for an extended duration. However, posturing is an active phenomenon where the patient spontaneously assumes the posture without external instructions. In the described scenario, the patient complies with the examiner's request, suggesting a response to external instruction rather than spontaneous posturing.

Option D – Negativism:

  • Negativism refers to the patient's opposition or lack of response to instructions. It is characterized by a resistance to comply with commands or a tendency to do the opposite of what is requested. While negativism can be observed in patients with catatonic features, it does not specifically describe the motor symptoms mentioned in the scenario.

questions.text: A 21-year-old individual presents to the emergency department after attending a party. On examination, the person appears euphoric, with redness of the conjunctiva, increased appetite, impaired motor coordination, and is talking continuously. The person also experiences a sense of time distortion and complains of dry mouth. The most likely diagnosis for this individual is:
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Cannabis Intoxication:

  • This option is the correct answer as the individual presents with the typical symptoms of cannabis intoxication, including euphoria, redness of the conjunctiva, increased appetite, impaired motor coordination, sense of time distortion, and dry mouth.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Alcohol Intoxication:

  • While alcohol intoxication can cause euphoria and impaired motor coordination, it typically does not cause redness of the conjunctiva or increased appetite. Dry mouth can be seen with alcohol intoxication but is more commonly associated with cannabis use.

Option C - Cocaine Intoxication:

  • Cocaine intoxication can cause euphoria, increased energy, and impaired motor coordination. However, it does not typically cause redness of the conjunctiva, increased appetite, or a sense of time distortion.

Option D - Amphetamine Intoxication:

  • Amphetamine intoxication can lead to euphoria, increased energy, and impaired motor coordination. However, it does not typically cause redness of the conjunctiva, increased appetite, or a sense of time distortion. Additionally, dry mouth is more commonly associated with cannabis use.

questions.text: At what BAC level is an individual likely to experience incoordination, judgment errors, and mood lability?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - 80-200 mg/dl:

  • Incoordination, judgment errors, and mood lability are associated with a blood alcohol concentration (BAC) level of 80-200 mg/dl.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - 20-30 mg/dl:

  • Slowed motor performance is seen at BAC levels of 20-30 mg/dl and not incoordination, judgment errors, and mood lability.

Option B - 30-80 mg/dl:

  • An increase in cognitive problems are seen at BAC levels of 30-80 mg/dl, not incoordination, judgment errors, and mood lability.

Option D - 200-300 mg/dl:

  • Nystagmus, slurring speech, and alcoholic blackouts are seen at BAC levels of 200-300 mg/dl, not incoordination, judgment errors, and mood lability.

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy underwent knee surgery for a ligament tear. A vertical incision was made. As a result, the wound edges kept gaping, and poor healing was observed. Which concept of skin anatomy explains the cause of this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Langer's lines:

  • Langer's lines, also known as cleavage lines or tension lines, represent the natural orientation of collagen fibers within the skin. These lines indicate the direction of tension and elasticity in the skin. When surgical incisions are made parallel to Langer's lines, the wound edges align with the natural tension lines, resulting in better wound healing and minimal scarring. However, in this case, the incision was made perpendicular to the lines of tension, leading to a tendency for the wound edges to gape and heal poorly.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Blaschko lines: Blaschko lines represent an invisible pattern of embryonic cell migration and are not directly related to wound healing or surgical incisions. They are important in understanding certain skin conditions that follow this pattern of distribution, but they do not explain the phenomenon described in the question.

Option B - Terry’s lines: These refer to lines in the nails - the nail is white proximally and normal distally. These are not associated with the skin concept asked in the question.

Option D - Mees lines: These are transverse white lines that traverse fingernails. They are commonly seen in arsenic poisoning. These are not associated with the skin concept asked in the question.

questions.text: Which of the following phenomenon is most likely to be seen in a patient of verruca vulgaris?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Pseudo Koebner phenomenon:

  • Pseudokoebner phenomenon refers to the development of new skin lesions along the lines of trauma caused to an existing skin lesion, thereby causing it to spread to those sites.
  • Therefore, it is practically autoinoculation of the new sites.
  • It is seen in infections- warts, molluscum

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Lucio phenomenon: Lucio’s phenomenon is an uncommon and unusual reaction that occurs in patients with diffuse lepromatous leprosy (DLL). It is not seen in verruca vulgaris.

Option B - Koebner phenomenon: The Koebner phenomenon, also known as the isomorphic response, refers to the development of new skin lesions or the worsening of pre-existing lesions at sites of skin trauma. It is commonly observed in individuals with psoriasis, LP and vitiligo but the history of these pathologies is not described in the question ruling out this option.

Option D - Uhthoff phenomenon: It refers to a phenomenon of neurological symptoms that are triggered by heat exposure. It is not associated with verruca vulgaris. It is seen in Multiple sclerosis.

questions.text: A 40-year-old female who has recently moved here from Iran came with complaints of progressively enlarging vesicles on her back. She gives a similar history of the appearance of vesicles attributing it to mental stress. On examination, a few vesicles and bullae are seen that are bulla spread sign positive. A biopsy shows intra-epidermal involvement of the blister. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Pemphigus vulgaris:

  • Pemphigus vulgaris is an immuno-bullous disorder characterized by intraepidermal blister formation. It is caused by autoantibodies targeting desmoglein proteins, which are components of the desmosomal adhesion complexes that hold keratinocytes together in the epidermis. The autoantibodies disrupt the adhesion between keratinocytes, leading to the formation of blisters within the epidermis. The positive bulla spread sign is a characteristic feature of Pemphigus vulgaris.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Bullous pemphigoid: Bullous pemphigoid is characterized by sub-epidermal blister formation, rather than intraepidermal blister formation. It is caused by autoantibodies targeting components of the basement membrane zone, specifically BP180 and BP230.

Option C - Epidermolysis bullosa: Epidermolysis bullosa is a group of acquired disorders characterized by blistering of the skin and mucous membranes. Bullae are formed at the site of trauma and they heal with scarring.

Option D - Dermatitis herpetiformis: Dermatitis herpetiformis is an autoimmune disorder. Itchy excoriated papulo-vesicular lesions are present on extensors and trunk. No bulla are seen.

questions.text:
A 25-year-old female came with peculiar complaints about her fingernails. The image depicts the cause for her concern.



Which of the following statements is true regarding this presentation?

choices.text: It is caused due to hypoalbuminemia
It can be blanched and is caused by external factors.
It results from a localized problem in the nail matrix.

questions.solution:
Correct Option C – It results from a localized problem in the nail matrix:

  • The image suggests diagnosis of true leukonychia. True leukonychia refers to the presence of white discoloration in the nail plate. It is caused by a localized problem in the nail matrix, which is the area where the nail is formed. This can result from trauma, injury, or inflammation of the nail matrix or in case of arsenic, thallium poisoning and chemotherapy.

Incorrect Options:

Options A - It is caused due to hypoalbuminemia:

  • True leukonychia is not caused due to hypoalbuminemia. Hypoalbuminemia causes false leukonychia that are called Muehrcke's paired white bands.

Option B - It can be blanched and is caused by external factors:

  • True leukonychia is caused by a localized problem in the nail matrix and the spots cannot be blanched. Blanching may be present in cases of false leukonychia.

Option D - It is a contagious condition that can spread from person to person:

  • True leukonychia is not a contagious condition that can spread from person to person.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient is scheduled for surgery, and the anesthesia plan involves the use of halothane. The anesthesiologist is considering the Minimum Alveolar Concentration (MAC) of halothane. What does a higher MAC value for halothane indicate for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D- Decreased anesthetic potency:

  • The Minimum Alveolar Concentration (MAC) represents the concentration of an inhalational anesthetic at which 50% of patients do not respond to a surgical stimulus. A higher MAC value indicates decreased potency, meaning a higher concentration of the anesthetic is needed to achieve the desired effect.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Increased anesthetic potency:

  • A higher MAC value indicates decreased potency, not increased potency. A lower MAC value reflects greater potency, as less anesthetic is needed to produce the desired effect.

Option B - Faster onset of action:

  • MAC is not directly related to the onset of action. The onset of action is influenced by factors such as blood solubility and alveolar ventilation, whereas MAC specifically refers to the concentration needed for a lack of response to a surgical stimulus.

Option C - Lower concentration required for anesthesia:

  • A higher MAC value indicates that a higher concentration of the anesthetic is required for anesthesia, not a lower concentration. Lower MAC values represent greater potency.

questions.text: Which of the following methods is considered the most reliable for confirming the correct placement of an endotracheal tube in a 30-year-old male patient who has been intubated for surgery by the final-year resident?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D- End-tidal CO2 concentration:

  • End-tidal CO2 concentration is the ideal method to confirm the endotracheal tube position during surgery.
  • This technique is also known as capnography. This technique measures the amount of CO2 in the exhaled breath.

Incorrect Options:

Option A- Chest X-ray:

  • Chest X-ray takes time, and the process can introduce a delay between intubation and confirmation. During this time, critical issues such as hypoxia due to esophageal intubation may go unnoticed.
  • In critical situations, immediate confirmation of endotracheal tube placement is crucial for patient safety. Waiting for a chest X-ray may not be feasible in such cases.

Option B- Auscultation:

  • Auscultation can be used to identify the initial clues of the endotracheal tube placement.
  • However, it cannot be used as a definitive technique as the breath sounds can be misleading and produce false results.

Option C- Pulse oximetry:

  • Pulse oximetry provides information about oxygen saturation but does not confirm the endotracheal tube's location. In cases of esophageal intubation, oxygen saturation can still be maintained, leading to a false sense of security. EtCO2 is a more direct indicator of correct tube placement.

questions.text: What is the colour of the nitrous oxide cylinder?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A- Blue:

  • In the standardized colour-coding system for gas cylinders, blue is the designated colour for nitrous oxide.

Incorrect Options:

Option B- White shoulder and Black body:

  • Oxygen cylinder has white shoulder and black body

Option C- Brown:

  • Heliox cylinder has Brown colour code

Option D- Grey:

  • Carbon dioxide has Grey colour code

questions.text: In the management of malignant hyperthermia, what is considered the treatment of choice to rapidly reverse the effects of the condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Intravenous dantrolene:

  • Intravenous dantrolene is the treatment of choice for malignant hyperthermia. It acts by inhibiting calcium release from the sarcoplasmic reticulum in skeletal muscle, helping to reverse the hypermetabolic state and muscle rigidity associated with malignant hyperthermia.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Epinephrine infusion:

  • Epinephrine may be used in the treatment of malignant hyperthermia to support cardiovascular function and treat hypotension, but it is not the primary treatment for reversing the hypermetabolic state.

Option C- Sodium bicarbonate:

  • Sodium bicarbonate may be used to correct metabolic acidosis that can occur in malignant hyperthermia, but it is not the primary treatment to reverse the condition.

Option D - Intravenous atropine:

  • Atropine is not a specific treatment for malignant hyperthermia. It is used to treat bradycardia and may be administered in certain situations, but it does not directly address the underlying hypermetabolic state.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man with a history of diabetes mellitus presents with polyuria and polydipsia. A urinalysis reveals glucosuria, indicating the presence of glucose in the urine. Which part of the nephron is primarily responsible for the reabsorption of glucose?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Proximal convoluted tubule:

  • Location: The reabsorption of glucose primarily occurs in the proximal convoluted tubule (PCT) of the nephron.
  • Transporters: Glucose reabsorption is facilitated by sodium-glucose cotransporters (SGLTs) located on the apical membrane of the PCT cells.
  • Active Transport: The process involves active transport of glucose against its concentration gradient, utilizing the sodium gradient established by the sodium-potassium pump.
  • Secondary Active Transport: Sodium ions are simultaneously transported with glucose into the tubular cells through SGLTs.
  • Basolateral Membrane: Once inside the tubular cells, glucose exits through facilitated diffusion across the basolateral membrane, facilitated by glucose transporters (GLUTs).
  • Water Reabsorption: The reabsorption of glucose is coupled with the reabsorption of water, maintaining osmotic balance in the nephron.
  • Glomerular Filtration: Glucose is filtered at the glomerulus, and under normal conditions, virtually all filtered glucose is reabsorbed in the PCT.
  • Renal Threshold: The renal threshold for glucose reabsorption is the plasma glucose concentration at which glucose starts appearing in the urine. It is usually around 180 mg/dL.
  • Pathological Conditions: Conditions such as diabetes mellitus, where blood glucose levels are elevated, can exceed the renal threshold, leading to glucosuria (glucose in the urine).

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Loop of Henle:

  • The loop of Henle plays a crucial role in the concentration and dilution of urine.
  • It creates an osmotic gradient in the medulla, allowing for the reabsorption of water and solutes.

Option C - Distal Convoluted Tubule (DCT):

  • The DCT is involved in fine-tuning the reabsorption of ions, particularly sodium and calcium.
  • It also plays a role in pH regulation by secreting hydrogen ions and reabsorbing bicarbonate.

Option D - Collecting Duct:

  • The collecting duct is responsible for concentrating or diluting urine based on the body's hydration status.
  • It reabsorbs water and regulates the final concentration of urine.
